EnglishScore: Foreign students are required to take the TOEFL or IELTS exam. The required minimum TOEFL score is 90 for the internet-based test. The required minimum IELTS score is 6.5, with no subsection below 6.
Requirements: An undergraduate B.S. degree in physics, engineering or a related discipline, with a minimum cumulative GPA of 3.0. Three letters of recommendation. Graduate Record Examination (GRE) General Test is required. For international applicants, the Test of English as aForeign Language (TOEFL) is required. The application also includes a statement of purpose.
Description: The Graduate Certificate in Accelerator Science at Stony Brook University aims to provide post-baccalaureate students with a solid and specialized background in the physics and technology of particle accelerators. This is achieved through a set of core courses that focus on accelerator physics and technology, along with a number of specialized elective courses and, notably, a practical training experience in one of the accelerator facilities operated by the Center for Accelerator Science and Education (CASE) at Stony Brook.

EnglishScore: All international students must demonstrate English proficiency by submitting scores from at least one of the following exams: TOEFL, IELTS, Duolingo English Test.
Requirements:
Stony Brook University Graduate School online application
Application fee
One unofficial transcript from each university/college attended
GMAT or GRE score reports* (optional)
*GMAT/GRE scores are currently optional through the Fall 2025 semester.
Personal statement/essay
Resume or CV
Two letters of recommendation
TOEFL/IELTS score (for international students)
An interview may be required
Description: The Master of Science in Accountancy (MSA) is a 30-credit, one-year graduate program that prepares students for careers in public accounting, industry, non-profit, and government. Stony Brook's MSA is designed for students with an undergraduate degree in accounting, as well as for those without an accounting background. The program offers a flexible curriculum that enables students to customize their coursework to their specific career goals. Core courses provide students with a strong foundation in the fundamentals of accounting, while electives allow them to specialize in areas such as forensic accounting, taxation, and information systems. In addition to our rigorous coursework, the MSA program provides students with opportunities to gain practical experience through internships and other experiential learning opportunities. We also have a strong network of alumni who are eager to help our students succeed.
Accredidation: The College of Business is accredited by AACSB International-the Association to Advance Collegiate Schools of Business, a hallmark of excellence earned by less than five percent of business schools worldwide.

EnglishScore: International Students must demonstrate English proficiency. You must submit one of the following: TOEFL, IELTS, Duolingo.
Requirements: Admission is based on a holistic review of each applicant’s credentials, including prior academic performance, GMAT or GRE score, letters of recommendation, statement of purpose, and resume. Evidence of strong quantitative skills is important for admission. Prior work experience is valued, but not required.
Description: The 30-credit, one-year Master of Science in Accounting program prepares students for a career in public accounting, and is designed to meet the educational requirements for CPA licensure in New York State. An undergraduate degree in accounting is not required, as we offer prerequisite courses in business and accounting that may be taken at Stony Brook as a non-matriculated student. Students will gain the knowledge of accounting, auditing, taxation, and technology necessary to become a successful accounting professional. They also have the ability to pursue specialized accounting knowledge by taking elective courses in topics such as forensic accounting, finance, operations management, human resources and marketing. The curriculum is enhanced with a strong emphasis on technology and quantitative analysis with courses in Business Analytics, and advanced data analytics in accounting. The required internship helps students gain hands-on professional experience to advance their career. Our experienced faculty include esteemed researchers and practitioners who are experts in their fields, dedicated to preparing students to become leaders in accounting.
Accredidation: Stony Brook University's College of Business is accredited by AACSB International-the Association to Advance Collegiate Schools of Business. AACSB accreditation is the hallmark of excellence in business education and has been earned by less than five percent of the world's business programs.

EnglishScore: TOEFL or IELTS - international students only
Requirements: A bachelor's degree with a B or better cumulative grade point average. Official transcripts from all colleges and universities attended. A current resume. A personal statement/essay describing your reasons for pursuing the MBA degree and your short- and long-term career goals. Two letters of recommendation. It is strongly suggested that at least one letter be from a college professor. GMAT or GRE test score. (GMAT/GRE waivers are available for some highly qualified candidates.) International applicants who did not receive their primary undergraduate degree from a US institution will also need to submit one of the following: TOEFL, IELTS, or Duolingo English Test. An interview with an admissions representative.
Description: The MBA in Accounting degree program is designed for students with an undergraduate major in accounting from a U.S. college or university. This full-time program, which can be completed in two semesters, allows graduates to meet the 150-credit hour requirement needed to sit for the CPA exam in New York State and many other states. Students can also qualify for advanced standing in the program, which will reduce their cost and time to degree. Stony Brook’s MBA in Accounting will not only prepare you for the CPA exam, but also to assume a leadership role in an accounting firm or corporation. In addition to a strong accounting foundation, the program features courses in finance, management, operations, and marketing, all taught by our world-class faculty. Graduates of the program are well prepared for careers in public accounting, corporate accounting, not-for-profit accounting, and government.
Accredidation: Stony Brook University's College of Business is accredited by AACSB International-the Association to Advance Collegiate Schools of Business, the premier accrediting agency for business schools in the world.

EnglishScore: International applicants from non-English speaking countries are required to demonstrate proficiency in English by submitting scores from one of the following testing services: TOEFL, IELTS or Duolingo. The minimum required composite TOEFL iBT score is 80. The minimum required composite IELTS score is 6.5, with no subsection score below 6. The minimum required Duolingo score is 105.
Requirements: An undergraduate degree from an accredited U.S. institution or the international equivalent. Undergraduate degree in accounting not required. A minimum undergraduate GPA of 3.2 is normally required for admission. Exceptional cases may be considered on an individual basis. A current resume. A statement of purpose. Two letters of recommendation, submitted online. The GMAT is not required but scores may be submitted to strengthen a candidate’s application. If you elect to submit scores, there is no minimum required score. International students are required to take the TOEFL or IELTS exam unless they have received a degree from an institution in which the primary language of instruction is English. Minimum TOEFL score is 85; minimum IELTS score is 6.5 with no subsection below 6. Prerequisites must be completed with a grade of C or higher.
Concentration: Accounting Analytics, Accounting and Financial Management
Description: The Master of Science in Accounting (MSA) program is designed for students with an undergraduate degree in accounting who wish to focus on a particular area within the field or for students with an undergraduate degree in a discipline other than accounting who are interested in pursuing a career in accounting. This program offers students an opportunity to obtain a graduate degree from a top-ranked research university that is accredited by AACSB International, the premier accrediting agency for business schools. The program also positions students to become a Certified Public Accountant (CPA) in New York State. The MS in Accounting program has two tracks: Accounting Analytics and Accounting and Financial Management. The Accounting Analytics track is a STEM-designated program that provides students with the advanced data analytics skills they need for a successful career in the growing field of accounting analytics. The Accounting and Financial Management track provides students with technical accounting skills and prepares students for a career in public or corporate accounting.
Accredidation: The College of Business is accredited by AACSB International-the Association to Advance Collegiate Schools of Business, a prestigious body that recognizes the top business schools in the world.

Requirements: To be eligible to apply, students must: Be a current Stony Brook undergraduate student. Have a Stony Brook cumulative GPA of 3.2 or higher. Be on track to complete all of the requirements for your bachelor's degree by the time you start your first MBA class. Meet with an MBA advisor and an undergraduate advisor to ensure that you are on track to complete both degrees on time. Please complete our form to arrange an appointment. You must do this before you apply.
Concentration: Finance, Marketing, Health Care Management, Operations Management, Innovation, Accounting
Description: The Combined Bachelor's/MBA program is an opportunity for ambitious undergraduate students to earn a bachelor's degree in their chosen major and a Master of Business Administration degree with a concentration in Finance, Marketing, Health Care Management, Operations Management, Innovation, or Accounting. Students in the Combined Bachelor's/MBA program will be able to complete all the requirements for both degrees in five years, saving a full year of time and tuition. Students may select from any of our six MBA concentrations, or they may opt for the general MBA and choose from a variety of electives that best suit their academic and career goals. This allows them the flexibility to design their own course of study in fields such as general management, human resources, or business analytics. The Combined Bachelor's/MBA program will prepare students for leadership roles in a variety of careers.
Accredidation: The College of Business is accredited by AACSB International

EnglishScore: All students whose native language is not English are required to demonstrate English proficiency. Acceptable tests include TOEFL iBT, IELTS, PTE, or Duolingo. The requirement may be waived if the applicant has received a degree from a U.S. college or university or from a university in another country where English is the official language of instruction.
Requirements: To apply to the MBA and MS programs in the College of Business, you will need the following: Online application and application fee; Official transcripts from all colleges and universities attended (an unofficial copy can be uploaded for application review, but official transcripts are required upon admission); A current resume or curriculum vitae, detailing professional experience, including titles, dates, and responsibilities; An essay detailing your reasons for pursuing a graduate degree and your academic and professional goals; Three letters of recommendation. The GMAT/GRE requirement is currently being waived for all applicants to the MBA programs. International students may need to provide TOEFL or IELTS scores.

EnglishScore: International applicants whose native language is not English are required to take the TOEFL exam. A minimum score of 90 on the TOEFL iBT is required for admission. The Program in Public Health also accepts the IELTS exam. An overall score of 6.5 with no subsection below 6 is required.
Requirements: Applicants must be current Stony Brook University undergraduate students in good academic standing. GPA of 3.0 or better. Completed all SBU D.E.C. and major requirements to be eligible for graduation. Completed the following prerequisite courses with a grade of B or better: One semester of college-level mathematics (calculus preferred); One semester of social and behavioral sciences. Application Materials: An application to the Graduate School, A current résumé, A statement of purpose, Official transcripts from all colleges and universities attended, Three letters of recommendation. GRE test scores are not required for admission.
Description: The Accelerated Master of Public Health (MPH) degree at Stony Brook University is designed for highly-qualified, currently-enrolled undergraduate and graduate students, as well as recent graduates, who wish to complete both a bachelor’s degree and a MPH degree, or a clinical doctorate and an MPH degree, in less time than it would take to complete them sequentially. Through our flexible accelerated programs, students gain advanced skills and knowledge to address complex public health issues and become leaders in the field.
Accredidation: The Program in Public Health at Stony Brook University is accredited by the Council on Education for Public Health (CEPH). Our program was first accredited in 2011 and was reaccredited in 2018 for a seven-year term, extending to July 1, 2025.

ProgramName: Adult-Gerontology Acute Care Nurse Practitioner Certificate
EnglishScore: All international students must demonstrate English proficiency. The Graduate School's minimum score for the internet-based TOEFL (iBT) is 80. The Graduate School's minimum IELTS score is 6.5 overall with no subsection below 6. The Graduate School's minimum Duolingo English Test (DET) score is 105. The Graduate School's minimum PTE Academic score is 53. This requirement is waived for applicants who have earned a degree from an institution in the United States or another English-speaking country.
Requirements:
Master of Science degree in nursing with a major in one of the following advanced practice areas: nurse practitioner (adult, family, adult-gerontology primary care), clinical nurse specialist (adult health), or certified registered nurse anesthetist. For consideration for admission, applicants must have graduated from a program accredited by the Commission on Collegiate Nursing Education (CCNE) or the Accreditation Commission for Education in Nursing (ACEN).
Licensure as a Registered Nurse and Nurse Practitioner in New York State.
National certification as a nurse practitioner.
A minimum of one-year of full-time work experience (two years preferred) as a nurse practitioner in a hospital setting with the critically ill population.
Current ACLS certification.
Three letters of recommendation.
A personal statement.
A current resume.
Successful completion of an admission interview.
An undergraduate or graduate statistics course with a grade of C or better.
A cumulative GPA of 3.0.
All applicants to the School of Nursing are required to submit their application and supporting documents via NursingCAS (www.nursingcas.org).
Description: The Advanced Certificate in Adult-Gerontology Acute Care Nurse Practitioner (AGACNP) program prepares acute care nurse practitioners to provide advanced nursing care to adult and gerontological patients with complex, acute, and chronic health conditions. This is a 27-credit program that includes 600 clinical hours. Students are prepared to provide a full spectrum of care from disease prevention to critical care in order to stabilize the patient’s condition, prevent complications, restore health and/or provide palliative care. Students who complete the program are eligible to take the American Nurses Credentialing Center (ANCC) or the American Association of Critical-Care Nurses (AACN) certification exam.
Accredidation: The baccalaureate degree program in nursing, master's degree program in nursing, Doctor of Nursing Practice program and advanced certificate programs at Stony Brook University School of Nursing are accredited by the Commission on Collegiate Nursing Education (http://www.ccneaccreditation.org).

ProgramName: Adult-Gerontology Acute Care Nurse Practitioner MSN
Requirements: Unofficial transcripts from all colleges and universities attended. A bachelor's degree in nursing (BSN) from a program accredited by a national nursing accrediting agency. Minimum cumulative grade point average of 3.0 on a 4.0 scale. Current, unencumbered NYS RN license and registration. At least one year of recent acute care experience as a registered nurse. Current BLS certification. Three letters of recommendation. Personal Statement. Resume/CV. Official transcripts will be required if you are offered admission. Proof of English Proficiency for international students whose native language is not English.
Description: The Adult-Gerontology Acute Care Nurse Practitioner program prepares the graduate with the knowledge and skills to provide advanced nursing care to the adult and gerontology population with complex, acute, and chronic health conditions. Emphasis is on the provision of health care services to patients who are acutely and critically ill in a variety of settings such as intensive care units, emergency departments, specialty labs, and specialty clinics. Clinical experiences with expert preceptors are provided in a variety of settings. Graduates of the Master of Science in Nursing in the Adult-Gerontology Acute Care Nurse Practitioner program will be eligible to sit for national certification through the American Nurses Credentialing Center (ANCC) or the American Association of Critical Care Nurses (AACN).
Accredidation: The master's degree program in nursing... at Stony Brook University School of Nursing are accredited by the Commission on Collegiate Nursing Education, 655 K Street NW, Suite 750, Washington, DC 20001, 202-887-6791.

ProgramName: Adult-Gerontology Primary Care Nurse Practitioner Certificate
EnglishScore: All graduate applicants are required to demonstrate English proficiency. The Graduate School does not have a minimum required TOEFL or IELTS score for admission; however, most successful applicants score 90 or higher on the TOEFL iBT and 6.5 or higher on the IELTS. The minimum Duolingo English Test score for consideration is 115. The minimum PTE Academic score for consideration is 65.
Requirements:
Admission to the Adult-Gerontology Primary Care Nurse Practitioner program is based on the following:
1. Master of science degree in nursing from a program accredited by a national accreditation agency approved by the State Education Department (e.g., CCNE, ACEN).
2. Minimum cumulative grade point average of 3.0.
3. Current, unencumbered New York State license and registration as a Registered Professional Nurse.
4. National certification in a nurse practitioner specialty.
5. Completion of a graduate-level course in each of the following: advanced pathophysiology, advanced pharmacology and advanced physical assessment within the last five years.*
6. Personal interview with faculty.
7. One year of clinical experience as a nurse practitioner is preferred.
Description: The Adult-Gerontology Primary Care Nurse Practitioner program is designed to prepare students to provide primary health care to the adult-gerontology population across the wellness-illness continuum. The program emphasizes health promotion, health maintenance, disease prevention and the management of common acute and chronic illnesses. The program provides the foundational knowledge and clinical skills for graduates to be eligible for both New York State NP certification and national certification by the American Nurses Credentialing Center (ANCC) or the American Academy of Nurse Practitioners (AANP).
Accredidation: The baccalaureate degree program in nursing, master's degree program in nursing, Doctor of Nursing Practice program and post-graduate APRN certificate programs at Stony Brook University School of Nursing are accredited by the Commission on Collegiate Nursing Education (http://www.ccneaccreditation.org).
CostPerCredit: NYS Resident: $471 per credit; Non-Resident: $997 per credit

ProgramName: Adult-Gerontology Primary Care Nurse Practitioner MSN
EnglishScore: All students from non-English speaking countries are required to demonstrate English proficiency. Acceptable forms of proof include TOEFL iBT (minimum score 80), IELTS (minimum overall score 6.5), Duolingo (minimum score 105), ELS (completion of Level 112), or PTE Academic (minimum score 53).
Requirements:
Bachelor's degree in nursing (BS) from a nationally accredited program.
Cumulative grade point average of 3.0.
Undergraduate statistics course with a grade of C or better.
Undergraduate research course with a grade of C or better.
Unencumbered license to practice as a registered professional nurse in New York State.
A minimum of one-year full-time clinical experience as a registered nurse in a medical-surgical setting is required for Adult-Gerontology Primary Care NP, and Psychiatric Mental Health NP programs.
A curriculum vitae (CV) or résumé.
Three letters of recommendation. See specific instructions regarding recommendations on the application.
A personal statement describing the applicant's reasons for pursuing graduate study, professional goals, and why they want to attend Stony Brook University.
Non-native English speakers must take and submit TOEFL or IELTS scores.
Description: The Adult-Gerontology Primary Care Nurse Practitioner program is a 45-credit master's degree that prepares students to provide primary care to the entire spectrum of adults, from adolescents to older adults. The curriculum focuses on health promotion, health protection, disease prevention and the management of common acute and chronic illnesses. Graduates of this program are eligible to sit for the Adult-Gerontology Primary Care Nurse Practitioner certification examination offered by the American Nurses Credentialing Center (ANCC) or the American Academy of Nurse Practitioners (AANP). The program's part-time plan of study allows students to continue working while pursuing their degree.
Accredidation: The baccalaureate degree program in nursing, master's degree program in nursing, and Doctor of Nursing Practice program at Stony Brook University School of Nursing are accredited by the Commission on Collegiate Nursing Education (http://www.ccneaccreditation.org).

ProgramName: Advanced Dental Education Program General Practice Residency
EnglishScore: TOEFL iBT is required for international students with a minimum score of 90.
Requirements: All applicants must be graduates of a CODA-accredited dental school and must have successfully completed National Board Dental Examination, Part I and Part II (Part I is required at the time of application; Part II is required before entering the program). Applicants must apply through the Postdoctoral Application Support Service (PASS) of the American Dental Education Association (ADEA). All application materials must be submitted through PASS. Please do not send any application materials directly to the program. Applicants must be registered with the Postdoctoral Dental Matching Program. A personal interview is required for admission.
Department: Stony Brook School of Dental Medicine
Description: The General Practice Residency Program at Stony Brook University Hospital is an intense, hospital-based dental training program with a strong emphasis on medical and dental care for medically complex patients. The program provides the resident with advanced training in all aspects of general dentistry, with rotations in anesthesiology, general medicine and emergency medicine. The primary goal of our program is to produce well-rounded practitioners competent in all aspects of dentistry who have a robust understanding of the intricacies of a hospital-based dental practice.
Accredidation: The program is accredited by the Commission on Dental Accreditation (CODA) of the American Dental Association.

ProgramName: Advanced Dental Education Program in Dental Anesthesiology
EnglishScore: TOEFL scores for international applicants
Requirements: The program participates in the Postdoctoral Application Support Service (PASS) and Postdoctoral Dental Matching Program (the “MATCH”). Requirements for Application: Completed PASS Application; Personal Statement; Curriculum Vitae (CV); Official Dental School Transcripts; Official Undergraduate Transcripts; INBDE Score Report; ADAT Score Report (optional); Three Letters of Recommendation; 2x2 Photograph; Non-refundable application fee submitted directly to the program.
Description: The School of Dental Medicine offers a 36-month, CODA-accredited advanced education program leading to a Certificate of Completion in Dental Anesthesiology. It is one of only two hospital-based dental anesthesiology training programs in the United States administered by a Department of Anesthesiology within a medical school. The program provides a solid foundation in clinical anesthesia for dental specialists who will be able to provide advanced anesthesia and pain control services for ambulatory and hospitalized patients. The program provides comprehensive training in all phases of anesthesia care for dental, oral and maxillofacial surgery, and other surgical subspecialties. Residents gain extensive experience in the anesthetic management of patients of all ages, including pediatrics, and those with special needs or who are medically compromised. Upon completion of the program, residents will be eligible for board certification by the American Dental Board of Anesthesiology (ADBA). The Stony Brook University Hospital based program is a Level 1 Trauma Center, providing a broad range of anesthesia experiences to dental residents including rotations at the Ambulatory Surgical Center. Our residents are trained side-by-side with their physician anesthesiology counterparts. During the 36 months, the dental anesthesia residents complete the same rotations as the medical anesthesiology residents with an additional emphasis on ambulatory anesthesia. They learn skills such as outpatient anesthetic techniques, advanced airway management, pediatric anesthesia and anesthesia for patients with special needs or who are medically-compromised. The comprehensive didactic program complements the clinical experience. Graduates of this program will be well-prepared to become competent practitioners, educators, and researchers.
Accredidation: The Advanced Education Program in Dental Anesthesiology at Stony Brook School of Dental Medicine is accredited by the Commission on Dental Accreditation and has been granted the accreditation status of approval without reporting requirements.

ProgramName: Advanced Dental Education Program in Endodontics
EnglishScore: Completion of the Test of English as a Foreign Language (TOEFL) for all applicants from countries where English is not the official language. Minimum acceptable score is 90.
Requirements: Applicants must be a U.S. Citizen or permanent resident of the U.S. and have a DDS/DMD from a CODA accredited dental school. A passing score on the National Board Dental Examination (NBDE) is required. The application requires a 2x2 photo, CV, undergraduate transcripts, NBDE Part I and II scores, and ADAT Score to be uploaded. Three Professional Evaluation Forms (PEFs) are also required.
Description: The Advanced Education Program in Endodontics at Stony Brook University School of Dental Medicine is a 24-month program leading to a Certificate in Endodontics. The program is fully accredited by the American Dental Association Commission on Dental Accreditation. The program is designed to educate qualified dentists to become specialists in endodontics. It will provide the postdoctoral student with a strong background in the biological sciences and their application to clinical endodontics. The program emphasizes the scientific basis for the clinical practice of endodontics. This will be achieved through a comprehensive series of scheduled lectures, seminars, and laboratory courses designed to complement the student's clinical experience. The postdoctoral student will be assigned a wide variety of clinical cases, both surgical and non-surgical. The student is encouraged to participate in original research, which should be of publishable quality and is a requirement for graduation. The School of Dental Medicine provides all endodontic instrumentation, including several brands of rotary instrumentation, ultrasonics, and thermoplastic obturation systems. State of the art operating microscopes are provided for each resident. All radiography is digital using phosphor plates and direct sensors. CBCT imaging is readily available.
Accredidation: The program is fully accredited by the American Dental Association Commission on Dental Accreditation.

ProgramName: Advanced Dental Education Program in Oral and Maxillofacial Radiology
EnglishScore: For applicants for whom English is not their native language, a score from the Test of English as a Foreign Language (TOEFL) is also required.
Requirements:
1. D.D.S., D.M.D. or equivalent degree.
2. Successful completion of Parts I and II of the National Dental Board Examination (for graduates of ADA-accredited schools).
3. Proficiency in the English language. Applicants whose native language is not English must take the TOEFL examination. A minimum score of 550 (paper based), 213 (computer based) or 85 (Internet based) is required for admission.
4. Participation in the Postdoctoral Dental Matching Program (MATCH) and the Postdoctoral Application Support Service (PASS). All application materials must be submitted through PASS. For information and an application, contact PASS directly.
5. Three letters of recommendation.
6. Personal interview.
Description: The School of Dental Medicine offers an advanced education certificate program in oral and maxillofacial radiology, which is designed to provide training in the interpretation of conventional and advanced images, such as computed tomography (CT), cone beam computed tomography (CBCT) and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). The goal of the residency program is to prepare residents to practice as specialists in oral and maxillofacial radiology. The educational philosophy is to consider the residents as colleagues and provide them with a broad background in the field of oral and maxillofacial radiology to assure a high level of clinical competency and to provide them with the tools and techniques of research in the field. The program provides the educational experience to allow the resident to meet the eligibility requirements for examination for certification by the American Board of Oral and Maxillofacial Radiology. The program is designed for two years of study and clinical experience, culminating in a certificate in oral and maxillofacial radiology. During this time, residents will gain experience and advanced knowledge in radiation physics, radiation biology, radiation safety, radiographic techniques, interpretation of conventional and advanced imaging modalities, and clinical correlation of disease. At the end of the program, the resident is expected to be proficient in the interpretation of conventional and advanced imaging modalities utilized in the diagnosis and management of diseases affecting the oral and maxillofacial region in the hospital and private practice settings.
Accredidation: The advanced education program in Oral and Maxillofacial Radiology is accredited by the Commission on Dental Accreditation and has been granted the accreditation status of initial accreditation.

ProgramName: Advanced Dental Education Program in Orthodontics and Dentofacial Orthopedics
EnglishScore: Required for all applicants who have not graduated from a CODA-accredited dental school. Minimum score of 100 iBT is required.
Requirements: Applicants apply through the Postdoctoral Application Support Service (PASS) of the American Dental Education Association (ADEA). All application materials, including the following, must be submitted through PASS: Official transcripts from all undergraduate and dental schools attended; National Board Scores (Part I and Part II when available); And three letters of recommendation (one must be from the dean of the applicant's dental school).
Description: The postgraduate program in Orthodontics and Dentofacial Orthopedics at Stony Brook University School of Dental Medicine is a thirty-six month course of study, which provides a Certificate of Proficiency in Orthodontics and Dentofacial Orthopedics and fulfills the educational requirements for eligibility for the American Board of Orthodontics Examination. In addition, an optional Master of Science degree in Oral Biology and Pathology is offered. The program, which accepts four residents each year, is designed to provide a comprehensive and balanced didactic and clinical orthodontic education. Our main objective is to develop outstanding, clinically proficient practitioners who will be able to successfully manage the full range of orthodontic problems. The program is fully accredited by the American Dental Association’s Commission on Dental Accreditation. Upon completion, graduates are well prepared for the American Board of Orthodontics clinical examination.
Accredidation: The program is fully accredited by the American Dental Association’s Commission on Dental Accreditation.

ProgramName: Advanced Dental Education Program in Pediatric Dentistry
EnglishScore: For applicants from non-accredited dental schools, in addition to the NBDE/INBDE requirement above, the successful completion of the Test of English as a Foreign Language (TOEFL) is required.
Requirements: Applications for the Stony Brook University Advanced Education Program in Pediatric Dentistry are accepted through the American Dental Education Association Postdoctoral Application Support Service (ADEA PASS). A complete PASS application includes: Personal Statement, Curriculum Vitae (CV), 2"x2" photo, Official dental school transcripts, Official undergraduate transcripts, Official National Board Dental Examination Scores, Parts I and II, Three letters of recommendation (one must be from the Dean of your dental school), Advanced Dental Admission Test (ADAT) scores are required. For foreign-trained applicants, TOEFL is required.
Description: The Advanced Education Program in Pediatric Dentistry is a 24-month university and hospital-based program. The program is designed to offer a balanced clinical and didactic curriculum in advanced infant, child and adolescent dentistry. The program provides the resident with the necessary training to become a competent pediatric dental specialist. Emphasis is placed on hospital dentistry, special needs patient care, pediatric medicine, growth and development, and interceptive orthodontics. Upon successful completion of all requirements, the resident receives a Certificate in Pediatric Dentistry. Graduates are educationally qualified for the American Board of Pediatric Dentistry examination. Residents may concurrently enroll in a Master of Science in Oral Biology and Pathology program offered by the Graduate School of Stony Brook University. The goal of this optional track is to provide an in-depth experience in the research process.
Accredidation: The Advanced Education Program in Pediatric Dentistry is accredited by the Commission on Dental Accreditation and has been granted the accreditation status of “approval without reporting requirements”.

ProgramName: Advanced Dental Education Program in Periodontics
EnglishScore: Program requires TOEFL for all foreign-trained applicants. Score of 90 on IBT recommended.
Requirements: Applicants must have graduated from a CODA-accredited dental school. Required tests include the Dental Admission Test (DAT) and the National Board Dental Examination (NBDE), which must be passed prior to matriculation. The Advanced Dental Admission Test (ADAT) is accepted but not required. Applicants from non-CODA accredited dental schools must submit official TOEFL scores, with a minimum of 550 for the paper-based test and 90 for the internet-based test. Required documents include three letters of recommendation (one from the Dean of the dental school), a Curriculum Vitae/Resume, a Personal Statement, official transcripts from all undergraduate and dental schools attended, and a 2”x 2” photograph. A supplemental application fee of $100 must be sent directly to the program.
Description:
The Advanced Education Program in Periodontics at Stony Brook University School of Dental Medicine is a thirty-six (36) month program designed to provide an outstanding educational experience and to satisfy the formal training requirements of the American Board of Periodontology. The program, which is based at the School of Dental Medicine, enrolls three residents each year. At the completion of the program, the resident is awarded a Certificate in Periodontics. The program is fully accredited by the Commission on Dental Accreditation of the American Dental Association.

The primary objective of the Advanced Education Program in Periodontics is to graduate competent periodontists. This competency is founded in a strong understanding of the biological basis of clinical periodontics, an appreciation of the importance of an evidence-based approach to patient care, and sound clinical judgment and skill. The curriculum provides for a broad-based education in periodontology including didactic and clinical components in the areas of diagnosis and treatment planning for patients with a wide variety of periodontal diseases, surgical and non-surgical periodontal therapy, oral medicine, pain and anxiety control, oral implantology, and principles of practice management. Additionally, a Master's degree (M.S. in Oral Biology and Pathology) is available as an option. The Master's program must be completed within the 36-month periodontics residency.
Accredidation: The program is fully accredited by the Commission on Dental Accreditation of the American Dental Association.

ProgramName: Advanced Dental Education Program in Prosthodontics
EnglishScore: TOEFL is required for all applicants from a country where English is not the official language. The code for the TOEFL is 2548.
Requirements: Applicants for the Advanced Education Program in Prosthodontics (certificate only) must apply through the American Dental Education Association's Postdoctoral Application Support Service (PASS) and participate in the Postdoctoral Dental Matching Program (the "Match"). In addition to the requirements of the Graduate School, the following are required for admission into the certificate program: A D.D.S. or D.M.D. degree from a CODA-accredited dental school, or the equivalent. Successful completion of Part I and Part II of the National Dental Board Examination. Applicants for whom English is not their native language must take the Test of English as a Foreign Language (TOEFL). The Educational Testing Service code for the Graduate School is 2548. A minimum score of 550 (written), 213 (computer-based), or 85 (internet-based) is required for admission. A personal interview is required. Three letters of recommendation. At least two of the letters should be from prosthodontists. One of the letters should be from the Dean of the applicant's dental school. All advanced education students must have a New York State restricted residency permit or a New York State dental license prior to enrollment.
Description: The Advanced Education Program in Prosthodontics at Stony Brook University School of Dental Medicine is a three-year program which combines didactic and clinical instruction leading to a Certificate in Prosthodontics. The program offers residents extensive experience in all aspects of prosthodontics, including complete dentures, removable partial dentures, fixed prosthodontics, esthetics, and implant dentistry. Strong emphasis is placed on diagnosis, treatment planning and execution of all facets of prosthodontic care. Residents are also expected to complete a research project and a manuscript suitable for publication. Residents may also elect to complete the requirements for a Master of Science in Oral Biology and Pathology at the same time.
Accredidation: The Advanced Education Program in Prosthodontics is fully accredited by the American Dental Association's Commission on Dental Accreditation.
ScholarshipType: Academic achievement, commitment to community dentistry, demonstrated financial need, leadership

ProgramName: Advanced Graduate Certificate in data and computational science
EnglishScore: For applicants whose native language is not English, proficiency is demonstrated by one of the following: a TOEFL iBT composite score of 80 for master’s and certificate programs, an IELTS overall score of 6.5, with no subsection score below 6.0, a Duolingo minimum score of 105 for master’s and certificate programs, or a PTE Academic minimum score of 53 for master's and certificate programs.
Requirements: All applicants must be current Stony Brook graduate students or have a minimum of a Bachelor's degree from an accredited institution. Applicants must submit an application through the Stony Brook Graduate School, which includes a personal statement, transcripts from all undergraduate and graduate institutions, and three letters of recommendation. GRE scores are not required.
Description: The AGC in Data and Computational Science is intended for students who have completed an undergraduate degree and wish to acquire specialized knowledge in data and computational science. The certificate will prepare students for careers in data science and analytics as well as for further graduate study. Students will choose one of two tracks: either an emphasis in computational and statistical methods for big data, or an emphasis in a domain-specific area of their choosing. Students will be required to meet with the graduate program director to formulate their plan of study upon entering the certificate program. For more information, contact the graduate program director for the DCS-AGC.
CostPerCredit: $471 for NYS residents; $1,008 for out-of-state residents

EnglishScore: All students from non-English speaking countries must demonstrate proficiency in English. The Graduate School accepts the following exams to satisfy this requirement: TOEFL, IELTS, Duolingo English Test, and PTE Academic.
Requirements:
To apply for the MA in Mass Communication, you will need to submit the following materials through the Graduate School's online application system:

A completed application form and fee.
Transcripts from all undergraduate and graduate institutions attended.
Three letters of recommendation from faculty or professionals who can speak to your academic and professional potential.
A 1-2 page statement of purpose outlining your reasons for pursuing a graduate degree in mass communication, your career goals, and your specific interests in our program.
A writing sample, such as a research paper, a professional report, or a portfolio of creative work.
A resume outlining your relevant experience.
GRE scores are optional for all applicants.
For international students, TOEFL or IELTS scores are required unless you have a degree from an institution in an English-speaking country. Please see the Graduate School's website for more information on English proficiency requirements.
Description: The Master of Arts in Advertising is a new, innovative program in the School of Communication and Journalism that will help you gain the knowledge and skills necessary to become a leader in the advertising industry. In this program, you will learn to manage advertising and marketing campaigns, develop and implement communication strategies and tactics, and create compelling content for a variety of audiences and platforms. The program is designed to be completed in one calendar year (fall, spring, summer), and classes are held in the evenings to accommodate working professionals. You will learn from seasoned advertising and marketing professionals and gain hands-on experience through client-based projects, case studies, and a capstone portfolio project. The MA in Advertising is ideal for students who are just starting their careers, as well as those who are already in the field and want to move into leadership roles. You will graduate from this program with a strong portfolio of work that will help you land a job in the fast-paced and exciting world of advertising.

Requirements: The Certificate in Africana Studies is open to any graduate student in good standing in a Master’s or Doctoral degree-granting program at Stony Brook. Students interested in pursuing the Certificate should consult with the Director of the Department or a designated member of the Graduate Committee. Students may apply for the Certificate program after they have been admitted to a graduate degree-granting program at Stony Brook. Students must complete a Certificate application form to be signed by their Graduate Program Director and the Director of the Africana Studies Department. Applicants for the Certificate program should submit an application to the Director of the Department.
Description: The Advanced Graduate Certificate in Africana Studies allows Stony Brook graduate students to develop expertise in the field of Africana Studies and to receive formal recognition for their training and research on campus. Students complete five courses (15 credits) on topics related to Africana Studies, which are taught by faculty affiliates from across the College of Arts and Sciences, the School of Social Welfare, the School of Journalism, and the School of Medicine. Our program includes a diverse intellectual community, including regular talks, workshops, and roundtables with leading scholars in the field of Africana Studies. The Advanced Graduate Certificate in Africana Studies also provides graduate students with crucial professionalization for today's competitive job market, including within and beyond the academy.

EnglishScore: All graduate applicants are required to demonstrate English proficiency. The following are the minimum scores required for admission to the Graduate School: TOEFL iBT: overall score of 80. IELTS: overall score of 6.5 with no subsection below 6. PTE Academic: overall score of 53. Duolingo English Test: overall score of 105.
Requirements: To be considered for admission to the MA program in Africana Studies, an applicant must: Have earned a BA degree from an accredited institution with a major in Africana Studies or related field in the Humanities or Social Sciences; Have earned a minimum cumulative GPA of 3.0; Submit a completed application to the Graduate School, including: Statement of purpose; Three letters of recommendation; A writing sample; Transcripts from all undergraduate and graduate institutions attended; An application fee. The GRE is not required for admission.
Description: The Department of Africana Studies at Stony Brook University offers a Master of Arts degree that prepares students for interdisciplinary scholarship in the field of Africana Studies and for professional careers that require advanced knowledge of the histories, cultures, and political economies of people of African descent in the United States, the Caribbean, Latin America, Africa, and the wider African Diaspora. The curriculum is interdisciplinary, drawing on a wide range of theoretical and methodological approaches from the humanities and social sciences. The program emphasizes a diasporic, comparative, and transnational approach to the study of the African world. Students will engage with a variety of research methods and theoretical perspectives, including postcolonial theory, critical race theory, feminism and womanism, cultural studies, and political economy. The M.A. program in Africana Studies also equips students with the research and writing skills necessary to succeed in a variety of Ph.D. programs and professional fields.
ScholarshipType: Partial tuition scholarships, graduate assistantships, fellowships

ProgramName: Aging Populations and Healthcare Administration, Advanced Certificate
EnglishScore: All international graduate applicants are required to demonstrate English proficiency by submitting official scores from at least one of the following exams: TOEFL, IELTS, PTE Academic, and Duolingo.
Requirements: Applicants must have earned a Master’s degree in a health or human services related field, from an accredited institution. Applicants must complete the Stony Brook University Graduate School online application, which includes: Official transcripts from all colleges and universities attended. Resume. Personal statement. Three letters of recommendation. TOEFL scores for international applicants. Application Fee. All applications are reviewed by the HA Program Admissions Committee. Applications are accepted for Fall admissions only.
Description: This 18-credit advanced certificate is intended to meet the needs of those individuals, in a variety of fields, who work with the aged. The program is specifically designed to provide specialized knowledge about the aging process which will supplement the generalist skills of administrators, planners, and clinicians who are, or will be, working with the elderly. The purpose of the advanced certificate program is to provide students with the ability to: analyze the economic, political, and social issues associated with aging populations; understand the physiological and psychological aspects of aging; evaluate the ethical and legal issues in healthcare; evaluate marketing and strategic planning for serving aging populations; understand the structure, financing, and management of the long-term continuum of care. The program is offered in an online format.

EnglishScore: All international students must demonstrate English proficiency. Stony Brook accepts the TOEFL iBT, the IELTS, the PTE Academic, and the Duolingo English Test.
Requirements:
Candidates for admission must have a baccalaureate degree from an accredited college or university. An undergraduate major in one of the biological sciences is recommended. Students whose undergraduate major is in another area may be considered for admission, but may be required to correct deficiencies in their background by taking appropriate undergraduate courses without graduate credit. A strong background in the physical sciences also is recommended.

Specific course prerequisites are one year of general biology, one year of general chemistry, and one year of organic chemistry. One year of physics is desirable. The average undergraduate GPA should be a minimum of 3.0.

The applicant must submit a personal statement, three letters of recommendation from faculty members who are familiar with the applicant’s academic abilities, and a current curriculum vitae. Test scores from the GRE or MCAT are not required, but are highly recommended. A TOEFL or IELTS score is required for all applicants from countries in which English is not the official language.
Description: The graduate program in Anatomical Sciences at Stony Brook University is a two-year program designed to train students for careers teaching the anatomical disciplines in medical and allied health science schools or for careers in which a thorough knowledge of anatomy is a prime requisite. The program provides the students with a comprehensive background in the major areas of the anatomical sciences, with special emphasis on the gross anatomy, microscopic anatomy, neuroanatomy and development of the human body. As an integral component of the program, students gain experience in the teaching of the anatomical sciences by participating as teaching assistants in the anatomy courses for medical, dental, and allied health science students. This aspect of the program provides the students with supervised practical experience and thus the opportunity to teach in a professional school environment.
ScholarshipType: Teaching Assistantships, Research Assistantships, Graduate Assistantships, Fellowships

EnglishScore: All graduate applicants are required to demonstrate English proficiency. The primary way to demonstrate this is by submitting scores from an approved English proficiency exam. The most commonly submitted exams are the TOEFL and IELTS. Stony Brook University also accepts Duolingo and Pearson PTE Academic.
Requirements: Applicants should have a B.S. or B.A. degree in one of the biological or chemical sciences and should have a minimum GPA of 3.0. Required undergraduate courses include one year of biology, general chemistry, organic chemistry, and physics. A course in biochemistry is strongly recommended. In addition to transcripts, a personal statement of career goals, and three letters of recommendation, GRE scores (verbal, quantitative, and analytical writing) are required. Students whose native language is not English are required to take the TOEFL exam (minimum acceptable score is 550 for the paper-based test or 80 for the iBT). Applications are reviewed by the Anatomical Sciences Graduate Program Admissions Committee. Applications must be received by January 15.
Concentration: Vertebrate Paleontology and Evolution, Functional Anatomy and Biomechanics, Human Evolutionary Biology, Developmental and Cellular Biology
Description: The Anatomical Sciences graduate program is designed for students interested in the evolutionary basis of vertebrate, especially mammalian and primate, structure. Our faculty are clustered in four major research areas in which students can specialize: Vertebrate Paleontology and Evolution, Functional Anatomy and Biomechanics, Human Evolutionary Biology, and Developmental and Cellular Biology. The program fosters an understanding of the relationship between organismal structure and function from the molecular to the gross anatomical levels. Students learn the importance of studying anatomy within an evolutionary and functional context. Our program aims to give students a broad exposure to the anatomical sciences while fostering the specialization necessary for an independent research career.

EnglishScore: All graduate applicants from a country where the native language is not English are required to take one of the following exams: Test of English as a Foreign Language (TOEFL) iBT, International English Language Testing System (IELTS), Duolingo English Test, or Pearson Test of English (PTE Academic). The Graduate School's minimum required scores are: TOEFL iBT 80, IELTS 6.5 (with no subsection score below 6), Duolingo 105, or PTE Academic 53.
Requirements: Applicants for admission to the doctoral program in Anthropological Sciences must have a bachelor’s degree from an accredited university. We admit students who intend to pursue a doctorate in one of two major subfields of anthropology: either Archaeology or Evolutionary Anthropology. Students accepted into the doctoral program will normally have had some undergraduate training in anthropology, and should have a good background in a related field such as biology, geology, psychology or anatomy. Applicants with a master’s degree in anthropology or a related field are also welcome to apply. All applicants must submit a completed application form, 3 letters of recommendation, a statement of purpose, transcripts of all college-level work, a résumé or C.V., and a writing sample. The GRE requirement is suspended for this program at this time.
Description: The doctoral program in Anthropological Sciences (DPA) is an interdepartmental graduate program administered by the Department of Anthropology. The focus of the program is on the application of the natural sciences to the solution of anthropological problems, both past and present. Students admitted to the DPA may specialize in either (1) evolutionary anthropology, which focuses on the evolutionary history and biocultural adaptations of humans and other primates, or (2) archaeology, which addresses anthropological problems through the study of the material remains of past human behavior. The DPA program emphasizes research design and the development of analytical skills that allow students to carry out original, problem-oriented research.
ScholarshipAmount: Full tuition scholarship plus a stipend

EnglishScore: All international students must demonstrate English proficiency. The Graduate School accepts the TOEFL iBT, IELTS, Duolingo English Test, and PTE Academic tests. A minimum score of 80 on the TOEFL iBT is required for admission to all graduate programs. A minimum overall IELTS score of 6.5, with no subsection below 6, is required. A minimum Duolingo score of 105 is required. A minimum PTE Academic score of 53 is required.
Requirements: Stony Brook Graduate School online application; application fee; transcripts and one official copy of all undergraduate and graduate transcripts; three letters of recommendation; GRE General Test (school code: 2548). Test scores are not required for students applying to enroll in Fall 2024; statement of purpose; curriculum vitae; writing sample; and TOEFL or IELTS is required for applicants whose native language is not English.
Description: The graduate program in anthropology provides training in the three major subdisciplines of the field: archaeology, biological anthropology, and sociocultural anthropology. The faculty consists of 19 full-time members. These faculty, often jointly with faculty in other departments such as Anatomical Sciences, Art, Ecology and Evolution, Geosciences, and History, offer a wide variety of specialized training and research opportunities. In addition to the regular course work, students benefit from a large number of research projects directed by the faculty in many parts of the world, including North, Central and South America; Africa; and Asia. A number of research laboratories and other facilities are available within the department and elsewhere on campus, including the new Turkana Basin Institute. The department also has close ties with several area museums. The Department of Anthropology does not offer a terminal M.A. degree. The M.A. is awarded as a qualifying degree en route to the Ph.D.

ProgramName: Concentration in Applied Biological Anthropology (Anthropology MA)
EnglishScore: Applicants who are non-native English speakers are required to take an English proficiency exam. Stony Brook University accepts the following tests: TOEFL iBT, IELTS, Duolingo English Test, and PTE Academic. The minimum score for TOEFL iBT is 80, for IELTS is 6.5 overall band with no band below 6, for Duolingo is 105, and for PTE Academic is 53.
Requirements: Required Application Materials include the Graduate School Application and application fee, transcripts from all previous institutions attended, three letters of recommendation, and a personal statement. The GRE General Test is no longer required for admission to the MA program. For international students, TOEFL/IELTS scores are required.
Description: Our department has established a new Master of Arts in Anthropology degree with a concentration in Applied Biological Anthropology. This program builds on our strengths in biological anthropology and will emphasize the practical and analytical skills necessary for careers in government, non-profits, and the private sector, as well as for further study in academic PhD programs. Coursework and training will be offered in a variety of topical areas within applied biological anthropology, and include: Functional Anatomy and Biomechanics; Human Osteology; Forensic Anthropology; Medical Anthropology; Human-Environment Interactions; Anthropological Genetics; and Geometric Morphometrics. The Masters of Arts in Anthropology with a Concentration in Applied Biological Anthropology is a two-year, 30-credit degree designed for students with a bachelor’s degree (in any field) who are interested in pursuing advanced training in biological anthropology, but who do not intend to pursue a PhD, or wish to strengthen their record before applying for a PhD. This program offers advanced coursework and training in a variety of topical areas within biological anthropology, and places special emphasis on the practical and analytical skills necessary for careers in government, non-profits, and the private sector, as well as for further study in academic PhD programs. Stony Brook University is known for its strength in biological anthropology, and this program provides a unique opportunity for students to acquire a Master’s degree from a world-renowned department, regardless of their undergraduate background. Students may enroll on either a full-time or a part-time basis. Full-time students may complete the degree in as few as three semesters.

EnglishScore: For international students who are required to prove proficiency, the university accepts several tests. Minimum scores for master's-level programs are: TOEFL iBT - 80, IELTS - 6.5 overall, Duolingo - 105, or PTE Academic - 53.
Requirements: A bachelor’s degree in geology or a closely-related field, with a GPA > 3.0. Preference will be given to students with an MS degree in geology or a closely related field or to those with work experience in the petroleum industry.
Description: The goal of the ACG certificate program is to provide geoscientists a world class training in carbonate geology, with an emphasis on carbonate sedimentology and stratigraphy, diagenesis, petrophysics and reservoir characterization. It can be taken as a stand-alone certificate to bolster your skill set, or in conjunction with our M.S. or Ph.D. programs in geosciences. The certificate program requires 18 credits of coursework, including a series of core courses and a range of optional advanced courses. The certificate program has been designed to meet the needs of those seeking advanced training in carbonate sedimentology/stratigraphy for careers in academia, government, and industry.

EnglishScore: All international students must demonstrate English proficiency by submitting scores from one of the following exams: TOEFL iBT (minimum 80), IELTS (minimum 6.5 overall band with no band below 6.0), Duolingo English Test (minimum 105), or PTE Academic (minimum 53).
Requirements:
1. A bachelor's degree in any field, with a cumulative grade point average of 3.0 or higher.
2. One year of college-level mathematics or statistics with a grade of C or better.
3. Three letters of recommendation.
4. Personal Statement.
5. For international students, TOEFL or IELTS is required. Please see http://grad.stonybrook.edu/admissions/international/english_proficiency.php.
6. GRE is required, MCATs or GMATs will be accepted in lieu of GREs. The GRE requirement can be waived based on prior education and experience. Please contact the program director for more information.
A completed on-line application that includes all of the above must be received by the program's stated application deadline.
Description: The Master of Science (M.S.) degree program in Applied Health Informatics (AHI) is offered through the Department of Biomedical Informatics (BMI) in the Stony Brook University School of Medicine. Our program is uniquely situated within an academic medical center and students will be exposed to both the research driven academic world as well as the applied operational world of the Stony Brook Medicine. The goal of the program is to train the next generation of informaticians who will be have the skills, knowledge and abilities to work as professional informaticians or to go on to PhD programs in informatics. The curriculum provides a strong technical and computer science foundation, a comprehensive understanding of the health and clinical environment, and familiarity with social and organizational issues in healthcare. These three pillars: computer science, the clinical environment, and social science/organizational issues are the essential components for well-trained informaticians. The AHI program trains future informaticians through our innovative curriculum, and our strong partnerships with the Stony Brook Medicine, Long Island Health Information Exchange, area hospitals, industry and public health agencies in the greater NY area. Students gain real-world experience through our practicum/capstone course which provides an opportunity to apply informatics principles to an active project in a health care setting. Our students will develop specialized expertise in health informatics and be prepared for positions in the health care industry or for advanced study in the field.

EnglishScore: All applicants whose native language is not English must take an English proficiency test. The following tests are accepted with minimum scores: TOEFL iBT (85), IELTS (6.5 overall band, with no band below 6.0), Duolingo English Test (115), or PTE Academic (61). Applicants who have completed a degree in the U.S. or other English-speaking country may request a waiver.
Requirements:
A master's degree from an accredited institution. Applicants may be enrolled in a master's degree program at the time of their application, but their degree must be conferred before starting the doctoral program.
A minimum of a 3.0 cumulative grade point average (GPA) on a 4.0 scale in all graduate coursework.
Three or more years of professional experience in education and/or a learning-related field.
GRE scores are not required.
Description: The EdD in Applied Learning Sciences (ALS) is a 48-credit, fully online program designed to advance the expertise of learning professionals in a variety of industries, including K-12 and higher education, corporate, non-profit, government, and military settings. The program will equip students with advanced knowledge and skills in learning sciences to design, implement, and evaluate technology-mediated learning environments. Core coursework explores learning theory and design, human cognition, program evaluation, research methods and data analytics, as well as emerging educational technologies. This applied doctoral program is practice-based and leads to a culminating doctoral project. In keeping with the practitioner-scholar focus, students will learn to identify real-world problems of practice and apply research-based approaches and solutions that will have a direct impact on learning and teaching.

EnglishScore: All international students must demonstrate English proficiency. The following are the acceptable exams and minimum scores required for admission to the Graduate School: TOEFL iBT: 80; IELTS: 6.5 overall band score with no band score below 6; Duolingo English Test: 105; PTE Academic: 53. These are automatically waived for students with a degree from a US institution.
Requirements: In addition to the Graduate School’s general admission requirements, applicants are expected to have a strong background in undergraduate mathematics, including courses in multivariate calculus, linear algebra and differential equations. Some familiarity with computers is expected and a course in probability and statistics is desirable. A minimum undergraduate grade point average of 3.00 on a 4.00 scale is required for admission. All applicants must submit a Graduate School application, including a personal statement, letters of recommendation, and transcripts of all previous college work.
Department: College of Engineering and Applied Sciences
Description: The Department of Applied Mathematics and Statistics offers a program of graduate study leading to the Master of Science degree. This program is designed for students who seek to obtain a higher level of knowledge in their chosen field of specialization. Four tracks are offered for the M.S. degree. Two of them are in operations research and statistics, which have long been the two principal areas of applied mathematics. The other two are in quantitative finance, an area of ever increasing importance and interest, and in computational applied mathematics, which emphasizes methods relevant to solving major scientific and engineering problems. A brief description of these areas of specialization is below. Each track gives students a great deal of flexibility in designing a course of study that will meet their own particular educational objectives.

Requirements:
In addition to the general admission requirements of the Graduate School, the following are required for admission to the Ph.D. program in Applied Mathematics and Statistics:
1. A bachelor’s degree in mathematics, a quantitative science, or an engineering discipline from an accredited college or university. The undergraduate program must have included at least three semesters of calculus (through multivariable integration), a course in linear algebra, and a course in differential equations. At least one calculus-based probability and statistics course is desirable, but not required.
2. A minimum cumulative grade point average of 3.0.
3. The Graduate Record Examination (GRE) General Test is not required, but applicants may submit scores if they have taken the test.
4. Three letters of recommendation.
5. International students are required to take the Test of English as a Foreign Language (TOEFL). A minimum score of 85 on the iBT is required for admission. See the Graduate School's requirements for more information.
Department: College of Engineering and Applied Sciences
Description: The Ph.D. program in Applied Mathematics and Statistics is designed to train students to become leading researchers and educators in the various fields of applied mathematics and statistics. It is an individualized program of study for highly qualified students. Its principal components are a broad training in applied mathematics and an in-depth specialization in one of the major research areas of the department: computational applied mathematics, computational biology, operations research, or statistics.

EnglishScore: All students whose native language is not English must demonstrate English proficiency. The Graduate School accepts the following exams to satisfy this requirement: TOEFL, IELTS, and Duolingo. The Graduate School's minimum score for the TOEFL iBT is 80. The Graduate School's minimum score for the IELTS (overall score) is 6.5. The Graduate School's minimum score for the Duolingo is 105.
Requirements: Prerequisites: Bachelor's degree from an accredited university. One year of undergraduate Anatomy & Physiology with laboratory. Minimum undergraduate GPA of 3.0. Application Requirements: An online application to the Graduate School, including the application fee. A Personal Statement detailing your interest in the field of Applied Physiology. Three letters of recommendation from individuals familiar with your academic background and potential for success in graduate school. Official transcripts from each college or university attended. GRE scores are no longer required. A non-refundable application fee. International Applicants: English Proficiency: Please refer to the Graduate School requirements.
Description: The Applied Physiology, M.S.Ed. is a 30-credit master's degree program that develops professionals who are both excellent healthcare providers and exemplary educators in the clinical setting. The graduate program provides a strong foundation in physiology and hands-on, research and educational experiences that prepare students to integrate evidence-based practice into their future careers. Students within the program can choose a general focus or a more specialized area of study, such as human performance, exercise physiology, pathophysiology, or health and wellness. This program is ideal for students who aspire to careers in professional healthcare fields like medicine, dentistry, physical therapy, occupational therapy, and physician assistant, as well as students with interests in athletic training, sports medicine, exercise physiology, or teaching in a healthcare setting.

EnglishScore: All graduate applicants whose native language is not English must demonstrate English proficiency. To satisfy this requirement, applicants may submit scores from the Test of English as a Foreign Language (TOEFL) or the International English Language Testing System (IELTS-Academic), Duolingo English Test (DET), or PTE-Academic. A minimum TOEFL iBT score of 80 is required for admission to a master’s program. A minimum overall score of 6.5 with no subsection below 6 on the IELTS is required. A minimum Duolingo English Test score of 105 is required. A minimum PTE-Academic score of 53 is required.
Requirements: In addition to the Graduate School’s general requirements, applicants must possess: Minimum undergraduate GPA of 3.0. At least one semester of college level physics, college level chemistry, and calculus. Transcripts of all previous college and university work (Undergraduate & Graduate). A personal statement clearly stating career goals and reasons for interest in the program. Three letters of recommendation. Graduate Record Examination (GRE) scores are not required. For International Students, a TOEFL or IELTS score is required. A Resume or C.V. Completed online application. Application Fee.
Department: School of Marine and Atmospheric Sciences
Description: The Master of Professional Studies (MPS) in Applied Remote Sensing is an interdisciplinary graduate program that blends foundational knowledge with hands-on technical training to meet the growing need for expertise in the processing, analysis, and application of remotely sensed data for a wide range of academic, industrial, and government career tracks. Remote sensing refers to the collection and interpretation of information about an object or area from a distance, typically by sensors on aircraft and satellites. Students will explore diverse topics in remote sensing theory and applications, including: the physical principles of remote sensing, digital image processing, and analysis, unpiloted aerial systems (UAS; i.e. drones), satellite and airborne remote sensing, and programming for geospatial applications. The curriculum integrates knowledge and skills across academic disciplines, including Geosciences, Ecology and Evolution, and Marine Sciences, to equip students with the ability to answer complex questions related to environmental systems and resources. This program does not currently accept applications.

EnglishScore: All graduate applicants whose native language is not English are required to demonstrate English proficiency by submitting scores from a standardized English proficiency test. Stony Brook University's Graduate School accepts the TOEFL iBT, IELTS, Duolingo English Test, and PTE Academic. Minimum Scores: TOEFL iBT: 80. IELTS: 6.5 overall band with no band below 6.0. Duolingo: 105. PTE Academic: 53.
Requirements: The required materials are: Online application; Official transcripts from all undergraduate and graduate institutions attended; Three letters of recommendation; A statement of purpose describing your interest in the program and career goals; A current curriculum vitae (CV)/résumé; The application fee. The Graduate Record Examination (GRE) is not required for application to this program.
Department: School of Marine and Atmospheric Sciences
Concentration: Finfish, Shellfish, and Algal Aquaculture; Restoration Aquaculture
Description: The Master of Professional Studies (MPS) in Aquaculture is an accelerated, 30-credit, non-thesis degree program designed for students who desire practical training in the diverse fields of aquaculture. The MPS degree provides students with the skills and experience necessary for a successful career as an aquaculture professional. The program offers two tracks: 1) Finfish, Shellfish, and Algal Aquaculture, and 2) Restoration Aquaculture. Students will develop expertise in one track and familiarity with the other. This program is offered at the Stony Brook Southampton campus, home to the newly renovated Marine Sciences Center. Students will have access to a state-of-the-art ~2,000 ft2 shellfish and algal culture facility as well as a ~4,000 ft2 finfish culture facility.

EnglishScore: All international students are required to demonstrate English proficiency by submitting TOEFL or IELTS scores.
Requirements: Applicants for admission to the M.S. and Ph.D. programs in Civil Engineering are expected to have a bachelor’s degree in civil engineering or a closely related field from a college or university of recognized standing. Applicants are judged on the basis of their previous academic performance (GPA), research or professional experience, three letters of recommendation, and a statement of purpose.
Department: College of Engineering and Applied Sciences
Concentration: structural systems, building envelope and MEP systems
Description: The Master of Science in Architectural Engineering (MSAE) is a two-semester program (fall and spring admission) designed to provide students with an engineering-focused graduate degree with an emphasis on building design and performance. The program builds on the undergraduate architectural engineering curriculum at Stony Brook by requiring more in-depth study of the major architectural engineering subject areas: structural systems, building envelope, and mechanical/electrical/plumbing systems. The curriculum provides a balance between theory and practice and addresses modern building design challenges and sustainability. The focus of the program is on building engineering system design, integration, and performance. In addition to coursework in each of the three subject areas, students choose a concentration in structural systems or in building envelope and MEP systems. All students must also complete a comprehensive design project.

EnglishScore: All international students must demonstrate English proficiency. Accepted tests and minimum scores include: TOEFL iBT score of 80, IELTS score of 6.5, Duolingo English Test (DET) score of 105, or PTE Academic score of 53.
Requirements: A complete application includes: The Common Application or ApplySUNY application, a $50 non-refundable application fee, your official high school transcript, a letter of recommendation from a teacher or counselor, SAT or ACT scores (Stony Brook is test-optional for the Spring 2025 and Fall 2025 semesters), and a required essay.
Department: School of Marine and Atmospheric Sciences (SoMAS)
Description: The major in Environmental Design, Policy, and Planning (EDP) is an interdisciplinary major in the social sciences that deals with the human dimensions of environmental problems. It combines coursework in environmental studies, economics, political science, sociology and other fields to prepare students for careers in environmental planning, policy, law, and research, or in “green” business and non-profit organizations. EDP majors acquire skills in critical thinking, policy analysis, spatial analysis (GIS), and written and oral communication. The curriculum emphasizes an understanding of social, political, economic, and institutional factors that lead to environmental problems and that must be addressed in order to create more sustainable and resilient societies. Each student is required to complete a 15-credit specialization in a topic of their choice, which may include environmental policy, environmental design, coastal environmental planning, sustainability studies, or GIS.
