A minimum undergraduate grade point average of 3.0. For international students, a score of at least 550 (paper based) or 80 (internet based) on the Test of English as a Foreign Language (TOEFL). All applications must be submitted online.
Description: The Graduate Certificate in Classical Architecture offers students an in-depth exposure to the history, theory, and practice of classical architecture. It allows them to understand how classical principles can be applied to contemporary design. The 18-credit curriculum combines studio courses and seminars that complement professional degree offerings in architecture, urban planning, landscape design, and interior design. The program also provides continuing education opportunities for a wide range of practitioners and others with an interest in the field. Applicants for the graduate certificate must hold a baccalaureate degree. Courses for the certificate program can be taken independently of the degree programs.

Successful applicants usually have a G.P.A. of 3.0 or higher. Applicants who do not satisfy these requirements may be admitted on a provisional basis, but will be required to make up any deficiencies by taking appropriate undergraduate courses. These courses must be taken for a letter grade and a grade of B or better must be obtained in each.

Description: The M.A. in Art History and Criticism at Stony Brook is for students who wish to pursue a doctorate in the field, as well as for those who intend to work in museums or other art-related professions. The MA is a two-year, 30-credit program in which students are immersed in the methods and practices of the field. All students are required to take AHI 591, Methods in Art History and Criticism, in their first semester. Over the course of their study, M.A. students are also required to take at least two seminars in each of the three historical areas offered by the department: Pre-Modern (before 1750), Modern (1750–1945), and Contemporary (1945–the present). The program of study is designed with a faculty adviser in consultation with the Graduate Program Director. The program culminates with a qualifying paper, a substantial research paper of publishable quality based on a revised seminar paper, which is completed under the supervision of a faculty adviser in the final semester of study.
ScholarshipType: Merit-based scholarships, Graduate Assistantships, Teaching Assistantships

Description:
The Ph.D. program in Art History and Criticism offers a critical and historical education in the visual arts. The doctoral curriculum at Stony Brook is designed to foster intensive study in a chosen field combined with a broad education in the discipline. The program prepares students for teaching at the college and university level, for curatorial careers in museums, and for a variety of other professions in the arts. Students are expected to devote their full attention to the doctoral program. Fellowships and teaching assistantships provide stipends and tuition scholarships that enable students to focus on their studies.
The Department of Art's faculty in art history and criticism focuses on modern and contemporary art, architecture and visual culture in a global context. The program has particular strengths in American, European, and East Asian art and architecture, and in cross-cultural exchange. Our approach is interdisciplinary. The curriculum combines focused seminars with broad historical and methodological training. The program culminates in a doctoral dissertation that demonstrates the student’s command of a specific area of art history and their ability to make an original contribution to scholarship in the field. Students often pursue interdisciplinary research in collaboration with faculty in other departments, such as history, philosophy, cultural studies, and women's and gender studies.

Description: The graduate program in Art at Stony Brook University offers a course of study leading to the Master of Fine Arts (MFA) degree. The program is dedicated to the notion of the artist as an intellectual and visual explorer. Our curriculum is built around a central core of individual studio work and critical seminars. Within this flexible structure, students are encouraged to develop their own individualized course of study, working with their advisors to combine the available resources of the Department and the University in a way that best suits their particular interests and goals. The MFA is offered in two tracks: Studio Art and the IMAP (Integrated Media Art and Practice) program. While students generally concentrate in a chosen field or medium, such as painting, drawing, sculpture, printmaking, photography, video, electronic media, installation, and performance art, a major emphasis of the program is on the crossing of these boundaries, and on the cross-pollination of ideas and methods. MFA students in the Department of Art also have the opportunity to participate in interdisciplinary study in other departments of the University. This is a 60 credit hour program that emphasizes extensive studio experience in the practice of art. The program also provides opportunities for study in the theory, criticism, and history of art. All graduate students are provided with individual studios. Studio visits are conducted regularly by the full-time faculty and by visiting artists and critics. The Visiting Artist Program brings to campus a diverse and distinguished group of artists, critics, and art historians each semester for lectures, studio visits, and seminars. Art students may choose to supplement their studies with a range of art history, theory, and criticism courses within the Department of Art. In addition to our faculty, graduate students have access to the resources of a major research university, including extensive libraries and computer-imaging facilities. Students also benefit from Stony Brook’s proximity to New York City and its rich cultural resources. The program also offers many opportunities for students to exhibit their work, and there is a final MFA Thesis Exhibition in the final semester. The Lawrence Alloway Memorial Lecture series, supported by an endowment, is an annual event that brings a distinguished art critic to our campus to lecture and meet with graduate students. Other symposia and conferences in the arts are regularly held on campus, providing a stimulating intellectual environment and opportunities to meet and connect with graduate students in other departments, as well as other artists, designers, critics, and scholars.

Description: This online certificate is designed for students seeking entry to a music program at the collegiate level, as well as high school and private music teachers looking to hone their craft. Students will build a strong foundation in music theory, aural skills, and keyboarding, developing professional skills through applied instruction. Students choose one area of specialization: voice, winds and brass, strings, percussion, or piano.

Description: The Advanced Graduate Certificate in Arts Leadership (ALS) is a 15-credit graduate certificate offered exclusively online through the School of Professional Development. The curriculum is designed for arts professionals with a passion for their field, an entrepreneurial spirit, and a desire to lead a thriving arts organization. Students will learn strategic planning and decision-making, fundraising, financial management, ownership and licensing, and board development and governance. With an emphasis on practical skills, the curriculum equips working professionals to advance to executive-level positions at a wide range of organizations, including museums, galleries, theaters, symphonies, and dance and opera companies.

Description: The Advanced Graduate Certificate in Arts Management program is designed for individuals currently employed in arts organizations or for those who wish to pursue a career in the field. The curriculum focuses on building and enhancing the professional skills necessary to meet the challenges of the arts industry in the 21st century by providing the professional training and education required to foster artistic and organizational success. The five-course curriculum provides a solid foundation of business practices relevant to the unique needs of arts organizations. Students can select courses that specifically target their areas of interest, including marketing, financial management, law, fundraising and development.

Description: The Advanced Graduate Certificate in Arts Presenting Fundamentals is a fully online, 12-credit program that prepares students for careers as arts presenters. Students will gain the skills, knowledge, and network to become leaders in the field of arts presenting by focusing on audience development, community engagement, arts advocacy, programming, financial management and fundraising for nonprofit arts organizations. The program curriculum culminates with an internship, in which students can choose from a wide range of top-tier professional arts organizations throughout the New York metropolitan area. All courses will be conducted by Stony Brook University faculty members and industry leaders in the field of arts presenting. The program can be completed in as little as two semesters.

Description: The master’s degree program in Athletic Training is designed for students who wish to pursue certification as an athletic trainer. The program is specifically designed to provide students with the opportunity to develop the knowledge and skills necessary for the athletic training profession in a variety of clinical settings. Athletic training is practiced by athletic trainers, who are health care professionals. They collaborate with physicians to optimize patient and client activity and participation in athletics, work and life. The practice of athletic training encompasses the prevention, examination and diagnosis, treatment, and rehabilitation of emergent, acute, subacute, and chronic neuromusculoskeletal conditions and certain medical conditions in order to minimize subsequent impairments, functional limitations, disability, and societal limitations. The master’s degree in Athletic Training will conform to the educational standards set forth by the Commission on Accreditation of Athletic Training Education (CAATE). It is a professional program that will require two years of intensive study (including summers) and will offer a curriculum with both a didactic and a clinical component. The didactic portion of the curriculum will offer students a thorough understanding of the theoretical basis of the profession, while the clinical component will provide hands-on experience in a variety of different clinical settings under the supervision of qualified allied health care professionals (e.g., certified athletic trainers, physicians). Students who complete this course of study will be eligible to sit for the Board of Certification (BOC) national examination to become a certified athletic trainer (ATC).
Accredidation: The master’s degree in Athletic Training is accredited by the Commission on Accreditation of Athletic Training Education (CAATE).

Description: The Master of Science in Athletic Training (MSAT) program is an entry-level professional program for students who have completed a bachelor’s degree and wish to become an athletic trainer. The MSAT program prepares students for a career in athletic training and provides them with the knowledge, skills and abilities to become a successful clinician. The program will emphasize evidence-based practice and encourage life-long learning. The MSAT program requires completion of 63 credits of graduate coursework, including 15 credits of clinical education experiences. Students are afforded multiple opportunities to apply knowledge and skills in a variety of athletic training practice settings under the supervision of qualified clinical preceptors. In addition, students will have the opportunity to engage in a scholarly project in the final semester of the program.
Accredidation: The Master of Science in Athletic Training program is accredited by the Commission on Accreditation of Athletic Training Education (CAATE).

Department: School of Marine and Atmospheric Sciences
Description: The graduate program in atmospheric sciences, offered through the School of Marine and Atmospheric Sciences (SoMAS), is designed to prepare students for careers in research, teaching, and applied meteorology. Two degree programs are available: the MS program, which prepares students for work in operational and applied meteorology or for pursuit of further graduate study, and the PhD program, which prepares students for careers in research and teaching. Coursework and research in the atmospheric sciences program focus on fundamental processes in the atmosphere and at the air-sea interface. Students may elect to work on a broad range of topics, including atmospheric chemistry, boundary-layer and cable meteorology, cloud and precipitation physics, climate and climate change, mesoscale and synoptic meteorology, atmospheric radiation, remote sensing, and tropical meteorology.

Department: School of Marine and Atmospheric Sciences
Description: The School of Marine and Atmospheric Sciences (SoMAS) offers the M.S. and Ph.D. degrees in marine, atmospheric and terrestrial sciences, and the M.A. degree in marine conservation and policy. Research opportunities are available in biological, chemical, geological and physical oceanography; in atmospheric chemistry, dynamics, and radiation; and in climate studies and terrestrial sciences. The atmospheric sciences program of study leads to the Ph.D. in Marine and Atmospheric Science. Study may be pursued in the following areas: tropical meteorology, including hurricane dynamics, climate dynamics, and the role of the tropics in the global climate system; atmospheric chemistry, especially the study of trace gases and aerosols in the troposphere; the planetary boundary layer and its interaction with the ocean; cloud physics, including the development of precipitation and the interaction of clouds with climate; mesoscale and synoptic-scale meteorology, particularly coastal meteorology; and radiative transfer and remote sensing, including the use of satellite and radar data to study the atmosphere.

Description: The master’s degree program in Biochemistry and Cell Biology provides an advanced education to students seeking careers in medicine and related health fields, biomedical research in academic, government, or industrial settings, as well as teaching. The course-based program focuses on the mechanisms of human disease at the biochemical and cellular levels, and can be completed in one year of full-time study. Students will develop problem solving, critical thinking, and communications skills through coursework and the critical review of scientific literature. Upon completion of the program, students will be able to apply their knowledge to the analysis of biomedical problems.

Applicants must have completed at least one semester of calculus, one year of general chemistry with laboratory, one year of organic chemistry with laboratory, and one year of physics. It is highly desirable that applicants have completed at least one course in physical chemistry and one course in biochemistry.
Description: The Master’s of Science in Biochemistry and Molecular Biology (BMB) program is designed for students who wish to pursue a research career in biochemistry and molecular biology. Students graduating with the M.S. degree in BMB will be prepared for a wide variety of job opportunities in academia and industry, including academic research laboratories, pharmaceutical and biotechnology companies, and government. It will also prepare students who are seeking to strengthen their academic credentials for Ph.D. and M.D. programs.

Description: The Biochemistry and Molecular Biology PhD Program trains independent researchers for academic or industrial careers. The first year of the program is spent in intensive course work and in laboratory rotations, designed to provide a broad foundation in modern biochemistry and molecular biology and to expose the student to various research opportunities in the department prior to the choice of a thesis advisor. Advanced courses and seminars in the following years of study are also required. The BMB Program involves a rigorous research component that culminates in the writing and defense of a PhD dissertation. Graduates of our Program are well-prepared for their next career steps, and many have achieved distinguished careers in academic research or in the biotechnology and pharmaceutical industries. See alumni page for examples.

Description:
The Graduate Program in Biochemistry and Structural Biology (BSB) offers interdisciplinary training leading to the Ph.D. degree. Research in the BSB Program focuses on the molecular mechanisms of biological processes, with a particular emphasis on the relationship between molecular structure and function. Students in the program gain expertise in a variety of cutting-edge research areas including structural biology (X-ray crystallography, NMR, cryo-EM), drug design, enzymology, chemical biology, molecular biology, and cell biology. Graduates of our program are well prepared for careers in academia, industry (biotechnology and pharmaceutical), education, science policy, and science writing. ... and many others. Faculty in the BSB Program come from several different departments, including Biochemistry and Cell Biology, Chemistry, Pharmacological Sciences, and the School of Medicine, as well as from the nearby Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory and Brookhaven National Laboratory. The BSB Program is directed by Dr. Robert Rizzo.

The BSB Graduate Program is part of a larger, interdisciplinary group of graduate programs in the molecular biosciences, collectively organized as the Molecular and Cellular Biology (MCB) Graduate Program. In addition to BSB, the programs include:

Molecular and Cellular Pharmacology (MCP)
Molecular Genetics and Microbiology (MGM)
Neuroscience (NEU)
Genetics (GEN)

Please see www.stonybrook.edu/mcb for a more detailed description of the umbrella program and the individual tracks.

Description: The graduate programs in Biological Sciences (BIO) include Biochemistry and Structural Biology; Cell Biology; Ecology and Evolution; Genetics; Molecular and Cellular Biology; Molecular and Cellular Pharmacology; and Neuroscience. These programs emphasize an interdisciplinary approach to graduate training and research. Faculty are drawn from many departments in the College of Arts and Sciences, the School of Medicine, and the School of Marine and Atmospheric Sciences. In addition, scientists at the nearby Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory and Brookhaven National Laboratory hold adjunct faculty appointments in the graduate programs and serve as research mentors for graduate students. The graduate programs are designed to prepare students for careers in research and teaching in a wide variety of academic, government, and industrial settings.

Description: The Biology teacher education program is designed to prepare students for careers as secondary school biology teachers. The program is composed of 45-credits of graduate coursework in biology, education and teaching pedagogy, which can lead to a Master of Arts in Teaching (MAT) degree. Students may also complete the program as a non-degree student, thereby fulfilling the course requirements for the initial New York State teaching certificate. Students will develop skills to critically analyze curriculum, create and adapt materials, and accommodate the needs of a diverse student population. The program has been nationally recognized by the National Science Teachers Association (NSTA). Students who successfully complete the program and the New York State Teacher Certification Examinations are recommended by Stony Brook for an Initial Teaching Certificate, which allows them to teach biology in grades 7 through 12 in New York State public schools. Note: Students seeking certification in states other than New York are responsible for researching the certification requirements for that state. Students should speak to an advisor about how the Stony Brook program might align with another state's requirements. This program has been approved by the New York State Education Department to be offered in a distance education format (some required courses may be offered only in an online format). Please be aware that if you are a student in an online program who is seeking professional licensure in a state other than New York, you should review the specific requirements for that state on our State Authorization page. Students seeking teaching certification in a state other than New York are advised to review the specific requirements for that state. Students are responsible for verifying that the Stony Brook program meets the educational requirements for the specific license they are seeking in the state in which they seek certification.
Accredidation: The Master of Arts in Teaching (MAT) programs at Stony Brook University are accredited by the Council for the Accreditation of Educator Preparation (CAEP), 1140 19th St NW, Suite 400, Washington, DC 20036 (202) 223-0077.

The Master’s of Science degree program is research-oriented and requires the completion and oral defense of a research thesis. Students in the program work with a faculty advisor within one of the following research specializations:

- Cellular and Molecular Biology
- Ecology and Evolution
- Neuroscience
- Genetics, Genomics, and Bioinformatics

Students in the Cellular and Molecular Biology, Neuroscience and Genetics, Genomics, and Bioinformatics specializations select a faculty advisor from the Department of Neurobiology and Behavior or the Department of Biochemistry and Cell Biology. Students in the Ecology and Evolution specialization select a faculty advisor from the Department of Ecology and Evolution.

Description: The Graduate Program in Ecology and Evolution at Stony Brook University is one of the leading programs in the nation. This is reflected in the high quality of our graduate students and faculty, who regularly publish in the very best scientific journals (e.g., Science, Nature, PNAS, Evolution, Ecology) and in the success of our graduates in obtaining positions in academia, government, and the private sector. Major research areas include evolutionary biology, systematics, population and community ecology, population genetics and genomics, behavioral ecology, conservation biology, disease ecology, and marine and freshwater ecology. Our program provides rigorous training through a combination of coursework, seminars, and the student's own dissertation research. The formal coursework for the Ph.D. is usually completed in two years. In addition to a series of core courses and seminars, each student's course of study is individually designed, with the approval of their dissertation committee, to meet their specific research and career goals. Students and their research are supported by a combination of teaching assistantships, research assistantships, and a variety of fellowships from Stony Brook and from state and federal agencies.

Description:
The M.S. in Biomedical Engineering program will prepare students for careers in the biomedical engineering industry or for Ph.D. studies. Students will learn how to apply engineering and biological sciences principles in the development of new medical devices and therapies.

The M.S. degree offers two options: thesis and non-thesis project. The thesis option is research oriented, which is to encourage students who would like to pursue a research career in academia or industry or continue their Ph.D. studies. The non-thesis option is course-oriented, which aims at students who desire to pursue a career in biomedical industry.

Stony Brook's Department of Biomedical Engineering fosters a collaborative research environment that allows for a multidisciplinary approach to problem-solving. We emphasize translational research, moving discoveries from the lab to the patient's bedside. To achieve this, students work alongside clinicians from Stony Brook Medicine, Long Island's premier academic medical center.

Description:
The Master of Science in Biomedical Engineering (MSBE) program is designed for students with a bachelor's degree in engineering or the physical/applied sciences. The program provides advanced training appropriate for students who wish to pursue a career in the biomedical engineering industry or continue to a doctoral degree program.

The MSBE program is designed to be completed in one-and-a-half to two years of full-time study. Part-time study is also an option.

Students in the program have the opportunity to participate in groundbreaking research with our world-renowned faculty and have access to our state-of-the-art facilities. The program provides the students flexibility in choosing their area of specialization. Students select one of the following specializations to meet their individual interests and career goals:

Description: The Biomedical Engineering (BME) graduate program offers a Master of Science (MS) degree in BME with an emphasis in Medical Physics. This MS program is designed to prepare students for a career in medical physics, a field which combines the knowledge of physics and engineering with medicine. The program is specifically intended for students with an undergraduate degree in engineering, physics, or another physical science. The MS-BME program with an emphasis in Medical Physics offers three tracks: Therapeutic Medical Physics, Diagnostic Medical Physics, Nuclear Medical Physics. Graduates of the program will be well qualified for positions in hospitals, industry, government, and academic medical centers. With a degree from a CAMPEP-accredited medical physics program, graduates are eligible for board certification in the field, a prerequisite for a clinical medical physicist position.

Description: The Ph.D. Program in Biomedical Engineering is designed to provide students with the advanced skills and knowledge necessary to become leaders in the field of biomedical engineering. The program is specifically structured to train students to conduct original, cutting-edge research and to prepare them for careers in academic research, government, or industry. A unique aspect of the BME graduate program is its organization into five focused research tracks based on strengths of the BME faculty: Biomechanics & Mechanobiology, Bioimaging & Bioinstrumentation, Biomaterials & Regenerative Medicine, Bioelectricity & Biocomputing, and Systems & Synthetic Biology. Students will complete didactic training and dissertation research in one of these five tracks.

Description: The graduate program in Medical Physics provides students with a firm understanding of the principles of medical physics, and a broad knowledge of the applications of physics in medicine. The objective is to train students to be leaders in the field of Medical Physics, in academia, industry, and the clinic. The program is offered within the Department of Biomedical Engineering, and students can obtain either a Ph.D. in Biomedical Engineering with a concentration in Medical Physics, or a M.S. in Biomedical Engineering with a concentration in Medical Physics. The program includes both formal didactic coursework and opportunities for practical experience and training. Students may also participate in the extensive research programs in the departments of Biomedical Engineering, Radiology, Radiation Oncology, and Neurology.
Accredidation: The Graduate Program in Medical Physics is accredited by CAMPEP (the Commission on the Accreditation of Medical Physics Educational Programs).

Description: The Advanced Graduate Certificate in Biomedical Informatics provides students with an opportunity to receive core training in the principles and methods of biomedical informatics. Students will acquire the necessary skills to collect, manage and analyze biomedical and health data for the purpose of advancing clinical care, and biomedical and translational research. The certificate is offered by the Department of Biomedical Informatics, which has primary responsibility for the curriculum. Upon completion of the program, students will be able to apply state-of-the-art computational methods to solve challenging biomedical and clinical problems. This certificate can be pursued in conjunction with another Stony Brook graduate program (e.g. MS, PhD, MD, etc.) or as a stand-alone program of study.

Description: The Master of Science (MS) program in Biomedical Informatics (BMI) is a 33-credit, non-thesis program open to students with or without a prior computational, statistical, or biological background. Biomedical Informatics is an interdisciplinary field that combines knowledge of computer science, information science, biostatistics, and biomedical science to improve human health through research, education, and patient care. Its goal is to provide biomedical researchers and health care providers with advanced tools for the acquisition, storage, retrieval, analysis, and use of biomedical data. Students in this program will complete a set of core courses that will provide them with a strong foundation of knowledge in biomedical informatics. They will have the opportunity to delve deeper into specific areas of interest through elective courses in one of three tracks: clinical informatics, translational bioinformatics, or imaging informatics. A capstone project will allow them to apply the knowledge and skills they acquired to a specific BMI research problem. Upon graduation, students in the MS-BMI program will be able to manage biomedical data, design and conduct studies that lead to new biomedical discoveries, translate these discoveries to improve the practice of medicine, and help ensure that data are used in an ethical manner. They will be competitive for BMI-related positions in academia, industry, and government.

Two letters of recommendation from college faculty who can attest to the applicant’s academic potential and accomplishments. Description: Biomedical Informatics is the field that is concerned with the optimal use of information, often aided by the use of technology, to improve individual health, health care, public health, and biomedical research. It is a scientific discipline that is grounded in the principles of computer science, information science, cognitive science, social science, and engineering, as well as the clinical and basic biological sciences. Biomedical Informatics is a broad and exciting discipline, with many opportunities for those who wish to make an impact on any of these areas. Stony Brook University’s Department of Biomedical Informatics PhD Program has three training tracks: Clinical Informatics, which is the application of informatics and information technology to deliver healthcare services; Translational Bioinformatics, which is the development of storage, analytic, and interpretive methods to optimize the transformation of increasingly voluminous biomedical and genomic data into proactive, predictive, preventative, and participatory health; Imaging Informatics, which is concerned with the common issues that arise in all imaging, and modality-specific issues. Students receive a broad training in all areas of Biomedical Informatics, and then focus on one of these three tracks for their dissertation research.

Description: The Department of Applied Mathematics and Statistics offers an M.S. program in statistics. This program is for students who are seeking a career as a practicing statistician in industry or government, or who wish to pursue a Ph.D. in statistics or a related field. The program requires 30 graduate credits. All requirements for the M.S. degree must be completed within three years of the date of matriculation. Typically, full-time students take two years to complete the M.S. degree. The statistics track is for students who want a broad education in applied statistics and who seek a general statistician’s career. It prepares students for a career as a practicing statistician in industry or government and provides a very strong background for Ph.D. studies in statistics. The statistics track has two specializations: (i) Biostatistics, and (ii) Data Science and Computational Statistics. The Biostatistics specialization is designed for students who want a career in the pharmaceutical industry or the medical field, and it also well prepares students who wish to pursue a Ph.D. in biostatistics.

The program provides rigorous training in the theory, methodology, and application of statistics. Students develop the skills to develop new statistical methods, to apply modern statistical methods to the analysis of complex data, and to collaborate effectively with domain experts. The PhD program in statistics has two tracks: (1) computational applied statistics and (2) biostatistics. The biostatistics track prepares students for careers in academia, industry (e.g., pharmaceutical and biotech), and government (e.g., FDA and NIH). The department has a long history of successful interdisciplinary collaboration with researchers in medicine, public health, biology, and many other fields. The Center for an Informed and Healthy Society (CIHS) under the Department provides a platform for such collaborations.

The program culminates in a final project creating a professional weathercast tape. Students who complete the program are eligible for the American Meteorological Society’s Certified Broadcast Meteorologist (CBM) designation. Successful graduates of the program will be qualified for a range of positions in broadcast meteorology as well as private-sector forecasting and consulting.

Our MBA program is designed for talented professionals from a broad spectrum of academic and business backgrounds. Small class sizes, personal attention from a world-class faculty, and collaboration with a highly-motivated and diverse group of peers create an engaging learning environment where students can thrive and excel. Our flexible scheduling options (full-time, part-time, evening, and weekends) allow students to tailor their program to their needs. MBA students can focus their studies in finance, marketing, health care management, innovation, or general management. Our program provides a unique opportunity to learn how to conduct applied research with direct relevance for business practice. Students in the Stony Brook Executive DBA program will develop their business expertise and research skills through a rigorous set of core courses and close mentorship from our world-renowned faculty. With a PhD from a top-tier research institution, each faculty member is a nationally or internationally recognized scholar in their field of expertise. DBA students will have a unique opportunity to focus on a particular area of business such as finance, marketing, organizational behavior, operations management and accounting. The curriculum includes a mixture of synchronous and asynchronous coursework to offer the flexibility working executives need to balance their education with a demanding career. Synchronous coursework takes place approximately one weekend per month.

Resume

Prerequisites: A bachelor's degree. A master's degree in a business or related field is preferable. While not a requirement, a research-oriented master's degree in a related discipline may increase the applicant's chances of admission.
Description:
The doctoral program in business administration at Stony Brook University's College of Business is a PhD program that develops scholars for careers in research and teaching with four areas of concentration: accounting, finance, marketing, and organizational behavior. Students are admitted into a particular area of concentration and work closely with faculty in that area.

The PhD program with a concentration in accounting prepares students for research and teaching careers in academia. The primary goal of our program is to train students to conduct rigorous and relevant accounting research that is publishable in top-tier academic journals. The program offers small classes and a collegial environment where students can work closely with faculty members. Students will receive thorough training in accounting (archival and/or analytical), econometrics, and finance.
Accredidation: The College of Business at Stony Brook is a member of the Association to Advance Collegiate Schools of Business (AACSB), the premier accrediting body for business schools worldwide. The College of Business is accredited by AACSB International.
ScholarshipAmount: Full tuition scholarship and a $35,000 annual stipend.

The typical applicant has a strong quantitative background from one of the following fields: economics, engineering, applied mathematics, statistics, computer science, and business. Description: The PhD in Business Administration at Stony Brook University is a rigorous, research-intensive program that prepares students for academic careers at leading research universities. The program has areas of emphasis in finance, marketing, organizational behavior, and operations management. Our curriculum provides students with a strong foundation in the theoretical and methodological knowledge required to conduct high-quality, impactful research. The program emphasizes a mentorship model where students work closely with faculty members on research projects. Our distinguished faculty, known for their prolific scholarly contributions, will serve as your dedicated mentors, guiding you through every step of your research journey. The PhD program offers a competitive funding package that includes a stipend, tuition scholarship, and health insurance. Our graduates have successfully secured tenure-track faculty positions at well-respected universities.
Accredidation: The College of Business at Stony Brook University is accredited by AACSB International-the Association to Advance Collegiate Schools of Business.
ScholarshipAmount: Full tuition waiver plus a $32,000 annual stipend

Description: The PhD in Business Administration program is a full-time, research-oriented program that prepares graduates for academic careers at leading research universities. Our curriculum provides students with a strong foundation in their chosen discipline, as well as the statistical and methodological skills necessary to conduct high-quality, scholarly research. Students in the program select one of the following five areas of emphasis: Accounting, Finance, Marketing, Organizational Behavior, or Operations Management & Decision Analytics. Small class sizes and close interaction with faculty in classes, research projects, and the dissertation provide a supportive and challenging environment in which to develop as a scholar. Our curriculum is designed to be completed in four to five years.
Accredidation: Stony Brook University's College of Business is accredited by AACSB International-the Association to Advance Collegiate Schools of Business. AACSB accreditation is the hallmark of excellence in business education and has been earned by less than five percent of the world's business programs.
AverageScholarshipAmount: Full tuition waiver and a $32,000 stipend
ScholarshipAmount: Full tuition waiver and a $32,000 stipend

EnglishScore: All graduate applicants are required to demonstrate English proficiency. Stony Brook University accepts scores from the TOEFL iBT, IELTS, Duolingo, and PTE Academic tests. The requirement may be waived for applicants who have received a degree from an institution in the United States or another country on the waiver list.

In addition to the online application, fee and transcripts, applicants must submit the following: A current resume; A personal statement that addresses the following question: How would you describe the unique characteristics of the business technology field and how will earning this MS degree position you for the career you want?; Three letters of recommendation; Official score report for the GRE or GMAT exam. The GRE/GMAT requirement may be waived if the applicant meets one of the following criteria: An undergraduate GPA of 3.2 or higher from an accredited institution. An earned master’s or doctoral degree from an accredited institution. 5+ years of relevant professional work experience.
Description: The Master of Science in Business Technology degree prepares students to be successful technology leaders and managers in today’s knowledge-based economy. The program has been redesigned to integrate business and technology to develop an applied understanding of the integration of people, processes, data, and devices that are so vital to every organization. The program offers students an opportunity to take advantage of cutting-edge business technology topics with practical skills to solve real-world problems. We recognize and support the growing need for leaders who can help companies navigate the world of ever-changing technology and use it as a strategic advantage.

ProgramName: Cellular Physiology and Molecular Biophysics PhD
EnglishScore: International applicants are required to demonstrate English proficiency. Accepted tests and minimum scores for doctoral programs are: TOEFL iBT (90), IELTS (6.5 with no subsection below 6), Duolingo (115), or PTE (61).

A personal statement describing research experience and career goals.

Description: The Graduate Program in Physiology and Biophysics at Stony Brook University is a research-intensive course of study that leads to the PhD degree. The aim of the program is to train the next generation of scientists and educators by providing a strong foundation in physiology and biophysics and to facilitate development of critical thinking and communication skills. The research interests of the faculty are diverse and encompass most modern areas of physiology, biophysics and neuroscience. Our research employs a wide range of state-of-the art techniques to address questions at the molecular, cellular, organ and whole-animal levels.
ScholarshipType: Full tuition scholarship, stipend, and health insurance

EnglishScore: All graduate applicants who are not native or primary speakers of English must demonstrate English proficiency. The Graduate School's English proficiency requirements must be met.
Requirements: In addition to the Graduate School’s general admission requirements, applicants are expected to have a bachelor’s degree in chemical engineering or a closely related field from a college or university of recognized standing. Promise for graduate study is judged by the applicant’s undergraduate record, letters of recommendation and statement of purpose. All applicants are required to take the Graduate Record Examination (GRE) general test. International applicants who do not have a degree from an English-speaking university must also take the Test of English as a Foreign Language (TOEFL). Application materials must include: the completed application form, official transcripts of all college-level work, three letters of recommendation, statement of purpose and official GRE scores. International applicants whose native language is not English are also required to submit TOEFL scores.
Department: College of Engineering and Applied Sciences
Description: The M.S. degree in Chemical and Molecular Engineering is awarded after the successful completion of 30 graduate credits of approved courses with a cumulative grade point average of 3.0 or better. The student may select either a thesis or a non-thesis option. The thesis option requires 6 credits of thesis research in addition to 24 credits of course work. The non-thesis option requires a 3 credit design project in addition to 27 credits of course work. All students have to pass a written qualifying examination (WQ).

EnglishScore: International students whose native language is not English are required to demonstrate English proficiency by submitting their official scores on the Test of English as a Foreign Language (TOEFL) or International English Language Testing System (IELTS).
Requirements: In addition to the general admission requirements of the Graduate School, admission to the Ph.D. program in Chemical and Molecular Engineering requires a B.S. or M.S. degree in chemical engineering, materials science and engineering, or a related discipline from an accredited institution. Applicants are expected to have a minimum cumulative grade point average of 3.0 on a 4.0 scale. The admission committee also holistically evaluates other credentials submitted by the applicant, including letters of recommendation, statement of purpose, and resume. The general GRE test is not required for admission.
Department: College of Engineering and Applied Sciences
Description: The graduate program in Chemical and Molecular Engineering is designed to provide students with a sound basis in chemical engineering fundamentals, as well as the advanced research skills needed to solve modern problems in chemical engineering. It is a research-oriented program leading to the Doctor of Philosophy degree. The student, in consultation with a faculty advisor, designs a program of study that best suits his or her interests and career goals. Students in the PhD program typically complete all the coursework within the first one to two years and devote the remaining time to research. There are many research opportunities available for students. Please browse our faculty profiles to find your research interest.

EnglishScore: All international graduate applicants are required to demonstrate English proficiency. The University accepts TOEFL iBT, IELTS, Duolingo English Test, and PTE Academic. Minimum scores are: TOEFL iBT - 80, IELTS - 6.5 overall (no band below 6.0), Duolingo - 105, PTE - 53.
Requirements: A bachelor's degree in Chemistry or a related discipline with at least 24 credits in college chemistry and 12 credits in related areas, i.e., physics, biology and mathematics, with an average of B or better. Required application materials: Online Application, Application Fee, Transcripts, 3 Letters of Recommendation, Resume or C.V., Personal Statement, English Proficiency. GRE General: Not Required.
Description: The Master of Arts in Teaching (M.A.T.) is a 15-month program that combines graduate-level coursework in Chemistry with pedagogical training for prospective secondary school teachers (grades 7-12). Upon successful completion of the program, students are awarded an M.A.T. degree and are recommended for New York State Initial Teacher Certification. Students completing the program may also be eligible for certification in other states, through reciprocity agreements. M.A.T. candidates take graduate courses in chemistry alongside Ph.D. students and master's students, and education courses specifically designed for M.A.T. science students, with a unique focus on how students learn science. The program includes two semesters of student teaching in local, partner districts, where candidates develop their teaching under the guidance of a highly qualified mentor teacher and a University supervisor.
Accredidation: All of Stony Brook's teacher preparation programs are registered by the New York State Education Department and are accredited by the Council for the Accreditation of Educator Preparation (CAEP).

EnglishScore: The Test of English as aForeign Language (TOEFL), the International English Language Testing System (IELTS), or the Duolingo English Test (DET) is required for all international applicants whose native language is not English.
Requirements:
Applicants should have an undergraduate major in chemistry or a related discipline with a solid background in chemistry. At a minimum, students should have successfully completed one year of general chemistry, one year of organic chemistry, one year of physical chemistry, and one year of physics. Additional courses in analytical chemistry, inorganic chemistry, and mathematics are also recommended. A minimum overall GPA of 3.0 is required.

The following are required for an application to be complete:

- A completed application form for admission to the Graduate School
- A nonrefundable application fee
- Official transcripts from all universities and colleges attended
- Three letters of recommendation
- A personal statement
- GRE scores are not required for admission.
- Official TOEFL or IELTS scores for international applicants whose native language is not English.
Description: The Department of Chemistry offers a program of graduate study leading to the Master of Science degree. The program is designed for students who desire a broader and more profound knowledge of chemistry than can be obtained in a four-year undergraduate curriculum. Since the requirements for the degree are less specialized than those for the Ph.D. degree, it offers a suitable program for students with diverse career objectives. The Master’s degree in Chemistry is available with three options: with thesis, without thesis, and with concentration in Chemical Education. In each case, a minimum of 30 graduate credits must be satisfactorily completed. An average grade of B (3.0 grade point average) or better is required. The specific course and research requirements are decided upon by the student in consultation with the Graduate Program Director. The requirements listed below are intended only as guidelines. Normally, a full-time student can complete the program within two years.

EnglishScore: For international students, an official TOEFL score is required. A minimum score of 90 on the internet-based test (iBT) is required for admission. The IELTS and Duolingo are also accepted.
Requirements: For admission to the Ph.D. program in Chemistry, a bachelor’s degree in chemistry is required with courses in general, organic, and physical chemistry. The Graduate School requires a minimum undergraduate grade point average of 3.00 on a 4.00 scale. Applicants must submit a completed application form, letters of recommendation, and a personal statement. The general GRE test is not required. International students whose native language is not English must also submit scores from the Test of English as a Foreign Language (TOEFL).
Description:
Welcome to the Graduate Program in Chemistry at Stony Brook University! The Department of Chemistry at Stony Brook is a premier center for research and education in the chemical sciences. We offer a vibrant and diverse program that includes a faculty of world-class scholars and an outstanding group of students and postdoctoral researchers. We offer a full range of degree programs in chemistry, with Ph.D. degrees in Chemical Physics and Chemistry.

The PhD program in chemistry is focused on preparing students for a variety of careers in academia, industry, and government. We provide a rigorous training program in the traditional areas of chemistry, as well as in a number of interdisciplinary areas. Our students graduate with a broad understanding of the chemical sciences, a deep knowledge in a particular research area, and the skills to succeed as independent scientists. The goal of the program is to bring each student to a level of knowledge and experimental or theoretical skill that will permit them, by the end of their program, to undertake significant research on their own. Students will take a number of graduate courses and will be required to pass a series of qualifying examinations. The major emphasis of the program is on research and the submission of an original and significant thesis is the highlight of the program. We offer students a choice of research opportunities in a wide range of areas that span the traditional disciplines of chemistry as well as interdisciplinary areas that include biological, materials, and physical sciences. Some specific research areas are listed under the faculty research pages.

EnglishScore: An applicant whose native language is not English must take an English proficiency exam. Stony Brook University accepts the following tests: Test of English as a Foreign Language (TOEFL) iBT, International English Language Testing System (IELTS), Duolingo English Test, Pearson Test of English (PTE) Academic.
Requirements: Application Materials: A completed application form to the Graduate School. A non-refundable application fee. Two letters of recommendation from faculty under whom you have studied. One copy of official transcripts from each college or university you have attended. A brief statement of purpose (approximately 500 words) describing your reasons for seeking a certificate in Children’s Literature, your background in the subject, and your goals. A writing sample (approximately 10-20 pages) of your academic prose, preferably on a literary topic. A résumé that lists professional and educational experience. GRE scores are not required.
Description: This 18-credit certificate is designed for students with a BA who wish to pursue a specialization in the study of children's and young adult literature. It can be pursued as a stand-alone certificate or in conjunction with the MA. This program explores the history and development of children’s literature, its major genres, and a range of critical and theoretical approaches. Courses in children’s literature cover a variety of historical periods, from early modern to contemporary, as well as a variety of genres, from picture books and fantasy to realism and young adult literature. All courses will pay close attention to the ways in which representations of childhood are informed by issues of class, race, gender, and nation.

EnglishScore: International students whose native language is not English are required to take the Test of English as a Foreign Language (TOEFL). The minimum acceptable score is 85 on the internet-based test (iBT). This requirement is waived for students who have received a degree from an institution in which the language of instruction is English.
Requirements: All application materials must be submitted through the Apply Yourself online application system. The complete set of required materials is: Graduate School Application and Fee, Transcripts, Three Letters of Recommendation, Statement of Purpose, GRE scores (required for MS and PhD applicants), Resume, TOEFL or IELTS scores (for international students).

Description: The Master of Science program is designed to provide students with the fundamentals of one or more of the civil engineering sub-disciplines. The program can be completed in three semesters of full-time study, with 30 graduate credits required for graduation. Both thesis and non-thesis options are available. The graduate program in civil engineering provides opportunities for professional development in such areas as structural engineering, geotechnical engineering, transportation engineering, and water resources and hydraulic engineering. In addition, the program offers a general option that allows the student to select a broader range of courses to meet their educational objectives.

EnglishScore: All graduate applicants are required to demonstrate English proficiency. Accepted tests and minimum scores include TOEFL iBT (80), IELTS (6.5 overall, with no subsection score below 6), Duolingo English Test (105), and PTE Academic (53).

A grade point average of at least 3.0/4.0 is normally required for admission. The Graduate Record Examination (GRE) general test is not required. Three letters of recommendation. A personal statement (statement of purpose).
Department: College of Engineering and Applied Sciences
Concentration: ['Structural Engineering', 'Geotechnical Engineering', 'Transportation Systems Engineering', 'Water Resources and Hydraulic Engineering']
Description: The Doctor of Philosophy (Ph.D.) program in Civil Engineering is designed to prepare students for a career in research and/or academia. A high level of scholarship is expected of Ph.D. students and the program provides sufficient flexibility to allow for a focus on research in a chosen area of specialization within Civil Engineering. In consultation with their academic advisor, students design an individualized plan of graduate study and research that best meets their interests and career goals. Students must successfully complete a set of core courses and then additional coursework as advised by their Ph.D. committee to strengthen their preparation for the Qualifying examination. Students are also encouraged to participate in teaching or mentoring activities and attend departmental seminars. The Ph.D. program is centered on original research performed under the guidance of the student's research advisor culminating in a dissertation. Students entering the program with a Bachelor of Science degree should expect to spend a minimum of four years of full-time study to complete the program; those with a relevant master’s degree can complete the program in approximately three years.

EnglishScore: An official TOEFL, IELTS, or Duolingo score report is required for all applicants who do not have English as their primary language. Minimum scores: TOEFL: 80 (iBT); IELTS: 6.5 overall band score with no band below 6.0; Duolingo: 105.
Requirements: An earned master's degree with a GPA of 3.0 or higher. Be a state-certified teacher, administrator or pupil personnel services provider (e.g., school counselor, psychologist, social worker). Submit an online application to the Graduate School. Submit a statement of purpose. Submit two letters of recommendation. Submit official transcripts from all colleges and universities attended. Submit a copy of your New York State teaching or service certificate.
Description: The 18-credit Advanced Graduate Certificate in Coaching is a comprehensive, state-of-the-art program designed to prepare students for the New York State coaching certification. Candidates will be trained in the principles and practices of coaching as they relate to the psychological, physiological, and sociological aspects of the athlete. Candidates will complete a six-credit internship that provides an opportunity to coach under the direct supervision of a certified coach in the school setting.

Requirements: To be admitted to the certificate program, a student must meet the graduate school admission requirements and must be enrolled in a Stony Brook PhD program in one of the following departments: Anthropology, Applied Mathematics and Statistics, Biomedical Engineering, Computer Science, Ecology and Evolution, Linguistics, Neurobiology and Behavior, Psychology, or Sociology. To be admitted to the program, a student must have a faculty advisor who is a member of the Cognitive Science faculty.
Description: The Graduate Certificate Program in Cognitive Neuroscience provides students with a solid foundation in the concepts and methods of cognitive neuroscience. Students will be exposed to a range of methodologies, including neuroimaging, electrophysiology, neuropsychology, and computational modeling. The program will involve students in the ongoing research of Stony Brook's strong and vibrant cognitive neuroscience faculty and will enrich their studies through a required proseminar that covers the most important and fundamental ideas and findings in the field.

EnglishScore: For international applicants, a TOEFL score of at least 100 or an IELTS overall band score of at least 7 is required. In exceptional cases, a student with a slightly lower score may be admitted, but will be required to take English proficiency courses upon arrival.
Requirements: All applicants must have a bachelor's degree from a regionally accredited U.S. college or university, or a baccalaureate or its equivalent from a foreign institution of higher learning, and a minimum undergraduate grade point average of 3.00. Students applying to the MA in Computational Linguistics program are expected to have some previous coursework in linguistics (e.g., Introduction to Linguistics, Phonology, Syntax, Semantics) and in computer science (e.g., Introduction to Programming, Data Structures). However, students who have a strong record in one of these areas but not the other are still encouraged to apply.
Description: The M.A. in Computational Linguistics is designed to prepare students for careers in the language technology industry, as computational linguists, software engineers, and data scientists. Students will gain foundational knowledge of linguistics and computer science, alongside advanced training and hands-on experience in the core areas of computational linguistics and natural language processing. The program takes place on-site at Stony Brook's main campus. It can be completed in three semesters by full-time students, or on a part-time basis. Students have the opportunity to participate in industrial internships and academic research projects as part of their studies. The curriculum includes courses on programming, algorithms, machine learning, and natural language processing, as well as courses on core areas of linguistics (phonology, syntax, and semantics). A background in linguistics, computer science, or a related field is expected.

ProgramName: Concentration in Community and Political Social Action (MSW)
EnglishScore: All graduate applicants are required to demonstrate English proficiency. Stony Brook University accepts: TOEFL iBT (80 minimum score), IELTS (6.5 minimum overall score with no subsection score below 6), Duolingo (105 minimum score), or PTE Academic (53 minimum score).
Requirements: A bachelor's degree from an accredited college or university. A minimum undergraduate grade point average of 3.0. Completion of at least 21 credits of liberal arts courses, including a course in statistics. A completed application for admission, including a personal statement, three letters of recommendation and official transcripts from all post-secondary schools attended. A minimum of 200 hours of documented work and/or volunteer experience in human services. For applicants with a GPA below 3.0, the School may consider an applicant for admission if they demonstrate outstanding performance in other areas of the application.
Concentration: Community, Policy, and Political Social Action (CPPSA)
Description:
The Master of Social Work (MSW) program prepares graduates for advanced social work practice. The School of Social Welfare offers two ways to complete your MSW degree: a full-time, two-year, 60-credit program or a part-time, three-year, 60-credit program. For applicants with a baccalaureate degree in social work (BSW) from a CSWE-accredited program, we also offer an Advanced Standing program.

In the specialized year of study, students will choose one of three specializations, which will provide them with a concentration of advanced practice skills and knowledge:

- Families, Youth and Transition to Adulthood (FYT)
- Integrated Health: Physical, Psychological and Social Well-being (IH)
- Community, Policy, and Political Social Action (CPPSA)

Community, Policy, and Political Social Action (CPPSA) prepares students for practice in a variety of macro settings including community organizing, legislative advocacy and policy analysis. The goal of this specialization is to create social change that will promote social and economic justice for marginalized and oppressed populations.
Accredidation: The School of Social Welfare's MSW program is accredited by the Council on Social Work Education (CSWE).

ProgramName: Concentration in Cosmetics and Consumer Goods (Product Design MS)
EnglishScore: All graduate applicants are required to demonstrate English proficiency. Accepted tests and minimum scores are: TOEFL iBT (90), IELTS (6.5), Duolingo English Test (115), or PTE Academic (61).
Requirements: A complete application includes: the online application form, a non-refundable application fee, unofficial transcripts from each college or university attended, three letters of recommendation submitted via the electronic recommendation system, a Personal Statement/Statement of Purpose, and English Proficiency Scores (e.g., TOEFL, IELTS) for applicants whose native language is not English. Note: Graduate Record Examination (GRE) general test scores are NOT required for applicants seeking admission for Fall 2024 and Spring 2025.
Department: College of Engineering and Applied Sciences
Concentration: Cosmetics and Consumer Goods (Product Design MS)
Description: This concentration focuses on the design, development, and manufacturing of consumer goods, with a particular emphasis on cosmetics and personal care products. Students will gain an understanding of the entire product lifecycle, from concept to market, including materials science, formulation, packaging, manufacturing, and regulatory compliance. The curriculum combines principles of mechanical engineering with chemistry, materials science, and business to prepare students for careers in the rapidly growing consumer goods industry. The program will provide students with the skills and knowledge to innovate and lead in the development of new products that are safe, effective, and sustainable.

ProgramName: Concentration in Educational Technology (Technological Systems Management MS)
EnglishScore: For international applicants, proof of English proficiency is required. Accepted tests include TOEFL, IELTS, Duolingo, and PTE. The Graduate School requires a minimum TOEFL iBT score of 80, a minimum overall IELTS score of 6.5, a minimum Duolingo score of 105, or a minimum PTE Academic score of 53. Successful completion of the ELS Level 112 Intensive Program also satisfies this requirement.
Requirements: Graduate School Application; Application Fee; Resume or C.V.; Personal Statement; Three Letters of Recommendation; Transcripts; GRE General: Not required for Fall 2024; TOEFL/IELTS: See Graduate School Requirements; Prerequisites: Bachelor's degree in engineering, the natural sciences, mathematics, computer science or management from an accredited institution. Applicants must have a minimum GPA of 3.0 overall in their undergraduate work.
Department: College of Engineering and Applied Sciences
Description: The Educational Technology concentration focuses on understanding the design, development, use, and evaluation of instructional technology in various educational settings. It covers a broad range of topics, including learning theories and instructional design; audio and visual media design and production; web-based course development; multimedia project management; and technology integration in the classroom. This concentration prepares students to be leaders in educational organizations, instructional designers in public or corporate education, curriculum developers, instructional technologists, and technology coordinators. The four-course concentration is offered entirely online.

EnglishScore: Applicants whose native language is not English must demonstrate English proficiency. This can be done by submitting scores from the Test of English as a Foreign Language (TOEFL), the International English Language Testing System (IELTS), Duolingo English Test, or PTE Academic.
