ProgramName: Concentration in Pharmaceutical and Biopharmaceutical (Product Design MS)
EnglishScore: For international applicants, proficiency in English must be demonstrated by submitting scores from one of the following exams: TOEFL iBT (minimum 80), IELTS (minimum 6.5 overall with no subsection below 6), Duolingo (minimum 105), or PTE Academic (minimum 53).
Requirements: To be admitted to the MS degree program, a student must hold a bachelor’s degree in chemical engineering or a related engineering or science field from a college or university of recognized standing. A minimum GPA of 3.0 on a 4.0 scale is required. Students from non-chemical engineering backgrounds may be required to take up to two undergraduate-level courses in addition to the normal graduate course requirements.
Department: College of Engineering and Applied Sciences
Description: This 30 credit Master's of Science concentration in Pharmaceutical and Biopharmaceutical Product Design is a one-year program that prepares students for employment or advanced degrees in the pharmaceutical and biopharmaceutical fields. The program is designed to integrate advanced study in pharmaceutical product development, biopharmaceutical product development, and related areas. The program curriculum includes coursework in drug discovery, drug delivery, pharmacokinetics, and biopharmaceutical product development, as well as hands-on laboratory research experiences with world-renowned faculty members. Graduates will be equipped to become leaders in the field of industrial pharmaceutics and biopharmaceutics, which are rapidly expanding in the US and abroad. Students may select an M.S. with thesis or M.S. without thesis.

ProgramName: Concentration in Resilience and Sustainability (Technological Systems Management MS)
EnglishScore: Stony Brook University requires all international students to demonstrate English proficiency by submitting scores from an approved English proficiency exam. Approved exams and minimum scores include: TOEFL iBT: 80, IELTS: 6.5 overall band score with no band score below 6.0, Duolingo: 105, PTE Academic: 53. The paper-based TOEFL exam (TOEFL pbt) is no longer offered, but scores of 550 or higher are accepted if the exam was taken within the past two years.
Requirements: Applicants must have a bachelor’s degree in engineering, science, management, or one of the social sciences. Students with other backgrounds may be admitted if their record shows evidence of the potential for success in a technology-based graduate program. All applicants must have at least one semester of college-level calculus with a grade of B or better. Applicants must have a minimum GPA of 3.0.
Department: College of Engineering and Applied Sciences
Description: The Master of Science in Technological Systems Management (M.S.-T.S.M.) is a 30-credit degree program designed for those who have a bachelor’s degree in engineering, science, management, or the liberal arts. The degree provides an interdisciplinary education to a diverse student body of graduate students that will prepare them for careers in industry, government, or academia. In this concentration, students prepare for leadership roles in a variety of industries to ensure resilient systems. Courses focus on the application of systems engineering tools, energy and environmental systems, disaster management, water resources management, and more. This is a STEM designated program.

ProgramName: Concentration in Social Work in Higher Education: Student-Community Development (MSW)
EnglishScore: For international applicants, a minimum TOEFL score of 90 for the Internet-based test is required.
Requirements:
The School of Social Welfare seeks to admit individuals with a strong academic background who have demonstrated a commitment to the goals of social work through their paid and/or volunteer work experience. The following are the minimum requirements for admission to the MSW program:

- A bachelor’s degree from an accredited U.S. college or university, or the equivalent from a college or university in another country.
- A minimum grade point average of 3.0 on a 4.0 scale.
- The completion of at least 21 credits in the liberal arts and sciences, including coursework from at least three of the four following areas: humanities, social sciences, biological sciences, physical sciences, or mathematics.

In addition to meeting the above requirements, the following materials must be submitted as part of the online application to the Graduate School:

- An essay (personal statement) describing the basis of your interest in social work and your career goals.
- A résumé that highlights paid and volunteer work experience, as well as any published or presented scholarly work.
- Three letters of reference from former professors and/or employers or supervisors who can speak to your academic and professional abilities.
- Official transcripts of all prior college or university coursework.
Description: The School of Social Welfare offers a 60-credit course of study leading to the Master of Social Work (MSW) degree. The MSW program prepares students for advanced social work practice in one of two specializations: Community, Policy, and Political Social Action (CPPA) or Families, Youth, and Transition to Adulthood (FYTA). The curriculum is designed to provide students with a strong foundation in the core principles of social work, including social justice, human rights, and evidence-informed practice. Students will develop the knowledge, values, and skills necessary to work effectively with individuals, families, groups, organizations, and communities.
Accredidation: The Master of Social Work program is fully accredited by the Council on Social Work Education (CSWE).

ProgramName: Concentration in Technology Management (Technological Systems Management MS)
EnglishScore: Stony Brook University requires all international students who are not native speakers of English to demonstrate their English proficiency through an approved test. The following tests and minimum scores are accepted: TOEFL iBT (80), IELTS (6.5 overall, no subsection below 6), Duolingo English Test (105), or PTE Academic (53).
Requirements: Prerequisites: A bachelor's degree in engineering, natural sciences, or a quantitative social science with a minimum GPA of 3.0. Students with degrees in other fields who have substantial work experience may also be admitted. For international applicants, a TOEFL score of at least 85 is required for the MS program. Required Application Materials: Graduate School Application, Application fee, Resume or CV, Personal Statement, Transcripts, Three letters of recommendation, GRE General: Recommended, not required.
Department: College of Engineering and Applied Sciences
Description: The M.S. degree in Technological Systems Management offers two options that are designed to meet the needs of both traditional students and professional managers who are working in a technological environment. The Technology Management option provides broad-based management education for those who have a technological background. The Global Technology Management option provides management education in a global context. The M.S. degree is earned by completing 30 credits of coursework as follows: Core Courses (18 credits) All students in the program must take the following six courses: EST 581 - Heuristics & Quantitative Decision-Making EST 582 - Introduction to Systems Concepts EST 562 - Strategic Marketing/Technology & Innovation EST 531 - Technology Assessment OR EST 644 - Management of Innovation EST 569 - Technology in the Workplace OR EST 580 - Advanced Technology Assessment EST 534 - Management of Engineered Systems OR EST 535 - Business and Managerial Economics. Option 1: Technology Management (12 credits) Four electives selected with the advice and consent of the graduate program director. Courses are selected from EST, business, management, public policy, or any of the engineering disciplines.

ProgramName: Executive MBA in Health Management and Policy
Requirements: Admission to the Executive MBA in Health Management and Policy is highly competitive. Successful candidates will possess a bachelor’s degree from an accredited institution, at least 5 years of professional work experience, with a minimum of 2 years in a management or leadership role, and demonstrated leadership potential and a commitment to a career in healthcare. Application requirements include: Application and Fee; Official transcripts from all colleges and universities attended; A current resume detailing your professional experience, education, and skills; Two letters of recommendation from professional or academic references; A personal statement (500-750 words) that addresses your career goals, why you are interested in the Executive MBA in Health Management and Policy, and what you will contribute to the program. GMAT or GRE scores are not required for applicants with 7+ years of significant managerial experience. For all other applicants, scores are optional but may strengthen your application. Waivers may be considered on a case-by-case basis. An interview with the admissions committee may be required.
Description: The Executive Master of Business Administration in Health Management and Policy is designed for mid-career professionals working in a variety of healthcare settings, such as hospitals, private practices, clinics, and long-term care facilities. The program will equip them with the business skills and knowledge needed to expertly navigate our increasingly complex healthcare industry. The healthcare industry is growing faster than any other sector of the U.S. economy, with more than 2.6 million new jobs expected by 2030, according to the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics. The healthcare industry is also more competitive than ever, with more organizations competing for patients. To be successful, healthcare providers need to focus on delivering high-quality care while also managing their finances and operations effectively. The Executive MBA in Health Management and Policy will provide students with the business skills and knowledge needed to manage in healthcare. This program is designed for working professionals who aspire to or currently hold leadership positions in healthcare. The program is ideal for physicians, nurses, dentists, and other clinical and non-clinical professionals working in a variety of healthcare settings.
Accredidation: The College of Business at Stony Brook is accredited by AACSB International-the Association to Advance Collegiate Schools of Business, the premier accrediting agency for business schools.
ScholarshipType: Dean's Choice Scholarship, Achievement in Business Scholarship, Diversity in Business Scholarship, Women in Business Scholarship, Healthcare Management Scholarship, Not-for-Profit Scholarship, GMAT/GRE Waiver Scholarship, Executive Network Scholarship

ProgramName: Executive PhD in Biochemistry and Molecular Biology Online
EnglishScore: Applicants for whom English is not their native language must demonstrate English proficiency. Minimum scores for accepted tests are: TOEFL iBT 85, IELTS 6.5, Duolingo 105, PTE Academic 59, or completion of ELS Level 112.
Requirements: Applications must include the following: The Graduate School application. A Personal Statement describing your motivation for pursuing a PhD in Biochemistry and Molecular Biology at Stony Brook, your previous research experience, and your future research interests. Three letters of recommendation from faculty who know you and your academic and research abilities. A curriculum vitae (CV). Transcripts from all undergraduate and graduate institutions attended. The General GRE is NOT required for admission to our graduate program. The TOEFL exam is required for international students from countries in which English is not the official language.

EnglishScore: All international students must take the TOEFL examination. A minimum score of 550 (paper-based), 213 (computer-based), or 80 (Internet-based) is required for admission. Our institution code is 2548. Please visit the Graduate School's website for international students for more information. Applicants may also submit an IELTS score. The minimum acceptable score is 6.5, with no subsection score below 6.
Requirements:
To be considered for admission, applicants must have:
- A master's degree in any subject from an accredited institution.
- An undergraduate grade point average of 3.00 or higher.
- A graduate grade point average of 3.00 or higher.
- Access to the Internet and an active email account.
In addition, applicants must submit:
- A State University of New York (SUNY) application.
- A non-refundable application fee.
- A personal statement that details the reasons for pursuing this certificate.
- Official transcripts from all colleges and universities attended.
- Two letters of recommendation.
Concentration: ['Student Affairs Administration', 'Higher Education Administration and Leadership']
Description: The Advanced Graduate Certificate in Higher Education Administration is a post-master's program that prepares students for leadership positions in a wide variety of higher education settings, including administration, management, and student affairs. The program is specifically designed to provide a broad understanding of the increasingly complex administrative issues confronting colleges and universities. It is most appropriate for individuals who have already earned a master’s degree and who are currently employed, or who wish to be employed, in a higher education setting. The program offers two tracks: Student Affairs Administration and Higher Education Administration and Leadership. Students will select a track based on their interests and career goals.

EnglishScore: All graduate applicants whose native language is not English are required to demonstrate proficiency. Accepted tests and minimum scores are: TOEFL iBT - 80; IELTS - 6.5 overall with no subsection below 6; Duolingo English Test - 105; PTE Academic - 53.
Requirements:
In addition to the School of Professional Development's admission requirements, applicants to this program must have:

- A bachelor's degree.
- A minimum cumulative grade point average of 3.00.
- Two letters of recommendation.
- A current résumé.
- A personal statement.
Description: The Master of Arts in Higher Education Administration (HEA) program is designed for current and aspiring administrators and leaders who want to advance their careers in a variety of postsecondary institutional settings, including colleges and universities, community colleges, government agencies, and associations. The program provides students with the knowledge, skills, and experiences necessary to become successful administrators and leaders in today’s colleges and universities.
ScholarshipType: SPD Scholarships, SPD Grants, Federal and State Aid, Veterans Benefits

EnglishScore: All applicants whose native language is not English are required to demonstrate English proficiency by taking the Test of English as a Foreign Language (TOEFL) or the International English Language Testing System (IELTS) exam. We also accept Duolingo English Test.
Requirements: Bachelor's degree; Minimum cumulative grade point average of 3.0; An official transcript from each college or university attended; Two letters of recommendation; A personal statement; A current résumé; A non-refundable $100 application fee. Note: GREs are not required.
Description: The Advanced Graduate Certificate (AGC) in Human Resource Management is designed for individuals who have already earned a baccalaureate degree and wish to complete a graduate-level certificate program in human resource management. This certificate is ideal for those who are currently working in or who are planning to enter the field of human resources. The program's core curriculum gives students a solid foundation in the concepts, principles, and practices of human resource management. The curriculum is aligned with the Society for Human Resource Management (SHRM) HR Curriculum Guidebook and Templates. Students in the program may take the SHRM-CP exam once they have 500 hours of relevant work experience.

EnglishScore: All international students must demonstrate English proficiency. This can be done by submitting scores from the Test of English as a Foreign Language (TOEFL) iBT (or an equivalent English proficiency exam), the International English Language Testing System (IELTS), Duolingo or PTE Academic. Minimum scores are an 85 on the TOEFL iBT, a 6.5 on the IELTS (with no subsection below 6), a 105 on Duolingo, or a 58 on the PTE Academic.
Requirements:
A bachelor's degree with a minimum cumulative grade point average of 3.0 from an accredited institution. Applicants who do not meet this requirement may be admitted on a conditional basis. Please see the policy on conditional admission in the SPD Bulletin.
A completed application for graduate studies.
Two letters of recommendation.
A current résumé.
A statement of purpose.
Official transcripts from all colleges and universities attended.
GRE is not required.
Description: The Master of Science in Human Resource Management (HRM) provides students with a comprehensive understanding of human resource management strategies that create a competitive advantage for any organization. Developed with guidelines from the leading professional HR association, the Society for Human Resource Management (SHRM), the curriculum covers core HRM competencies such as people, the organization, the workplace, and strategy. Courses are taught by HR professionals who have both academic qualifications and practical business experience. Students learn practical and theoretical concepts they can apply immediately to their current or future careers. The program is offered completely online, making it ideal for busy professionals and those who want the flexibility of an online learning environment.

EnglishScore: Applicants whose native or primary language is not English must take an English proficiency exam. The following are accepted: TOEFL, IELTS, and Duolingo.
Requirements:
To be admitted to the Master of Arts in Liberal Studies, students must have:

A bachelor's degree with a B average (3.0 on a 4.0 scale), or its equivalent from an accredited college or university.
One official copy of all transcripts from each college or university attended. Unofficial transcripts are accepted for initial review of your application.
A personal statement that addresses the following: (1) what you hope to achieve by pursuing graduate study in liberal studies and (2) how your academic and/or professional background has prepared you for this program.
Two letters of recommendation.
A non-refundable $100 application fee, paid online via credit card.
A current resume.
A writing sample, such as a paper submitted for an undergraduate course.
Graduate Record Examination (GRE) scores are not required.
Concentration: Coaching, Human Resource Management, Health and Wellness Management
Description: The Master of Arts in Liberal Studies (MALS) is an interdisciplinary graduate degree program that allows students to draw upon the rich and diverse graduate course offerings at Stony Brook University to create a master’s degree program that best suits their academic and professional goals. This 30-credit master’s degree allows students to fashion their graduate program in two ways. Students may choose a traditional approach to Liberal Studies and choose graduate courses from across the academic disciplines that reflect their own personal and intellectual interests. Or, students may choose a more professionally focused approach and work with the graduate program director to build a program of study using the graduate course offerings available in SPD as well as those from other graduate programs to build the graduate degree that suits their needs.

EnglishScore: All international students who are not native English speakers must demonstrate English proficiency. The Graduate School accepts the TOEFL, IELTS, Duolingo, and PTE Academic tests. The minimum acceptable TOEFL iBT score for admission is 80. The minimum acceptable overall IELTS score is 6.5, with no subsection score below 6. The minimum acceptable Duolingo score is 105. The minimum acceptable PTE Academic score is 53.
Requirements:
Online application
Application fee
Transcripts from all colleges and universities attended
Minimum undergraduate GPA of 3.0
Three letters of recommendation
Personal statement
Resume or CV
GRE General Test is not required.
TOEFL or IELTS is required for applicants whose native language is not English.
Department: College of Engineering and Applied Sciences
Description: The Master of Science in Management of Technology (MS/MOT) is a 30-credit program that prepares students for leadership positions by providing the expertise to manage technological and organizational change, and to develop and implement complex business strategies in today’s demanding corporate environment. The program is designed for students with bachelor's degrees in engineering, science, or technology who are already employed or plan to seek employment in a technology-based company.

EnglishScore: International students whose native language is not English are required to take an English proficiency exam. The university accepts TOEFL (minimum 80 for MS), IELTS (minimum 6.5 overall, no subsection below 6), Duolingo (minimum 105 for MS), and PTE Academic (minimum 53 for MS).
Requirements: The following application materials are required: the Graduate School Online Application and application fee; a Personal Statement (a concise one- to two-page statement explaining your academic purpose for graduate study and why you wish to pursue this at Stony Brook’s School of Marine and Atmospheric Sciences); a Resume or Curriculum Vitae; three letters of recommendation; official transcripts from all colleges and universities attended; and official TOEFL or IELTS scores for international students. Note: SoMAS has dropped the GRE requirement for applications for the 2024 admissions cycle.
Department: School of Marine and Atmospheric Sciences
Description: The Master of Science program in Marine Biology and Ecology is a thesis-based program designed to train students for professional positions as marine biologists or ecologists, or to prepare students for a more advanced degree in the field. The program provides students with a broad knowledge of modern marine biology and ecology, along with the research tools necessary to carry out independent study. Students complete at least 30 graduate credits of coursework, research and seminars, and a written thesis. The thesis research must be a significant piece of original work, which should be suitable for publication in a peer-reviewed journal. Coursework is determined by the student and the student’s advisory committee, depending on the student’s background and research interests.

Requirements: Formal application to the Marine Biology and Ecology track of the Marine and Atmospheric Science Ph.D. program is made through the Graduate School. Applicants should indicate the Marine Biology and Ecology Track on the application form. All applicants must meet the following minimum requirements for admission to the Marine Biology and Ecology program: 1. Bachelor’s degree from an accredited university in one of the natural sciences (e.g. biology, ecology, chemistry, physics, geology) or engineering. 2. One year of biology with lab, one year of inorganic chemistry with lab, and one semester each of organic chemistry, physics and calculus. Recommended courses include statistics, physical chemistry and additional math courses. 3. A minimum undergraduate GPA of 3.0/4.0. 4. A minimum GPA of 3.0 in all science and math courses. 5. Submission of the GRE General Test is no longer required and scores will not be considered during the application review. 6. Three letters of recommendation. 7. A Statement of Purpose outlining the applicant’s research interests and career goals and how they relate to SoMAS faculty. 8. For international students whose native language is not English, a minimum TOEFL iBT score of 90.
Department: School of Marine and Atmospheric Sciences
Description: The School of Marine and Atmospheric Sciences (SoMAS) offers a doctoral program in Marine Biology and Ecology (MBE). It is a flexible program designed for students with research interests in the biology and ecology of marine organisms. The program has particular strengths in crustacean biology, diseases of marine organisms, marine conservation, biological oceanography, and larval, physiological, population, and ecosystem ecology of a wide variety of marine organisms. Our faculty use a diversity of research approaches, including behavioral, cellular, developmental, ecological, evolutionary, genetic, molecular and physiological techniques, and apply these approaches to a variety of organisms, from phytoplankton to whales. All doctoral students are fully supported by either teaching or research assistantships and are provided tuition scholarships. Students in good standing will be supported for five years. Students may affiliate with research groups on either the main campus of Stony Brook or at the Stony Brook-Southampton campus. Prospective students should contact one or more faculty members with whom they share research interests. Admission decisions are based upon a student’s academic record (GPA, GRE scores), letters of recommendation, statement of purpose, and an interview conducted in person, by telephone or by video conferencing. Additional information can be found at the SoMAS website (www.somas.stonybrook.edu), and in the Graduate Student Handbook.

EnglishScore: International applicants whose native language is not English are required to take the TOEFL or IELTS exam. The MCP Program requires a minimum TOEFL IBT score of 85 or an overall IELTS score of 6.5 with no subsection below 6.
Requirements: The following materials are required to be submitted with the online Graduate School application: A 1-2 page statement detailing your interest in the program and career goals; Transcripts from all undergraduate and graduate institutions attended; Three letters of recommendation from academic or professional references; Resume/CV.
Department: School of Marine and Atmospheric Sciences
Description: The Master of Professional Studies in Marine Conservation and Policy (MPS-MCP) is a graduate-level degree offered through the School of Marine and Atmospheric Sciences (SoMAS) at Stony Brook University. The program is designed to be completed in one calendar year, and is focused on practical application of knowledge to solving problems in the marine environment. The curriculum is comprised of a set of core courses and a flexible elective curriculum that students choose from based on their interests. The MPS-MCP program culminates in a capstone project and internship that provides students with on-the-ground experience working in the marine conservation and policy field. Students will acquire the skills to: evaluate of the efficacy of current marine conservation and management initiatives; understand the underlying science that informs these initiatives; effectively communicate this science to the public and to policy-makers.

EnglishScore: All international students must demonstrate English proficiency. Accepted tests and minimum scores include: TOEFL iBT (80), TOEFL PBT (550), IELTS (6.5 overall with no subsection below 6), Duolingo English Test (105), PTE Academic (53), or completion of ELS Level 112.
Requirements:
Admission to the MES-MPS degree is based on a holistic review of each applicant’s file. Competitive applicants will typically have completed an undergraduate degree in the natural sciences, social sciences or humanities with an overall GPA of 3.0 or better and have some work or volunteer experience in a related field. Students seeking admission must fulfill all admission requirements of the Graduate School. Completed applications must be submitted by the deadlines provided by the Graduate School and consist of the following:

An online application to the Graduate School
Official transcripts of all college/university coursework
A personal statement
Three letters of recommendation
A resume or CV
The GRE is not required for admission to this program.
Department: School of Marine and Atmospheric Sciences
Description: The Master of Professional Studies (MPS) in Marine Ecosystems and Society is a 12-month, 30-credit graduate degree offered through the School of Marine and Atmospheric Sciences (SoMAS) at Stony Brook University. This program provides students with advanced training in the theory and practice of marine science, focusing on the interdisciplinary nature of coastal and marine issues and the need to include socioeconomic and political as well as scientific and technical considerations in environmental management. The curriculum is intended to be interdisciplinary, but can be tailored to fit the interests of each student, with potential focus on marine conservation, fisheries management, marine policy and law, or other areas within marine science. Graduates will be prepared for positions in government, not-for-profit conservation organizations and environmental consulting.

EnglishScore: Applicants whose native language is not English must demonstrate English proficiency. The Graduate School accepts TOEFL iBT (minimum score of 85), IELTS (minimum overall band score of 6.5, with no band score below 6), Duolingo (minimum score of 115), or PTE Academic (minimum score of 58).
Requirements: The Graduate School requires a minimum undergraduate GPA of 3.0 on a 4.0 scale. The following application materials must be submitted online: Online application and application fee; Transcripts from each university or college attended. Unofficial transcripts are accepted at the time of application. Official transcripts will be required if an offer of admission is accepted; Three letters of recommendation; A statement of purpose; A resume/CV; The Department of Geosciences no longer requires the GRE general test for admission to the graduate program.
Description: The Department of Geosciences offers a Master of Science (M.S.) degree program with concentrations in geochemistry, hydrogeology, petrology, geophysics, marine geology, surficial processes, sedimentary geology, and paleontology. Students are provided a broad background in the geosciences with an emphasis on research in one of the specialty areas. The M.S. degree requires the completion of 30 graduate credits and a research thesis. There are no specific courses that are required by the department, which allows a student, in consultation with a faculty advisor, to design a program of study that is tailored to individual needs. Each student must take at least one seminar course (GEO 599). Please consult the Graduate Bulletin for detailed course information.

EnglishScore: All international students must demonstrate English proficiency. This can be done by submitting official scores from one of the following exams: TOEFL, IELTS, Duolingo English Test, or PTE Academic.
Requirements:
Online Application
Application Fee
Personal Statement
Three letters of recommendation
Transcripts from all colleges and universities attended
GRE test scores (optional for domestic applicants)
TOEFL/IELTS scores (for international applicants)
Résumé or CV
Department: School of Marine and Atmospheric Sciences
Description: The Marine Geosciences track is a 30-credit Master of Professional Studies degree that focuses on coastal processes, sediment transport, and related topics. Course topics may include coastal geology, sediment transport, marine pollution, geological oceanography, coastal zone management, and statistics. An internship and a final project are required for this track. Graduates are prepared for a variety of jobs in government and the private sector, as well as for admission to a doctoral program. Admission is for the Fall semester only and full time study is required.

EnglishScore: International applicants whose native language is not English are generally required to take the TOEFL or IELTS exam. Minimum scores are set by the Graduate School. For doctoral programs, the minimum acceptable score for the TOEFL iBT is 90, for IELTS is 6.5 (with no subsection score below 6), for Duolingo is 115, and for PTE is 61. Successful completion of Level 112 of the English Language Services (ELS) Program is also accepted.
Requirements: The School of Marine and Atmospheric Sciences (SoMAS) admits students with a wide range of academic backgrounds, including biology, chemistry, geology, physics, mathematics, engineering, and meteorology. SoMAS accepts students with a B.S. degree into both the M.S. and Ph.D. programs. Students can also be admitted with an M.S. degree into the Ph.D. program. The admissions committee evaluates applicants based on their entire record, including: ...academic preparation and performance as demonstrated through course work, GPA and GRE scores (if submitted), personal statements of purpose, and letters of recommendation. We place particular emphasis on previous research experience. Required Application Materials include: Stony Brook University Graduate School Application, Application Fee, Three Letters of Recommendation, One Official Transcript from each university you have attended, Statement of Purpose, and a Curriculum Vitae (CV) / Resume. The Graduate Record Examination (GRE) general test is no longer required for admission to the SoMAS graduate program.
Department: School of Marine and Atmospheric Sciences
Description: The Ph.D. in Marine Geosciences is administered jointly by SoMAS and the Department of Geosciences. Please visit the Department of Geosciences Graduate Programs website for program details and admissions requirements.

EnglishScore: TOEFL scores are required for international students for whom English is not their native language.
Requirements: Applicants must have a bachelor's degree in marine biology, biology, animal science, or a related field with a GPA of 3.0 or higher. Prerequisites: a C or better in introductory biology, introductory chemistry, introductory physics, and calculus.
Department: School of Marine and Atmospheric Sciences
Description: The Master of Professional Science in Marine Mammal Science (MMS) is a 12-month, 30-credit, non-thesis degree program offered by the School of Marine and Atmospheric Sciences (SoMAS) at Stony Brook University Southampton. The program provides students with a strong academic background in the science of marine mammalogy, while also giving them the professional skills necessary to thrive in the job market. Students will learn directly from experts that work with marine mammals in a variety of settings (e.g. government, academia, non-profit, etc.) and be exposed to the most up-to-date technologies and techniques used to study these fascinating animals. The MMS program aims to train the next generation of managers, technicians, and policy makers in the marine mammal science field. Graduates from this program will have a broad, working knowledge of the marine mammal science field and be better prepared for careers working with marine mammals in a variety of capacities (e.g. government agencies, non-governmental organizations (NGOs), non-profits, private sector, etc).

EnglishScore: All graduate applicants whose native language is not English must demonstrate English proficiency. The University accepts scores from the TOEFL, IELTS, Duolingo, and PTE Academic tests.
Requirements: Admission to the graduate program in Materials Science and Engineering requires a bachelor's degree in an engineering discipline or in the physical sciences. A minimum undergraduate GPA of 3.0 is required, along with three letters of recommendation. The GRE General Test is waived for the MS program.
Department: College of Engineering and Applied Sciences
Concentration: ['Metals and Ceramics', 'Polymers and Soft Materials', 'Computational Materials Science', 'Materials for Energy and the Environment']
Description: The Master of Science degree program in Materials Science and Engineering is designed to provide students advanced training in a broad range of topics in materials science and engineering. This is primarily a course-based degree, designed to give students a strong technical background that is valued by industrial employers. The MS degree also gives students an excellent background to pursue doctoral studies. The program is flexible and may be tailored to a student’s career goals with both a thesis and non-thesis option. Our program provides specialization in four major areas of materials science and engineering: metals and ceramics, polymers and soft materials, computational materials science, and materials for energy and the environment. Graduates of the program are well prepared for professional employment in a wide range of industries including aerospace, biomedical, chemical, electronic, and semiconductor industries or for further graduate study.

EnglishScore: For international applicants, the minimum TOEFL iBT score is 80, the minimum IELTS (Academic) overall score is 6.5 with no subsection below 6, the minimum Duolingo score is 105, and the minimum PTE Academic score is 53.
Requirements: Applicants must hold a bachelor’s degree from an accredited college or university. They should have a strong background in mathematics, including multivariable calculus, linear algebra and probability theory, and some computer programming experience. Admission is based on a student’s prior academic performance, GRE scores, letters of recommendation, and the personal statement. Required documents include the Graduate School application, three letters of recommendation, transcripts of all college/university work, a personal statement, and GRE scores. A résumé is strongly recommended.
Department: College of Engineering and Applied Sciences
Description: The Department of Applied Mathematics and Statistics offers a program of graduate study leading to the Master of Science in Quantitative Finance. This program is designed for students with strong mathematical backgrounds who wish to pursue careers in the quantitative areas of the financial industry. The program is designated as STEM. The M.S. in Quantitative Finance has a prescribed curriculum consisting of five required courses from the Department of Applied Mathematics and Statistics, two required courses from the Department of Economics, and an additional three electives to be chosen from a pre-approved list of courses from the Departments of Applied Mathematics and Statistics, Computer Science, and Economics. Each student must also register for the one-credit seminar on quantitative finance for two semesters. A central feature of the program is a required summer internship with a financial institution that provides the student with hands-on experience of working in the financial industry. Upon completion of the required coursework and internship, the degree is awarded. No thesis is required. A total of 36 graduate credits is required for the M.S. in Quantitative Finance.

EnglishScore: All graduate applicants whose native language is not English must demonstrate English proficiency. This requirement can be satisfied by submitting scores from TOEFL iBT, IELTS, PTE Academic, or the Duolingo English Test. The Graduate School's minimum score for master's programs is 80 on the TOEFL iBT, 6.5 overall on the IELTS (with no subsection below 6), 53 on the PTE, and 105 on the Duolingo English Test.
Requirements:
Application for admission should be made through the Graduate School online application system. Besides the materials requested by the Graduate School, the applicant should submit the following:
1. A personal statement. This statement should explain the applicant’s interest in mathematics and describe his/her background in mathematics beyond the minimum requirements for admission. The statement can also be used to explain any special circumstances.
2. Three letters of recommendation. The letters should be written by mathematics professors who are familiar with the applicant’s abilities and know the applicant well. At least two letters should be from professors at the institution from which the applicant will receive his/her most recent degree. The letters should specifically address the applicant’s suitability for graduate study in mathematics.
3. The General GRE is not required. However, we strongly recommend that the applicant take the general GRE test and have the score reported. A high score in the quantitative part is an asset for the application.
4. The GRE Mathematics Subject test is not required. However, we recommend that applicants take this test, and a high score is a definite asset for the application.
5. TOEFL scores for international applicants.
Description: The Professional Option of the MA degree is intended for students who wish to pursue a career in industry. It includes courses in statistics, numerical computing, and mathematical finance, as well as an internship. The requirements for this option can typically be completed in three semesters.

Requirements: For admission to graduate study in the Mathematics Department, a student must have a bachelor's degree in mathematics or a related field from an accredited college or university. An applicant's record must indicate a superior grasp of undergraduate mathematics. There is no specific requirement on credit hours but a typical applicant has completed a full year of analysis and abstract algebra with distinction. Students who do not meet these requirements are advised to enroll as non-matriculated students to take any necessary undergraduate courses.

Description: The Mathematics Department offers a master's degree program in mathematics leading to the M.S. degree. The primary purpose of this program is to give students a professional education in mathematics. The M.S. program is designed for students who have a bachelor's degree in mathematics or the equivalent and who wish to obtain further training in mathematics. It is suitable as a terminal degree for those who intend to seek employment in industry or government, or at the junior college level, and it is also excellent preparation for a Ph.D. program in mathematics or a related field. There are four tracks to the M.S. degree in mathematics: the Mathematics Track, the Quantitative Finance Track, the Computational and Applied Mathematics Track, and the Mathematics Education Track. There is also an accelerated Bachelors/Masters program for Stony Brook undergraduates who wish to complete both a bachelors degree in mathematics and the M.S. degree in five years.

For the Duolingo English test, the minimum acceptable score is 115.
Requirements: Admission to the Ph.D. program is based primarily on the applicant's undergraduate record in mathematics, letters of recommendation, and scores on the Graduate Record Examinations (GRE). At least six semesters of undergraduate mathematics with grades of A or B are required, including courses in advanced calculus or real analysis, abstract algebra, and linear algebra. Complex analysis and topology are also very desirable.

Description: The Department of Mathematics at Stony Brook is a center for research and graduate education in mathematics. The department's particular strengths are in geometry, topology, and their relation to mathematical physics. Research specializations are available in algebra, algebraic geometry, analysis, complex analysis, differential geometry, dynamical systems, mathematical physics, and topology. Students may also do research in quantitative finance or in statistics through the Department of Applied Mathematics and Statistics. Members of the department have been honored with many prizes and awards, and several hold endowed chairs. The department is closely associated with the Simons Center for Geometry and Physics.

Requirements:

A Bachelor's degree in mechanical engineering, or a closely related field, from a nationally accredited institution.
A minimum undergraduate grade point average (GPA) of 3.0 on a 4.0 scale.

Description: The Department of Mechanical Engineering offers a comprehensive program of graduate study and research leading to the MS and PhD degrees in Mechanical Engineering. The Master of Science (MS) program in Mechanical Engineering provides students with a high-quality and broad-based graduate education that will prepare them for careers in industry, government, or academia. Students can choose between a thesis option and a non-thesis option. The MS program with thesis is recommended for students who are interested in research-oriented careers in industry, government labs or plan to pursue a PhD degree. The MS program without thesis is recommended for students who are not planning to pursue a research career.

EnglishScore: International applicants whose native language is not English are required to take the Test of English as a Foreign Language (TOEFL). The minimum acceptable score is 550 for the paper based test and 85 (for PhD) for the internet-based test (iBT).
Requirements: All applicants must submit an online application to the Graduate School. Requirements include: An online application, application fee, transcripts from all undergraduate and graduate institutions attended, three letters of recommendation, a statement of purpose, Graduate Record Examination (GRE) scores, and TOEFL or IELTS scores for international applicants whose native language is not English. A resume is required. Successful applicants will generally have an undergraduate grade point average of at least 3.2 on a 4.0 scale, a combined verbal and quantitative GRE score of at least 310, and an analytical GRE writing score of at least 3.5. Students entering with a Bachelor's degree from a U.S. university are expected to have an ABET accredited degree. For the PhD program, entering students are normally expected to have a M.S. degree in Mechanical Engineering or a closely related field. Highly qualified students with a B.S. degree and exceptional research potential can be admitted directly into the Ph.D. program.
Department: College of Engineering and Applied Sciences
Concentration: Solid Mechanics and Design, Thermal-Fluid Sciences, Mechatronics and Robotics, Materials Science, Energy and Environment, Manufacturing and Industrial Engineering
Description: The graduate programs in Mechanical Engineering provide the education for students to have a successful career in industry, research or academia. We offer both M.S. and Ph.D. degrees. For both degrees, students may choose to conduct research for their thesis (M.S.) or dissertation (Ph.D.). Students who prefer to focus on coursework may choose the non-thesis M.S. degree option. The department has 33 faculty members whose expertise covers a wide range of research areas in mechanical engineering and related disciplines. Research in the department is concentrated in the following areas: Solid Mechanics and Design, Thermal-Fluid Sciences, Mechatronics and Robotics, Materials Science, Energy and Environment, Manufacturing and Industrial Engineering. The research areas described above are the areas in which a student may specialize. The Department of Mechanical Engineering is the home of several research centers and institutes, including the Advanced Energy Research and Technology Center (AERTC), the Center of Excellence in Wireless and Information Technology (CEWIT), the New York State Center for Engineering Design and Industrial Innovation (CEDI), the Mineral Physics Institute (MPI), and the Center for Mesoscale Transport Properties. Students in the graduate program conduct their research in these state-of-the-art facilities. The Department of Mechanical Engineering receives about $6M per year in external research funding from federal and state agencies as well as private companies. Currently, there are 120 full-time graduate students in the department. Most Ph.D. students are supported by either research or teaching assistantships. The stipends for Ph.D. students are highly competitive. In addition, outstanding Ph.D. applicants are considered for a number of prestigious fellowships, such as the Presidential fellowship and the STEM fellowship from the Graduate School. Ph.D. applicants with excellent academic records will automatically be considered for these fellowships.

Requirements: Applicants to the program must hold an undergraduate degree with a minimum GPA of 3.0. In addition, candidates must have worked in a media-related field (journalism, advertising, public relations, film, marketing, publishing, corporate communications, etc.) for a minimum of two years OR have earned a graduate degree in a media-related field. Applications are accepted on a rolling basis, so candidates should consider applying early. A complete application consists of: An online application to the Graduate School, A 500-word personal statement outlining your professional experience and your career goals., A resume., Two letters of recommendation., Transcripts from all undergraduate and graduate institutions attended., International students whose native language is not English must score at least a 90 on the TOEFL IBT exam.
Description: The advanced graduate certificate in Media Management is an 18-credit program for working professionals in journalism or related fields who aspire to management positions. It’s also ideal for managers in other industries who seek a career change into media. The curriculum provides a strong foundation in media economics, marketing, leadership and ethics, and it focuses on innovation and entrepreneurship in new media and new media business models. All credits from the certificate program may be applied to the Master of Science in Journalism.

Requirements:
We welcome applicants with a bachelor’s degree in any field. The application process is entirely online through the Stony Brook University Graduate School. All of the required materials should be uploaded with your application. In addition to a completed application form and fee, you will need to provide:

- Your resume.
- Official transcripts from every college or university you have attended, including community colleges and institutions where you may have taken only one or two classes. We accept unofficial transcripts for the review process. Please submit official transcripts upon admission to the program.
- A personal statement of 500-1,000 words that describes your interest in media management, career goals, and what you hope to get out of the program.
- Two letters of recommendation from professional or academic references. These should be requested and submitted electronically as part of the online application.

International students must also submit scores from the Test of English as a Foreign Language (TOEFL). The minimum acceptable score is 90 for the Internet-based test. We require an official score report from ETS. The Stony Brook University code is 2548.
Description: The Master of Science in Media Management at Stony Brook University prepares students to manage the business operations of today’s media organizations. The media landscape is complex. New platforms, new business models and new technologies have disrupted traditional media. Our students are prepared to navigate this exciting, ever-changing environment. They are ready to lead. The curriculum focuses on business, including courses in finance, marketing, technology, leadership and entrepreneurship. Students learn about the business of media from experts in the field. Our instructors are top executives at some of the world’s leading media companies. This is where theory and practice come together. We provide the essential business skills and the real-world perspective to build a successful career. Our flexible scheduling — with all classes offered on nights and weekends in New York City — means students don’t have to put their careers on hold to advance them.

Description: The MM in Media Scoring and Production is a 36-credit, two-year degree program that will provide a thorough grounding in the creative, technological, historical, and practical aspects of scoring for visual media such as film, television, games, and advertising. The curriculum includes private composition lessons focused on media scoring, as well as two years of coursework in orchestration, music technology, and the history and business of media scoring. A key component of the program will be collaboration with student directors in the Stony Brook / Killer Films MFA in Film program on their film projects. Students in the MM in Media Scoring and Production will complete a culminating thesis project consisting of the score for an MFA thesis film.

Description: The Stony Brook University MM in Media Scoring and Production is a fully online, 30-credit degree designed for aspiring and early/mid-career media composers. With a focus on scoring for film, television, video games and other interactive media, the curriculum combines traditional conservatory-style compositional training with practical, project-based coursework using the latest music technology. The program is designed to be completed in one calendar year of full-time study, with a part-time option as well, making it accessible to working professionals and students worldwide. The Stony Brook MM in Media Scoring and Production is a rigorous, professionally oriented program that will prepare you for a successful career in the fast-paced and competitive world of media scoring.
Accredidation: The Department of Music is a fully accredited member of the National Association of Schools of Music.

Description: The Center for Medical Humanities, Compassionate Care, and Bioethics offers an MA program to train students in the key concepts and methods of medical humanities and clinical bioethics. The program emphasizes the importance of understanding the values and cultural contexts of illness, health, and medicine, and it fosters a compassionate, patient-centered approach to healthcare. The MA program offers two tracks: Track 1 focuses on clinical ethics, designed for health care professionals, medical, and other health professions students who wish to serve as ethics consultants; Track 2 focuses on health humanities, designed for students interested in doctoral studies and academic careers in the medical/health humanities, for journalists and other professional writers who wish to specialize in writing about medicine and health, and for students in any other discipline that connects with the program’s mission.

EnglishScore: Applicants must prove English proficiency by submitting scores from a recent (within two years) TOEFL, IELTS, or Duolingo English test. The PTE Academic test is also accepted. Applicants from countries where English is the official language of instruction are exempted from this requirement.

A PhD in physics, medical physics, or a closely related field (e.g., engineering, physical chemistry, or computer science) is required for admission. Prerequisite coursework required for consideration includes: Two semesters of calculus-based physics (e.g., mechanics, E&M, modern physics), Multivariable calculus, Differential equations, Upper-level undergraduate courses in electricity and magnetism, quantum mechanics, and classical mechanics are required.
Description: The Certificate Program in Medical Physics at Stony Brook University is designed to provide the didactic component of the training for medical physicists in the specialty of diagnostic medical physics. The program is offered under the sponsorship of the Departments of Radiology and Radiation Oncology, and Biomedical Engineering. The program addresses the shortage of qualified medical physicists, which resulted from the changes in the requirements for certification by the American Board of Radiology (ABR). The goal is to train the next generation of medical physicists, who will ensure the safe and effective use of radiation in medicine. The program curriculum consists of a sequence of eight courses, which are offered over a two-year period, with two courses per semester. All classes are offered in the late afternoon or early evening, to accommodate students who are working full-time. Classes are offered at the Health Sciences Center, Stony Brook University.
Accredidation: The Medical Physics Certificate Program at Stony Brook University has been granted accreditation by the Commission on Accreditation of Medical Physics Education Programs (CAMPEP).

Requirements: The Medical Dosimetry program requires a Bachelor's degree from an accredited university. Applicants must have a cumulative GPA of at least a 3.0. Prerequisite coursework includes: Physics (two semesters with labs), Anatomy & Physiology (two semesters with labs), Pre-calculus, Medical Terminology, Oral and Written Communication. All prerequisite courses must have been completed with a grade of a C or better and within the past 10 years. ARRT certification in Radiation Therapy is required at the time of application. In addition to the online Graduate School application, the following supplemental materials must be submitted: Official transcripts from all colleges/universities attended; Three letters of recommendation; Personal statement indicating interest in the program and career goals; Copy of ARRT certification in Radiation Therapy; Resume; Observation hours documentation (a minimum of 24 observation hours are required).
Description: The Medical Radiation Dosimetry Advanced Certificate is a full-time, 12-month program. The program is offered as either a campus-based or an online distance learning program. All students, campus-based and online, are required to complete a one-year clinical practicum at one of our many clinical affiliates. The mission of the program is to educate students to become competent, compassionate, and professional medical dosimetrists, and to provide them with the knowledge and skills necessary for a successful career in medical radiation dosimetry. The program prepares students with the fundamental concepts of radiation therapy, including radiation physics, radiobiology, anatomy and physiology, patient care, radiation safety, quality assurance, and treatment planning. The curriculum also includes instruction on the latest radiation therapy technologies, such as intensity-modulated radiation therapy (IMRT), volumetric-modulated arc therapy (VMAT), stereotactic radiosurgery (SRS), and stereotactic body radiation therapy (SBRT).
Accredidation: The Medical Radiation Dosimetry Program is accredited by the Joint Review Committee on Education in Radiologic Technology (JRCERT), 20 N. Wacker Drive, Suite 2850, Chicago, IL 60606-3182, (312) 704-5300, www.jrcert.org, mail@jrcert.org. The program was awarded an 8-year accreditation in 2021.

Completion of the following prerequisite coursework from an accredited college or university: Mathematics (calculus) - one semester; Statistics - one semester; Physics (calculus-based) - two semesters with labs; Chemistry - two semesters with labs; Biology (with human focus) - two semesters with labs; English composition - one semester; Computer literacy - one semester. Prior clinical experience in radiation oncology is highly recommended but not required. The Medical Dosimetry Program does not require the GRE exam for admission.
Description: The Medical Dosimetry specialization is a 12-month JRCERT-accredited advanced certificate program for experienced radiation therapists who hold a minimum of a bachelor's degree. A medical dosimetrist is a member of the radiation oncology team who has knowledge of the overall characteristics and clinical relevance of radiation oncology treatment machines and equipment, is cognizant of procedures commonly used in brachytherapy and has the education and expertise necessary to generate radiation dose distributions and dose calculations in collaboration with the medical physicist and radiation oncologist. The program is designed to provide students with the didactic and clinical skills necessary to be eligible to take the Medical Dosimetry Certification Board (MDCB) examination upon graduation. Courses are offered using a combination of in-class and online instruction. All students complete a 12-month, full-time (35 hours/week) clinical internship, which is completed at one of our affiliated medical facilities throughout the country.
Accredidation: JRCERT-accredited

Students with degrees in the basic sciences (physics, chemistry, mathematics) or engineering are also encouraged to apply provided they have taken courses in mathematics (through differential equations) and physics (through mechanics, heat, electricity, and magnetism). Your statement of purpose describing your interests and career goals is an important part of your application.
Department: School of Marine and Atmospheric Sciences (SoMAS)
Description: This program is designed for students with strong backgrounds in the physical, mathematical or engineering sciences who are interested in pursuing a career or further graduate studies in the fields of either meteorology or physical oceanography. Students are educated in the fundamentals of the dynamics of the atmosphere and ocean, and in the physical and mathematical principles underlying these disciplines. Thesis and non-thesis options are available. The thesis option involves in-depth research with a faculty member. The non-thesis option culminates with the submission of a research paper and requires a few more credits of coursework in lieu of thesis credits. All SoMAS M.S. degree programs are expected to be completed in four semesters.

Department: School of Marine and Atmospheric Sciences
Description: The graduate program in meteorology and physical oceanography is administered by the School of Marine and Atmospheric Sciences (SoMAS). It is designed to prepare students for careers in research, teaching and applied sciences. A Ph.D. is granted to a student who has fulfilled the course requirements and has completed a dissertation that makes a significant and original contribution to the body of knowledge in their chosen field of specialization. Both theoretical and observational studies are stressed. There are two major tracks of study: meteorology and physical oceanography. The meteorology track includes studies of atmospheric dynamics, atmospheric chemistry and radiation, and cloud and precipitation physics. The physical oceanography track is concerned with the study of the physics of the ocean, including ocean circulation, ocean-atmosphere interaction, coastal oceanography and sediment transport. In both tracks, the use of numerical models and state-of-the-art instrumentation form an essential component of the graduate education experience. SoMAS has a strong program in tropical meteorology. On-campus facilities include a computing cluster and meteorological instrumentation. Students and faculty have access to research aircraft and ships, and to radar and other remote sensing facilities. Students also can participate in a wide variety of field programs on a worldwide basis. There are many opportunities to develop interdisciplinary research programs with faculty in other fields, such as chemistry and engineering. Graduate students are encouraged to gain teaching experience as well as research expertise. The goal of the program is to produce professionally competent scientists who will make fundamental contributions to the understanding of the processes that govern the dynamics of the world’s atmosphere and oceans.

For further information about the application process and requirements for the graduate program, please go to the MCB graduate program web page.
Department: Renaissance School of Medicine at Stony Brook University
Description: The Graduate Program in Microbiology and Immunology (M&I) offers interdisciplinary training leading to the Ph.D. degree. The Program provides students with a broad knowledge base in Microbiology and Immunology and in-depth training in a selected area of research. Research opportunities in the M&I Program span the disciplines of bacteriology, immunology, virology, and molecular genetics. Students may choose to conduct research in any one of a number of areas including: mechanisms of bacterial and viral pathogenesis; host responses to infection; immune system development and function; cancer immunology; molecular genetics of bacteria, animal viruses, and host cells; and genomics. Training is supported by a large and diverse group of faculty from a number of basic science and clinical departments in the School of Medicine as well as from the adjacent Brookhaven National Laboratory. First-year students participate in three laboratory rotations, which provide an opportunity to explore a variety of research topics before selecting a thesis adviser. In addition to course work and research, students gain teaching experience by assisting in courses at the undergraduate and/or professional school level. The Program is one of ten Ph.D. programs that are part of the Graduate Program in the Biomedical Sciences at Stony Brook University. The average time to degree is five years. All students admitted to the M&I Program are supported by a stipend plus tuition waiver. First year support is provided by the Program. Thereafter, students are supported by the thesis adviser’s research grants, an institutional NIH training grant, or by individual pre-doctoral fellowships from a variety of governmental and private agencies. The M&I Program nominates outstanding applicants to the University’s Graduate Council Fellowship program; all applicants who apply by January 15 and are selected for support are considered automatically for these fellowships.

Requirements:
To be considered for admission to the doctoral program in Molecular and Cellular Pharmacology, applicants must have a bachelor’s degree in the life or physical sciences from an accredited college or university. This background should include one year each of general biology, general chemistry, organic chemistry and physics, and at least one semester of calculus. It is highly recommended that students also take physical chemistry and biochemistry. A grade point average of at least 3.0 is expected.

Research experience is highly desirable.

Letters of recommendation from at least three professors are required.

A statement of purpose describing the student’s background and career goals is required.

The GRE General Test is not required.

International students must take the Test of English as a Foreign Language (TOEFL), and score at least 90 on the iBT test.

Applications for admission and financial support should be received by December 1 for admission the following fall. Only students applying for full-time work toward the PhD degree will be considered for admission.

For more information, visit the program website at: http://www.pharm.stonybrook.edu/pharmacology/grad_program
Description: The Graduate Program in Molecular and Cellular Pharmacology is based in the Department of Pharmacological Sciences in the Renaissance School of Medicine at Stony Brook University. The program trains students for a career in biomedical research and education. The Graduate Program provides a curriculum of formal course work, research training in state-of-the-art laboratories, and teaching experiences. The central focus of the Ph.D. program is the completion of an independent research project that represents a significant, original contribution of new knowledge to the field of pharmacology. The program seeks to develop scientists who are creative, critical, and knowledgeable and can design and conduct research that is at the cutting-edge of the field of pharmacology. The research experience in the program is enhanced by a state-of-the-art research environment, which combines the facilities of the Renaissance School of Medicine, Stony Brook University, Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory and Brookhaven National Laboratory. Faculty research programs focus on multiple areas of molecular pharmacology, including signal transduction, systems biology, cancer biology, neuropharmacology, structural biology, and chemical biology. Graduates of the program are well prepared for the future, as the broad-based training is applicable to many areas of biomedical science. Our graduates find employment in academia, the biotechnology/pharmaceutical industry, and government.

Description: The Graduate Program in Molecular and Cellular Biology (MCB) is an interdisciplinary program of study leading to a Ph.D. degree. The Program offers broad training in the areas of molecular biology, cellular biology, genetics, microbiology, developmental biology, immunology, neurobiology, structural biology and cancer biology. More than 100 faculty from the Departments of a) Biochemistry and Cell Biology; b) Microbiology and Immunology; c) Neurobiology and Behavior; d) Pathology; e) Pharmacological Sciences; and f) Physiology and Biophysics in the College of Arts and Sciences and the School of Medicine participate in the program, thus offering students a wide choice of research experiences. The MCB Program has six major research areas: a) Cancer Biology; b) Cell and Developmental Biology; c) Molecular Biology and Genetics; d) Molecular Microbiology; e) Neuroscience; f) Structural Biology and Molecular Biophysics. Students in the MCB Program are encouraged to select a research area for their dissertation studies but are free to work with any of the participating faculty. The curriculum provides a broad foundation in molecular and cellular biology, with sufficient flexibility for students to design an advanced course of study consistent with their specific research interests.

Description: The MFA in Motion Pictures is an intensive three-year, 60-credit terminal degree program in which students are trained in all aspects of filmmaking, from writing to directing to post-production. Our philosophy is that a successful filmmaker in the 21st century has to understand the process from beginning to end. With a story-driven focus, students write, direct and edit their own films. In addition, they serve in a variety of production roles on their cohort’s films, including cinematographer and producer, and get a strong technical grounding in sound, lighting, editing and the business of film. Students will complete multiple films, culminating in their thesis film, which will be supported by a written thesis document articulating their creative process and artistic ambitions. The program offers a diverse and experienced faculty, as well as renowned guest artists, to help students develop their professional skills and cultivate their artistic vision. Killer Films, a leading independent film company, is Stony Brook’s partner, providing students a unique opportunity to interact with an active film production company. The program culminates in a showcase in New York City, attended by industry professionals. Graduates will leave with the professional skills to launch a career in the film industry and the artistic skills to create their own motion pictures.

Description: The M.A. program in philosophy is a two-year program designed for students who want to develop their knowledge in philosophy in a systematic way and improve their abilities in critical thinking, writing, and reading. The M.A. program offers two tracks: the Academic Track, designed for students planning to go on for a Ph.D. in philosophy or a related field; and the Professional Ethics Track, for students planning careers in fields outside of academia such as business, law, journalism, or medicine, who want a solid grounding in ethics and value theory. Students in the Academic Track write an M.A. thesis, while those in the Professional Ethics Track take a comprehensive exam. Both tracks provide excellent training for a variety of careers.

Description: The graduate program in philosophy has a strong pluralistic orientation and is especially known for its focus in the area of nineteenth and twentieth-century continental philosophy. Areas of specialization include Continental Philosophy since Kant (Phenomenology, Existentialism, Hermeneutics, Structuralism, Post-Structuralism, Deconstruction, Critical Theory, Psychoanalysis, Feminism), Ethics (and its history, ancient, modern, and contemporary), Social and Political Philosophy (and its history), Philosophy of Art (Aesthetics), Philosophy of Race, and Philosophy and Psychoanalysis. The program offers a broad range of courses, and works closely with many other departments and programs, such as Art, Comparative Literature, Cultural Analysis and Theory, English, European Languages, Hispanic Languages, History, Political Science, Sociology, and Women’s, Gender, and Sexuality Studies. The department hosts a number of lecture series and conferences each year, and is the home of the journal, "Continental Philosophy Review" as well as "Epoché: A Journal for the History of Philosophy". The department has a very active graduate student organization, which hosts its own annual conference and "brown bag" series of talks.

Description: The Ph.D. in Health and Rehabilitation Sciences with a concentration in Physical Therapy is a post-professional research-oriented program designed to prepare physical therapists for a career in academia or research. Areas of focus include motor control, biomechanics and motor learning with research emphasis in such populations as stroke, multiple sclerosis, Parkinson’s disease, cerebral palsy, spinal cord injury and geriatrics. Students may have the opportunity to participate in teaching in the professional DPT curriculum based upon their experience and interest.

Description: Welcome to the Graduate Program in Physics & Astronomy at Stony Brook University. We are a large and intellectually vibrant department with a distinguished history of research and education. Our graduate program is one of the top programs in the country, and we welcome talented students from all over the world to join our community. Stony Brook Physics and Astronomy is particularly strong in nuclear physics, condensed matter physics, and astrophysics, but we have strong programs in AMO, and high energy physics as well. The Department of Physics and Astronomy offers a full-time program of study leading to the Ph.D. degree in Physics. Students in the program may also obtain a M.A. degree in passing. Our Ph.D. students are active partners in the research of the department. They work closely with faculty members and are crucial to the success of our research programs. Most of our students go on to very successful careers at academic institutions, national laboratories or in industry.

Description: The MS in Prevention Science and Community Health prepares graduates to serve as practitioners who promote well-being and identify and address public health problems in communities, including health departments, non-profits, healthcare systems, and research settings. Graduates of the program are also well-prepared to enter doctoral programs in public health and related fields. The program has a strong focus on community-engaged prevention research and practice, and provides students with the fundamental skills for developing, implementing, and evaluating programs that address the behavioral and social determinants of health in communities. Students develop strong research skills and learn to use a range of quantitative and qualitative methods to understand how to promote health and health equity. Upon graduation, all students will have had an opportunity to work collaboratively on a community-based, faculty-mentored master's project and will have completed an applied practice experience with a community partner agency. This program is offered full-time (three semesters) and part-time. The curriculum follows a hybrid model with a combination of in-person and online courses.

Description: The Prevention Science and Community Health PhD Program prepares students to become leading researchers who can develop, implement, and evaluate effective and culturally-tailored health promotion and disease prevention programs. The program provides doctoral-level training in the theoretical and methodological basis of prevention science and community health. Students will develop competence in a wide range of relevant theoretical frameworks and research methods, including qualitative and quantitative data collection, survey research, research design (including experimental and quasi-experimental designs), and advanced statistical analysis. Our faculty have expertise in a broad range of areas, including health disparities, cancer prevention and control, chronic disease prevention, global health, HIV/AIDS and other sexually transmitted infections, implementation science, community-based participatory research, health communication, and environmental health. The program draws on an interdisciplinary framework grounded in the public health perspective of understanding the interplay of individual, social, and environmental determinants of health.
