Students will develop a strong foundation in public administration theory and practice, as well as specialized knowledge in a particular area of public administration.

EnglishScore: All graduate applicants are required to demonstrate English proficiency. We accept the TOEFL iBT, the IELTS, and the Duolingo English Test. TOEFL iBT: overall score of 80. IELTS: overall score of 6.5, with no subsection score below 6. Duolingo English Test: minimum score of 105.
Requirements: Required application materials include: official transcripts from all undergraduate and graduate institutions attended, three letters of recommendation, a personal statement describing your interest in public health and your career goals, and a resume or curriculum vitae. GRE scores are optional for Certificate applicants.
Description: The 18-credit Advanced Graduate Certificate in Public Health provides students with foundational knowledge in the five core areas of public health: epidemiology, biostatistics, social and behavioral sciences, environmental health, and health policy and management. The certificate program is designed to provide public health training for individuals who are new to the field, those who are working in public health and wish to enhance their knowledge and skills, and those who would like to explore public health as a potential career. Upon completion of the Advanced Graduate Certificate in Public Health, students will be able to: Explain public health history, philosophy, and values; Identify the core functions of public health and the 10 Essential Services; Explain the role of quantitative and qualitative methods and sciences in describing and assessing a population’s health; List the major causes and trends of morbidity and mortality in the US or other community; Discuss the science of primary, secondary and tertiary prevention in population health, including health promotion, screening, etc.; Explain the critical importance of evidence in advancing public health knowledge; Explain effects of environmental factors on a population’s health; Explain the effects of behavioral and social factor on a population’s health; Explain the legal and ethical bases for public health and health services; Explain the importance of cultural competence in communicating public health content; Define diversity as a core value of public health; Describe the importance of community engagement for public health.

EnglishScore: International applicants must also submit an evaluation of foreign transcripts from World Education Services (WES) and Test of English as a Foreign Language (TOEFL) or International English Language Testing System (IELTS) scores. The university's graduate school specifies the following minimum scores for applicants whose native or primary language is not English: TOEFL iBT: 80, IELTS (Academic): 6.5 overall with no subsection below 6.0, Duolingo: 105, PTE Academic: 53.
Requirements: To apply for admission to the Master of Public Health (MPH) program, you must submit an application through the Schools of Public Health Application Service (SOPHAS). The following documents are required for an application to be considered complete: Online SOPHAS application; Official Transcripts from all post-secondary institutions attended; Three letters of recommendation; A statement of purpose or personal statement; A resume or curriculum vitae. The Program in Public Health has suspended the GRE requirement for all MPH applicants for the Fall 2024 admissions cycle. Applicants can choose whether to submit their GRE scores with their application.

EnglishScore: International applicants who are not native or primary speakers of English are required to submit an official score report from the Test of English as a Foreign Language (TOEFL), the International English Language Testing System (IELTS), or the Duolingo English Test. The minimum score for the TOEFL internet-based test (iBT) is 80, and 550 for the paper-based test. The minimum overall score for IELTS is 6.5, with no subsection score below 6. The minimum score for the Duolingo English Test is 105.
Requirements:
Applicants to the Master of Public Health program are required to have:

- A bachelor’s degree from an accredited college or university.
- A cumulative GPA of 3.0 or higher.
- At least one college-level math course (e.g. algebra, pre-calculus or calculus) and one college-level basic science course (e.g., biology, chemistry, or physics) with a grade of C or better.
- Application submitted through the Schools of Public Health Application Service (SOPHAS).
- Three letters of recommendation.
- Resume or curriculum vitae.
- Personal Statement: a 500-1500 word personal statement of purpose that describes your interest in public health, your career goals, and how the Stony Brook MPH program will help you achieve these goals.
- Official transcripts from all post-secondary schools attended.
- Application fee.
Concentration: Community Health, Health Analytics, and Health Policy and Management
Description: The Master of Public Health (MPH) is the primary professional degree in the field and is designed to prepare students to be public health professionals. The degree is based on a core of knowledge in biostatistics, epidemiology, environmental health sciences, health services administration, and social and behavioral sciences. Students in the MPH program gain a deep understanding of these core disciplines, which provides them with the tools needed to work in the challenging field of public health. Upon completion of the MPH degree, graduates are qualified to define, critically assess, and resolve public health problems.
Accredidation: The Stony Brook Program in Public Health is accredited by the Council on Education for Public Health (CEPH).

EnglishScore: International students must demonstrate English proficiency by submitting one of the following: TOEFL iBT (minimum score 80), IELTS (minimum overall score 6.5, with no subsection score below 6), Duolingo English Test (minimum score 105), or PTE Academic (minimum score 53). Applicants are exempt from submitting English proficiency scores if they have earned a bachelor’s or master's degree from an accredited U.S. institution or from a country on the approved list.
Requirements: To be admitted to the dual-degree program, students must be admitted separately by both the Master of Arts in Public Policy (MAPP) and the Master of Public Health (MPH) programs. Application requirements for admission include a bachelor's degree, a strong academic record (the MAPP program recommends a minimum undergraduate GPA of 3.0), official transcripts from every college/university attended, three letters of recommendation, a personal statement/statement of purpose, and a resume or curriculum vitae. The GRE is not required for the MAPP program and is optional for the MPH program.
Department: College of Arts and Sciences, Program in Public Health
Description: This is a dual degree program offered in conjunction with the Program in Public Health that allows students to earn both a Master of Arts in Public Policy and a Master’s in Public Health. The dual degree MAPP/MPH is intended to prepare students for careers in public health policy. Graduates will be prepared to take positions in government, non-profit organizations, and the private sector that focus on the design, implementation, and evaluation of public health policies and programs. The dual degree program draws on the social science disciplines to provide a foundation for understanding the formulation and implementation of public health policy in the United States and other nations. The MAPP side of the curriculum provides strong training in policy analysis and political processes, including American politics, public opinion, and international relations. The MPH side of the curriculum provides strong training in the core disciplines of public health, including epidemiology, biostatistics, and the social and behavioral sciences. Students have the option of completing a concentration in either Community Health or Health Analytics. The dual degree program requires a total of 69 credits. A full-time student can normally complete the program in two and a half years. Students must be admitted separately to the MAPP and MPH programs.

EnglishScore: Stony Brook University requires international graduate applicants to demonstrate proficiency in English. The Graduate School accepts the TOEFL iBT (including the Home Edition), IELTS, Duolingo, and PTE Academic tests. The minimum score for master's programs is 80 on the TOEFL iBT, 6.5 overall on the IELTS, 105 on the Duolingo, and 53 on the PTE Academic.
Requirements:
The following are required for admission to the Master of Science in Public Health degree program:
1. A baccalaureate degree or its equivalent from an accredited college or university.
2. A minimum cumulative grade point average (GPA) of 3.0 on a 4.0 scale.
3. Three letters of recommendation. At least two of the letters of recommendation should come from academic instructors who are able to assess the applicant’s potential for success in a graduate program.
4. Personal statement. A personal statement of approximately 1,000 words describing the applicant’s reason for pursuing a graduate degree in public health, interest in the chosen concentration, and both short- and long-term career goals. Applicants should highlight any experiences in public health (e.g., employment, volunteer, research, etc.).
5. A current resume or curriculum vitae.
6. Graduate Record Examination (GRE) scores. Test must be taken within five years of the application date. Please note that GREs are waived for the Fall 2024 application cycle.
7. Official transcripts from all post-secondary schools attended.
Description:
The MSPH program is a research-focused degree designed to prepare students to work in a variety of research and research-related settings in academic institutions, local, state and federal government agencies, research organizations and the private sector. The 42-credit hour MSPH is a full-time 21-month program, which begins in the Fall semester. The degree is structured around the required public health core courses, as well as MSPH required courses in research methods, theory and application, ethics, professional and scientific writing, grant writing, and a public health specialty content area.

The MSPH is a STEM-designated degree. The STEM Designation is an indicator of a high-quality program that provides graduates with a competitive advantage for employment.

Students can choose a concentration in Biostatistics, Community Health, Epidemiology, or Health Analytics. Each concentration includes required coursework and a culminating research-based thesis in which students will demonstrate their ability to apply research methods on a public health topic of interest.
Accredidation: The Program in Public Health at Stony Brook University is accredited by the Council on Education for Public Health (CEPH). Our Program has been continuously accredited by CEPH since 2008.

EnglishScore: ALL international applicants from non-English speaking countries must provide proof of English proficiency. This can be demonstrated by submitting official scores from at least one of the following testing agencies: TOEFL, IELTS, Duolingo, or PTE Academic. The minimum acceptable score for master's programs are: TOEFL iBT: 80; IELTS: 6.5 overall with no subsection below 6; Duolingo English Test: 105; PTE Academic: 53.
Requirements: All applications must include the following: Online application and fee; Unofficial transcripts from all previously attended colleges and universities. Official transcripts will be required if you are offered admission; Three letters of recommendation; Statement of purpose; Resume; TOEFL or IELTS scores for all applicants whose native language is not English; Writing sample (see below for more details); GRE scores are not required.
Description: The Master of Arts in Public Relations is the School of Communication and Journalism’s newest graduate program. It is designed to meet the growing need for public relations professionals who are not only skilled writers and strategic thinkers, but who also are fluent in digital media and grounded in ethical practices. Students will get hands-on experience, learn from top public relations executives, expand their professional networks and graduate with a strong portfolio that will help them launch or advance their careers. The 30-credit curriculum is built on a foundation of writing, ethics and digital communication strategies. Students will take a range of courses in strategic communications, learning how to analyze, develop, execute and assess a full range of communication for any type of organization. These professional skills are complemented by courses in communication theory and research. The program also draws from the Alan Alda Center for Communicating Science's internationally-recognized expertise to help students learn how to translate complex topics for a variety of audiences. The degree culminates in a capstone professional project, in which students will work in teams with a real-world client to help solve a communication challenge.

ProgramName: Special Focus Area in Health Programs, Policies and Practice (MSW)
EnglishScore: All graduate applicants are required to demonstrate English proficiency. This can be satisfied with minimum scores on TOEFL iBT (80 for master's), IELTS (6.5 overall), Duolingo (105 for master's), or PTE Academic (53 for master's). Students who have earned a degree in the U.S. or in a country that is exempt from the English proficiency requirement are not required to submit test scores.
Requirements: A baccalaureate degree from an accredited college or university. A minimum undergraduate grade point average of 3.0 on a 4.0 scale. A minimum of 18 credits in the liberal arts and sciences (i.e. social and behavioral sciences, humanities, natural sciences and math). A statistics course with a grade of C or better. Human or social service experience, preferably post-baccalaureate, paid or volunteer. Personal characteristics and qualifications suitable for the profession of social work.
Concentration: Special Focus Area in Health Programs, Policies and Practice
Description: The School of Social Welfare is in the process of developing a new special focus area in Health Programs, Policies and Practice. The expected launch date is Fall 2025. Students in this special focus area will learn theories of health, illness and disability and will be trained to use evidence-based practices to improve health outcomes and well-being. Upon graduation, students will be prepared for a wide range of social work career paths in medical and public health settings. Specifically, students will be trained to: Understand and appraise the role of social and behavioral factors (e.g., economic stability, neighborhood safety, social connections, lifestyle/health behaviors) in shaping health and well-being at the individual, family, community and population level; Apply a social justice and health equity framework to the analysis of health problems and the development of programs and policies; Design and implement culturally responsive evidence-based interventions in a variety of practice settings that aim to improve health outcomes, promote well-being, and reduce health inequities; Collaborate with interprofessional teams to plan and manage health care and advance population health; Translate and disseminate research and practice evidence to inform health programs, policies and practices. Students will have a range of options for their field placements, including hospitals, community-based health clinics, substance use treatment programs, health departments, managed care organizations and advocacy groups.
Accredidation: The Stony Brook University MSW Program is fully accredited by the Council on Social Work Education (CSWE).

ProgramName: Teaching and Learning With Technology Certificate
EnglishScore: International applicants are required to demonstrate English proficiency. The School of Professional Development requires a minimum TOEFL iBT score of 80. The Graduate School also accepts IELTS (minimum 6.5), Duolingo (minimum 105), and PTE Academic (minimum 53) to satisfy this requirement.
Requirements: Applicants must have a bachelor's degree from an accredited institution. They must also have a minimum cumulative grade point average of 3.00. Applicants should apply for this certificate program by submitting a School of Professional Development (SPD) application, which includes official transcripts from all colleges and universities attended, a personal statement, and one letter of recommendation.
Description: The Advanced Graduate Certificate in Teaching and Learning with Technology is designed for teachers who have initial certification and who wish to meet the New York State requirements for professional certification in the area of educational technology. The program provides the theoretical and pedagogical foundations for the successful infusion of technology into the P-12 curriculum. Upon completion of this program and any other outstanding requirements, such as mentoring, the student has met the State's requirements for professional certification.

EnglishScore: International applicants are required to take the TOEFL or IELTS examination.
Requirements: In addition to fulfilling the requirements for admission to the Graduate School, applicants must have completed an undergraduate major in English (or its equivalent, e.g. 36 credits of upper-division coursework in English). A cumulative grade point average of 3.0 or higher is required for admission, as is a 3.0 or higher in all English coursework. The following materials must be submitted through the online application system: Graduate School Application form, Two letters of recommendation, A statement of purpose, One official transcript from each college/university attended, A writing sample of 8-10 pages of academic writing on a literary topic, A curriculum vitae. The GRE general test is not required for admission to the English MAT program.
Description: The MAT in English program leads to a Master of Arts in Teaching and recommendation for the New York State Initial Certificate in English Language Arts, grades 7-12. The program is designed for students who have a bachelor’s degree in English and are seeking to become secondary school English teachers. The program combines graduate study of literary texts and cultural theory with coursework in pedagogy and a supervised student teaching experience. Our MAT program in English enables students to continue studying literature and culture at the graduate level, while at the same time developing the skills and dispositions of a reflective and effective classroom teacher. MAT candidates complete 12 credits in graduate English courses and 30 credits in pedagogy, including 100 hours of field experience and a 14-week, full-time student teaching placement. This program has a high placement rate for its graduates.
Accredidation: Stony Brook University’s Professional Education Program (PEP) is accredited by the Council for the Accreditation of Educator Preparation (CAEP).

EnglishScore: An English proficiency test (TOEFL) is required for applicants for whom English is not their first language. As per the Graduate School's policy, this requirement can be met with a minimum TOEFL iBT score of 80, an IELTS overall score of 6.5, a Duolingo English Test score of 105, or a PTE Academic score of 53.
Requirements:
Applicants should have:
- A bachelor’s degree in one of the languages in which we offer certification: French, Italian, or Spanish.
- An overall GPA of 3.0 and a GPA of 3.0 in the major.
- A grade of B or better in a course on the structure of the target language (e.g., FRE 311, ITL 311, SPN 311 or equivalent).
- Proficiency in spoken and written English, and in the language of certification. All applicants must take the Oral Proficiency Interview (OPI) in their language of certification and achieve at least the advanced-low rating. They must also pass a Writing Proficiency Test (WPT).
- A minimum of 24 semester hours of upper-division courses in the target language. These courses should focus on language, literature, and culture.
- 12 credits of language study other than English and the target language (this requirement can be met by 4 years of one language in high school or 2 years each of two languages in high school or a combination of high school and college coursework).

Required application materials include:
- Unofficial transcripts from all undergraduate and graduate institutions attended are required for the application review. Official transcripts are required upon acceptance into the program.
- 3 letters of recommendation
- Resume
- Personal statement in English
- A writing sample in the target language of about 250 words.

Standardized Tests:
- GRE is not required.
- For international applicants: Minimum TOEFL Score: 85 (iBT with 22 Speaking subscore); Minimum IELTS Score: 6.5 (Overall with 6.5 Speaking subscore); Minimum Duolingo Score: 115.
Description: The Master of Arts in Teaching a Foreign Language program is a 42- to 45-credit* course of study that leads to a master’s degree and initial/professional New York State certification for teaching French, Italian or Spanish in grades 7-12, with an optional extension for grades 5-6. This program is for individuals who have completed an undergraduate or graduate degree with a major in French, Italian or Spanish, or who have completed a minimum of 36 credits in college-level courses in the target language. The course of study includes both pedagogical and content-specific coursework. It culminates in a student teaching experience that is supervised by a faculty member from the program. The School of Professional Development also offers an advanced graduate certificate in Educational Leadership that leads to NYS certification for School Building and School District Leaders. Visit the Educational Leadership website for details.
Accredidation: The teacher education programs at Stony Brook University are accredited by the Council for the Accreditation of Educator Preparation (CAEP).

EnglishScore: TOEFL iBT or IELTS: Required for international students whose native language is not English. TOEFL iBT 85 / IELTS 6.5
Requirements:
To be considered for admission, a student must have an undergraduate degree in mathematics or its equivalent: at least 36 credits of mathematics and related areas, including a year of calculus of one and several variables (AMS 161, 261 or MAT 132, 203 or similar), linear algebra (AMS 210 or MAT 211 or similar), and at least 18 credits of upper division mathematics courses, including courses on the foundations of analysis (MAT 319 or 320 or similar), and on the foundations of algebra (MAT 312 or 313 or similar). The cumulative GPA must be at least 3.0, and the GPA in mathematics and science must be at least 3.0.

Online Application to the Graduate School, including:

Résumé
A personal statement (about 2 pages) stating your purpose in undertaking graduate study in mathematics education.
Transcripts from all colleges and universities attended. Unofficial transcripts can be uploaded to the online application for review purposes. If an offer of admission is made and accepted, official transcripts will be required.
Three letters of recommendation.
GRE scores are not required.
A TOEFL score of at least 90 (for the internet-based test) is required for all applicants from countries where English is not the primary language.
Description: The Master of Arts in Teaching Mathematics program is a 45-credit program of study for individuals who have an undergraduate major or the equivalent in mathematics but who do not have the background in education to qualify for teacher certification. The program provides students with the necessary coursework to obtain a New York State Initial Teaching Certificate to teach mathematics in grades 7-12. Upon completion of the program, students are recommended for certification. The MAT program is offered through the School of Professional Development and is registered with the New York State Education Department. The professional education coursework for the MAT is offered through SPD's teacher education program, which is accredited by the National Council for Accreditation of Teacher Education (NCATE).
Accredidation: The professional education coursework for the MAT is offered through SPD's teacher education program, which is accredited by the National Council for Accreditation of Teacher Education (NCATE).

EnglishScore: All international students must demonstrate English proficiency. The following are the acceptable exams and the minimum scores that SPD will accept: TOEFL IBT: 85; IELTS: 6.5 overall band score with no band score below 6.0; PTE Academic: 58; Duolingo English Test: 105. We will also accept an ELS Language Centers score of 112. This requirement is waived for applicants who have earned a degree from a university in the United States or another English-speaking country.
Requirements:
Admissions Requirements

- A bachelor's degree in biology, chemistry, earth science, or physics with a minimum GPA of 3.0 overall, and in the content area. A minimum of 36 credits in the content area is required. Students who need to fulfill additional science content courses may be able to take them as a non-matriculated student in the School of Professional Development.
- GRE general test. Students with a cumulative GPA of 3.0 or higher who also have a degree in the sciences (biology, chemistry, physics, earth science) from a U.S. college or university may request a GRE waiver. (Note: GRE requirement is currently suspended. It is not required for Spring or Fall 2024 admissions.)
- One year of college-level study of a foreign language with a grade of "C" or better (or equivalent).
- A course in developmental psychology/adolescent development is also required. Candidates who have not taken this course may be admitted, but will be required to take SPD's CEF 547: Human Growth and Development, or its equivalent, within the first two semesters of study.

Application Materials

To apply, candidates must submit the following:

- A completed online Graduate School application.
- Official transcripts from all colleges and universities attended.
- A personal statement that addresses the following question: "Why do you want to become a science teacher?" The statement will be evaluated on the basis of clarity, grammar, and syntax.
- Three letters of recommendation.
- GRE general test scores. (Note: GRE requirement is currently suspended. It is not required for Spring or Fall 2024 admissions.)
- A non-refundable application fee of $100.
- TOEFL/IELTS scores are required for applicants for whom English is not their first language.
Description: The Master of Arts in Teaching (MAT) degree programs are designed for individuals who hold a bachelor's degree in one of the content areas (biology, chemistry, earth science or physics) and wish to become a classroom teacher. The MAT is a graduate-level program that leads to a master’s degree and teacher certification simultaneously. Candidates who successfully complete the program will be eligible for New York State initial certification in their content area, grades 7-12. The program is offered on a full- or part-time basis, providing flexible scheduling options.
Accredidation: Stony Brook University is accredited by the Middle States Commission on Higher Education (MSCHE). The School of Professional Development's teacher and leader education programs are accredited by the Council for the Accreditation of Educator Preparation (CAEP).

EnglishScore: Required for international applicants. Accepted tests are TOEFL, IELTS, or Duolingo. Minimum scores are TOEFL iBT: 85, IELTS: 6.5 overall with no subsection below 6, or Duolingo: 105.
Requirements: Bachelor's degree with a GPA of 3.0 or higher. A major in history, political science, economics, anthropology, or geography or 30 credits in social studies, including 21 credits in history (including coursework in U.S. history and non-western history) and coursework in political science and economics. Completion of one year of college-level study of a foreign language with a grade of C or better. GRE or other standardized tests are not required for admission. Three letters of recommendation. A statement of purpose. New York State requires that all candidates for teacher certification pass a series of tests to become licensed. Candidates in the Social Studies Teacher Education program must pass the Content Specialty Test (CST) prior to student teaching. Résumé.
Description: The Master of Arts in Teaching (MAT) in Social Studies program is designed for individuals who hold an undergraduate degree in history or an approved related field (economics, political science, sociology or anthropology) and who wish to teach social studies in secondary schools (grades 7-12). It is a 45-credit program that leads to a master's degree and professional certification. The program includes a comprehensive set of courses in professional studies in education and in social studies content. It places a special emphasis on global studies and the development of a multicultural perspective. Upon successful completion of the program, candidates are recommended for New York State Initial Certification in Social Studies, 7-12. The degree can be completed in four semesters of full-time study or three years of part-time study.
Accredidation: The School of Professional Development's teacher education programs are accredited by the Council for the Accreditation of Educator Preparation (CAEP).

EnglishScore: All international students must demonstrate English proficiency. TOEFL: The minimum acceptable score for the TOEFL iBT is 80 for master’s programs and 90 for doctoral programs. IELTS: The minimum acceptable score for the IELTS is an overall score of 6.5, with no subsection score below 6. Duolingo English Test: The minimum acceptable score for Duolingo is 105 for master’s applicants and 115 for doctoral applicants. PTE Academic: The minimum acceptable score for the PTE Academic test is 53 for master's applicants and 65 for doctoral applicants.
Requirements: In addition to the Graduate School’s admission requirements, the following are required: A bachelor’s degree in engineering, natural sciences, or mathematics, with a minimum cumulative grade point average of 3.0. Appropriate work experience is considered. GRE general test is no longer required for applicants holding a degree from an ABET-accredited program in the U.S. All other applicants are required to take the GRE General Test (verbal, quantitative and analytical). The department does not set a minimum GRE test score. Three letters of recommendation. A personal statement clearly stating the applicant’s interest in this program. International applicants are required to take the TOEFL examination and must score at least 85 on the iBT.
Department: College of Engineering and Applied Sciences
Description: The Master of Science in Technological Systems Management (M.S.-T.S.M.) is the flagship graduate program in the Department of Technology and Society. It is designed for students with a background in engineering, the natural sciences or an environmental field. The degree provides an opportunity for students to develop their skills in management, public policy, and technology. The M.S. TSM degree requires a minimum of 30 graduate credits. There is a flexibility in selecting graduate courses that supports individual career objectives of our students.
ScholarshipType: Teaching Assistantships, Research Assistantships, Graduate Assistantships

EnglishScore: International applicants are also required to take the TOEFL exam.
Requirements: The PhD Program in Technology, Policy, and Innovation is intended for those with a master’s degree from a recognized university. Students with exceptional undergraduate degrees will be considered on a case by case basis. Applicants for admission to the PhD program in Technology, Policy, and Innovation are required to submit the following credentials: An official application to the Graduate School. Official transcripts of all undergraduate and graduate courses. Three letters of recommendation. A comprehensive statement of purpose. For foreign students, a satisfactory score on the TOEFL examination is required (550 on the paper-based test or 213 on the computer-based test). The GRE is not required.
Department: College of Engineering and Applied Sciences
Description: The PhD program in Technology, Policy, and Innovation, offered through the Department of Technology and Society in the College of Engineering and Applied Sciences, is focused on the analysis of public policies for science and technology, and on the development of policies to address major societal challenges, including those involving energy, the environment, and sustainable economic development. Students in this program focus on gaining a deep understanding of the interplay among scientific, technological, social, political, and economic forces that is required to address these challenges. The program curriculum provides students with a solid foundation in the theory and methods of policy analysis. Students in the program come from a wide variety of backgrounds, including engineering, the natural sciences, the social sciences, and the humanities. All students are expected to have a basic level of quantitative skills. Graduates from the program are prepared for careers in academia, government, and industry.
ScholarshipAmount: Full tuition coverage and a stipend of $22,500 per academic year
ScholarshipType: Graduate Assistantships, Teaching Assistantships, Fellowships, Research grants

EnglishScore: If English is not your native language, you must demonstrate English proficiency. Stony Brook accepts the TOEFL, IELTS, Duolingo, and PTE academic tests. Your scores must be less than two years old.
Requirements: To complete an application, prospective students must submit either the Common Application or the Coalition Application, which includes the Stony Brook Supplement questions and a personal essay. A $50 non-refundable application fee and official high school transcript(s) are also required. Stony Brook University is test-optional; submission of SAT or ACT scores is not required. While not required for admission, applicants may submit up to two letters of recommendation.
Description: Accounting is the language of business. It provides a framework for analyzing financial transactions and communicating economic information to investors, creditors, and other interested parties. The Bachelor of Science in Accounting program at Stony Brook University is designed to equip students with a strong foundation in accounting principles, financial reporting, auditing, taxation, and business law. Graduates are prepared for positions in public accounting, corporate accounting, government, and not-for-profit organizations. The program provides a foundation for students pursuing professional certification, such as the CPA or CMA.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Arts in Africana Studies
EnglishScore: For applicants whose native language is not English, one of the following exams is required with the specified minimum score: TOEFL: 80, IELTS: 6.5, Duolingo English Test (DET): 105, PTE Academic: 53, or completion of the ELS Language Center Level 112.
Description: The Bachelor of Arts (BA) program in Africana Studies is an interdisciplinary program designed to give students a critical understanding of the experiences of African peoples and their descendants throughout the world. Students examine the history, culture, politics, economics, and social structures of African, African American, and Caribbean communities. The program emphasizes critical thinking, research skills, and an appreciation for diverse perspectives. Graduates are prepared for a variety of careers in fields such as education, public service, social justice, law, business, and international affairs, or for further graduate study.

EnglishScore: If English is not your native language, you must take one of the following exams and meet the minimum score requirement: TOEFL, IELTS, Duolingo, or PTE Academic.
Requirements: To apply for undergraduate admission, applicants must submit a completed Common Application or Coalition Application, powered by Scoir. A $50 non-refundable application fee or an approved fee waiver is required. Necessary documents include official high school transcript(s) and one letter of recommendation from a school counselor or teacher. If applicable, official college transcripts for any completed coursework must also be submitted. An essay is required as part of the application.
Description: Anthropology is a comparative and holistic discipline that explores humanity in all its breadth and depth. The program covers the four major fields of Anthropology (Cultural Anthropology, Archaeology, Biological Anthropology, and Linguistics) and offers students a variety of opportunities for fieldwork, laboratory research, and museum studies both at Stony Brook and abroad. Courses focus on human evolution, primate behavior, human variation, cultural diversity, social inequality, development, forensics, archaeology, language and cognition. The diverse interests of the faculty provide students with a broad and theoretically sophisticated understanding of the human condition.
ScholarshipAmount: Varies, e.g., Presidential Scholarship ($10,000/year), Provost's Scholarship ($5,000/year)

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Applied Mathematics & Statistics
EnglishScore: All international students must demonstrate English proficiency. This can be done by submitting official scores from one of the following exams: TOEFL (minimum score of 80 on the internet-based test), IELTS (minimum composite score of 6.5), Duolingo English Test (minimum score of 105), or PTE Academic (minimum score of 53). Students may be exempt if they achieve a 550 or higher on the SAT Evidence-Based Reading and Writing section or a 22 or higher on the ACT English section, or if their native language is English.
Requirements: Qualified first-year and transfer students who have indicated their interest in the major on their applications may be admitted directly to the major at the time of their admission to the University. Students who did not apply for the major and are not admitted to the major when they enter the University may apply for admission to the major provided that their cumulative g.p.a. is at least 2.80 and that they have received a grade of B- or higher in MAT 125 or MAT 131 or MAT 141 or AMS 151 and a grade of B- or higher in MAT 126 or MAT 132 or MAT 142 or AMS 161.
Description:
The undergraduate program in Applied Mathematics and Statistics (AMS) provides students with a strong mathematical, statistical, and computational background that prepares them for careers in industry or government and for graduate study in applied mathematics, statistics, and other quantitative fields.
The program provides a solid foundation in calculus, linear algebra, discrete mathematics, and differential equations. It also provides a strong background in probability, statistical inference, and computational methods. A variety of elective courses in subjects such as operations research, mathematical finance, actuarial science, and mathematical biology, gives students the opportunity to learn about important modern applications of applied mathematics and statistics.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Arts in Art History & Criticism
EnglishScore: If English is not your native language, you will be required to provide proof of your English proficiency. Stony Brook accepts the TOEFL, IELTS, Duolingo, and PTE Academic tests. An SAT Evidence-Based Reading and Writing score of 500 or higher or an ACT English score of 22 or higher can also be used to satisfy this requirement.
Requirements: Application requirements for first-year students include the submission of a Common Application or ApplySUNY application, a non-refundable application fee, official high school transcripts, one required teacher or counselor recommendation, and a personal essay. Stony Brook University is test-optional and does not require SAT or ACT scores for students applying for admission for terms through spring 2025.
Description: Art history provides a broad humanistic foundation and critical framework for understanding the visual arts and culture. The curriculum develops students’ analytical, research, and writing skills, while fostering visual literacy and critical thinking. It covers a range of historical periods, geographical regions, and theoretical approaches to diverse media including painting, sculpture, architecture, and new media. Beyond its inherent value as a liberal art, the study of art history prepares students for careers in museums, galleries, auction houses, publishing, education, conservation, historic preservation, government, and other areas of the art world. It is also an excellent preparation for graduate study in art history, law, or related fields. Students are encouraged to pursue an internship to gain practical experience.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Arts in Art, Studio
EnglishScore: If English is not your native language, you must demonstrate English proficiency. Stony Brook University accepts the TOEFL, IELTS, Duolingo, and PTE academic tests. Test scores are considered official when they are sent directly from the testing agency. Scores over two years old will not be accepted.
Requirements: Admission is contingent on a successful portfolio review by the Art Department. The portfolio review takes place only after the student has been admitted to the University. For portfolio submission guidelines, please visit stonybrook.edu/art.
Fees: In-state: $7,070 per year; Out-of-state: $25,110 per year

ProgramName: Bachelor of Arts in Asian & Asian American Studies
EnglishScore: For international students where English is not their native language, demonstration of English proficiency is required. Accepted tests and minimum scores are: TOEFL iBT (80), IELTS (6.5), Duolingo (105), or PTE (53).
Description: The Bachelor of Arts (B.A.) program in Asian & Asian American Studies enables students to achieve a greater understanding of Asian and Asian American history, societies, politics, economies, and cultures. The curriculum offers students a broad, interdisciplinary learning experience with courses from the humanities, social sciences, and fine arts. Students can engage in the study of a particular Asian country or region, or focus on a specific thematic area such as Asian diaspora studies, transnationalism, globalization, or gender studies. With guidance from the undergraduate program director, students may create their own specialized course of study to meet their individual academic and professional goals. This program is offered by the Department of Asian & Asian American Studies.
ScholarshipAmount: Varies; ranges from $1,000/year to full tuition for merit-based awards.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Astronomy/Planetary Sciences
EnglishScore: If English is not your native language, you must demonstrate English proficiency. You may do so by submitting scores from one of the following exams: TOEFL (minimum score of 80), IELTS (minimum score of 6.5), Duolingo (minimum score of 105), or PTE (minimum score of 53).
Requirements: Stony Brook University takes a holistic approach to reviewing applications. We seek to enroll students with diverse backgrounds, interests, and abilities who will take advantage of our outstanding academic and extracurricular offerings. Each application is reviewed on an individual basis. There are no score cutoffs for admission. We look for a strong high school academic program, and we consider your highest scores on the SAT or ACT. We also consider factors such as your extracurricular activities, special talents or abilities, and your personal essay. Students who have challenged themselves with an Advanced Placement (AP) or honors curriculum will be given special consideration.
Fees: $7,070 per year for New York State residents and $25,110 per year for out-of-state students.
Description: The Department of Physics and Astronomy offers an undergraduate major leading to the Bachelor of Science (BS) degree in Astronomy/Planetary Sciences. This is a rigorous program for students interested in a career as a professional astronomer or planetary scientist, or for students who wish to pursue graduate work in astronomy, planetary science, or a related field. It is suitable for students seeking a strong preparation in basic science with emphasis on the quantitative analysis required for modern astronomy and planetary science. The program emphasizes both theoretical and observational aspects of modern astronomy and planetary science, drawing on the expertise of faculty in the Department of Physics and Astronomy. Students are encouraged to participate in undergraduate research with faculty members. A number of internship opportunities exist for students at institutions like the American Museum of Natural History, Brookhaven National Laboratory, and the Intrepid Sea, Air & Space Museum. In addition, the department maintains an astronomical observatory on campus, which includes a 14-inch telescope available for both class use and undergraduate research.
ScholarshipAmount: Presidential Scholarships are offered for up to the full value of New York State resident tuition.
ScholarshipPercentage: 58% of full-time undergraduate students received grant or scholarship aid.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Atmospheric and Oceanic Sciences
EnglishScore: For international applicants, Stony Brook accepts the TOEFL, IELTS, Duolingo, and PTE academic to satisfy the English proficiency requirement. Minimum scores are: TOEFL iBT 80, IELTS 6.5, Duolingo 105, or PTE academic 53.
Requirements: Stony Brook will holistically review your application and take all parts of your application into consideration, including: your high school transcript, the rigor and strength of your academic program, your supplemental essay and letters of recommendation, and standardized test scores (if you choose to submit them). For this major, students should complete at least one semester of calculus and at least one semester of either chemistry or physics before entering the major.
Department: School of Marine and Atmospheric Sciences
Description: The Atmospheric and Oceanic Sciences (AOS) Program at Stony Brook University provides students with a solid foundation in the physical and chemical processes governing the Earth’s atmosphere and oceans. Our program offers rigorous training in quantitative analysis, modeling, and observational techniques essential for understanding and predicting weather, climate, and ocean dynamics. Students will develop a strong background in mathematics, physics, and chemistry, applying these principles to complex environmental challenges. With a focus on interdisciplinary approaches, our graduates are well-prepared for careers in meteorology, oceanography, climate science, environmental consulting, and graduate studies.

EnglishScore: If English is not your native language, you must demonstrate English proficiency. Accepted tests include TOEFL iBT (80 or higher), IELTS (6.5 or higher), Duolingo English Test (105 or higher), or PTE Academic (53 or higher). Other ways to satisfy the requirement, such as prior education in the U.S. or successfully completing ELS Language Centers Level 112, are also available.
Requirements: A completed application for first-year admission includes: The Common Application or Coalition Application, a $50 non-refundable application fee, your official high school transcript, one teacher or counselor recommendation, and the Stony Brook Writing Supplement. Stony Brook is test-optional and will not require SAT or ACT scores for most applicants.
Description: The Department of Biochemistry and Cell Biology provides an excellent environment for students interested in biochemical and molecular biological research. The Bachelor of Science program in Biochemistry prepares students for graduate work in biochemistry and related fields as well as careers in the biotechnology and pharmaceutical industries. Many of our graduates pursue careers in the health sciences including medicine, dentistry, and veterinary medicine. Students in the program develop critical thinking and problem-solving skills necessary for a career in science and medicine.

EnglishScore: All international students must demonstrate English proficiency by submitting official scores from at least one of the following exams: TOEFL, IELTS, Duolingo, or PTE Academic.
Requirements: To apply as a first-year student, you must submit either the Common Application or the SUNY Application, along with a $50 non-refundable application fee. Required documents include your official high school transcript(s), one letter of recommendation from a school counselor or teacher, and an application essay. Stony Brook is test-optional, meaning you have the choice to submit SAT or ACT scores as part of your application.
Description:
The Bachelor of Arts (BA) in Biology is a liberal arts program designed for students interested in a broad education in biology with maximum flexibility in course selection. The BA degree does not include any specific area of specialization, and can be combined with other majors, minors, and pre-professional programs (e.g., Pre-Law, Pre-Med). Students completing the BA degree can continue their education in graduate programs, professional schools, or enter the workforce. The program learning outcomes for the BA in Biology are that students will be able to:
1. Demonstrate knowledge of major concepts, theoretical perspectives, empirical findings, and historical trends in biology.
2. Formulate and evaluate biological research questions, and design and execute experiments to address them.
3. Understand and apply scientific methods, including observation, experimentation, and quantitative analysis, to solve biological problems.
4. Effectively communicate scientific information in both written and oral formats.
5. Apply ethical principles to biological research and practice.
ScholarshipAmount: Awards range from $500 per year up to the full cost of attendance.

EnglishScore: If English is not your native language, you must demonstrate English proficiency. Stony Brook accepts the TOEFL, IELTS, Duolingo and PTE academic tests.
Requirements: To be eligible to declare the Biology major, students must complete CHE 131 General Chemistry I and one of the following courses with a grade of C or higher: BIO 201, BIO 202 or BIO 203. A grade of C or higher is also required in CHE 132 General Chemistry II.
Description: The B.S. program in Biology is designed for students interested in a broad training in biology and for students who intend to pursue careers in research, teaching, medicine, dentistry, or other health professions. This program provides students with a strong foundation in all areas of biology (molecular, cellular, organismal, and ecological/evolutionary biology), along with a strong background in chemistry, physics, and mathematics. Students also develop critical thinking and communication skills essential for success in diverse fields.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Engineering in Biomedical Engineering
EnglishScore: If your native language is not English, you must demonstrate English proficiency. We accept the TOEFL, IELTS, Duolingo, and PTE academic tests. Recommended scores are: TOEFL (iBT): 80, IELTS: 6.5, Duolingo: 105, PTE: 53.
Requirements: Applicants must submit either the Common Application or the Coalition Application, an application essay, an official high school transcript, and one teacher/counselor recommendation. A nonrefundable $50 application fee or fee waiver is also required. Submission of official SAT or ACT scores is optional.
Department: College of Engineering and Applied Sciences
Description: Biomedical engineering (BME) is a rapidly growing interdisciplinary field that combines engineering, biology, and medicine. Biomedical engineers work to advance human health by applying engineering principles and design concepts to medicine and biology. The BME curriculum combines a strong foundation in mathematics, physics, and chemistry with in-depth study of engineering and biological sciences and provides the necessary background for students to succeed in this field. Technical electives allow students to specialize in areas such as biomechanics, bioinstrumentation, biomaterials, and medical imaging. The program prepares students for graduate study in biomedical engineering and other related fields or for careers in the biomedical industry (e.g., medical devices, pharmaceutical, and biotechnology).
Accredidation: Accredited by the Engineering Accreditation Commission of ABET.
ScholarshipAmount: Varies, with some awards covering full tuition.
ScholarshipType: Merit-based, financial need, and other specific criteria

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Business Management
EnglishScore: If your native language is not English, you must demonstrate English proficiency. You can do this by submitting official scores from at least one of the following exams: TOEFL, IELTS, Duolingo, and PTE Academic.
Requirements: Qualified freshmen and transfers who have indicated their interest in the major on their applications may be admitted directly to the major. Admission is highly competitive and based on a review of the student’s application materials. Students not admitted directly to the major may apply for admission after their first year at Stony Brook provided they meet the secondary admission requirements. To be considered for admission after the first year, students must have a 3.2 cumulative grade point average and must have completed at least two of the following courses with a grade of B or better: BUS 115, ECO 108, AMS 102, and MAT 123 (or a higher-level calculus course).
Description: The Bachelor of Science (BS) in Business Management provides students with a strong foundation in business principles and practices, preparing them for a variety of careers in the private, public, and non-profit sectors. The curriculum emphasizes critical thinking, problem-solving, and ethical decision-making, equipping students with the skills necessary to succeed in a dynamic global business environment. Students gain a comprehensive understanding of core business functions, including accounting, finance, marketing, operations, and strategic management. The program also offers flexibility through electives, allowing students to explore areas of interest or prepare for graduate studies. Through rigorous coursework and experiential learning opportunities, students develop leadership potential and the ability to contribute effectively to organizations. The Business Management program provides a comprehensive business education grounded in the liberal arts and sciences. It prepares students for a wide range of careers in business, government, and not-for-profit organizations. It is also an excellent preparation for graduate study in business, law, or other fields. Through rigorous coursework, students develop analytical and problem-solving skills, learn to communicate effectively, and gain an understanding of ethical and social responsibility in business. The curriculum covers key functional areas of business, including accounting, finance, marketing, operations management, and strategic management. Students are encouraged to participate in internships, study abroad programs, and student organizations to gain practical experience and network with professionals.
ScholarshipAmount: Varies by scholarship, amounts range from $1,000 per year to full tuition.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Engineering in Chemical & Molecular Engineering
EnglishScore: If English is not your native language, you must demonstrate English proficiency by providing a satisfactory score from one of the following exams: TOEFL (minimum 80 iBT), IELTS (minimum 6.5), Duolingo English Test (minimum 105), or PTE Academic (minimum 53).
Requirements: To apply as a freshman, you will need to submit the following: Common Application or Coalition Application, powered by Scoir; Official high school transcript(s); One teacher or counselor recommendation; One essay; Application fee. Stony Brook University is test-optional, which means you have the choice to submit SAT or ACT scores as part of your application for admission.
Department: College of Engineering and Applied Sciences
Description: The undergraduate Chemical and Molecular Engineering (CME) program has been designed to provide students with a strong foundation in chemical engineering principles, as well as the advanced concepts of molecular engineering that are at the forefront of modern chemical technology. The curriculum encompasses a broad range of topics, including thermodynamics, transport phenomena, reaction kinetics, and process design, while also integrating molecular-level understanding of materials and processes. Students learn to apply engineering principles to design, analyze, and optimize systems involving chemical, physical, and biological transformations, preparing them for careers in diverse industries such as energy, pharmaceuticals, materials, and environmental management, or for further graduate studies.
Accredidation: The Undergraduate Chemical and Molecular Engineering program is accredited by the Engineering Accreditation Commission of ABET, https://www.abet.org.

EnglishScore: If your native language is not English, you will be required to provide proof of English proficiency by submitting scores from at least one of the following tests: TOEFL, IELTS, Duolingo English Test, or PTE academic.
Requirements:
To be considered for admission, the following must be on file in the Office of Undergraduate Admissions by the appropriate deadline:
- Common Application or Coalition Application, powered by Scoir
- $50 non-refundable application fee or fee waiver
- Official high school transcript(s)
- Official SAT or ACT Scores (Optional)
- One teacher/counselor recommendation
- Essay
Description: The Bachelor of Arts (B.A.) program in Chemistry is designed to provide students with a strong background in chemistry, along with the flexibility to combine their studies with other academic interests or pre-professional programs. This program is suitable for students interested in careers that benefit from a chemical foundation, such as teaching, technical sales, environmental science, patent law, science writing, or various health professions. It also provides a solid preparation for graduate studies in chemistry or related fields, especially when supplemented with additional advanced coursework. Students completing the B.A. program will be prepared to critically analyze chemical problems, understand fundamental chemical principles, and apply laboratory techniques effectively.
ScholarshipAmount: Varies, ranges from $1,000/year to full tuition

EnglishScore: If your native language is not English, you are required to take one of the following exams and meet the minimum score requirement: TOEFL (80), IELTS (6.5), Duolingo (105), or PTE (53).
Requirements: To be considered for admission, you should have a strong college preparatory curriculum including: 4 units of English, 4 units of social studies, 3 units of mathematics (4 units are recommended), 3 units of science (4 units are recommended), and 2 or 3 units of a foreign language.
Description:
The undergraduate program in Chemistry has as its goal the education of students in the fundamental principles of chemistry and biochemistry and the development of their ability to understand and to apply these principles to current problems in science and technology. This goal is accomplished through a balanced curriculum of lecture and laboratory courses that leads to a Bachelor of Science (BS) degree in Chemistry, a BS degree in Biochemistry, or a BA degree in Chemistry.
The department also offers a Minor in Chemistry. Students may participate in research and may earn academic credit for such work, including independent work with faculty.
The BS degree in Chemistry has three areas of study: Standard, Environmental Chemistry, and Chemical Physics. The BS in Chemistry with a Chemical Physics specialization is administered by the Department of Chemistry in cooperation with the Department of Physics and Astronomy. The BS in Biochemistry is described under Biochemistry, and the BA in Chemistry is described under Chemistry, B.A.
ScholarshipAmount: Merit scholarships range up to $10,000 per year

ProgramName: Bachelor of Engineering in Civil Engineering
EnglishScore: For international applicants where English is not their native language, proof of proficiency is required. This can be demonstrated by submitting a minimum score from one of the following tests: TOEFL iBT (80), IELTS (6.5), Duolingo English Test (105), PTE Academic (53), or through completion of ELS Level 112.
Requirements: Students who have completed the prerequisites with grades of C or higher and have a GPA of 3.2 in all mathematics, physics, and chemistry courses applicable to the major requirements and an overall GPA of 3.0 may be admitted to the Civil Engineering major.
Department: College of Engineering and Applied Sciences
Description: The Civil Engineering program provides students with a strong background in the scientific and mathematical principles underlying civil engineering, while developing in them an ability to integrate these principles into the design and analysis of civil engineering systems. It emphasizes fundamental concepts and their application to a variety of areas of civil engineering practice including: structural engineering, geotechnical engineering, transportation engineering, environmental engineering, and water resources engineering. The program prepares students for careers in the various specialties of civil engineering and for graduate study. The program curriculum is designed to satisfy the requirements for accreditation by the Engineering Accreditation Commission of ABET.
Accredidation: Designed to satisfy the requirements for accreditation by the Engineering Accreditation Commission of ABET.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Climate Science
EnglishScore: If your native language is not English, you will be required to provide proof of English proficiency by providing official scores from one of the following exams: TOEFL (minimum 80 iBT), IELTS (minimum 6.5), Duolingo (minimum 105), or PTE Academic (minimum 53).
Requirements: To apply for first-year admission, please submit the following: Common Application or Coalition Application, powered by Scoir; Official High School Transcript(s); One Teacher/Counselor Recommendation; Standardized Test Scores (SAT/ACT); Application Fee or Fee Waiver. Stony Brook is test-optional, meaning you have the choice to submit SAT or ACT scores with your application.
Department: School of Marine and Atmospheric Sciences
Description: The Bachelor of Science (BS) in Climate Science provides a comprehensive understanding of the Earth’s climate system, its variability, and human impacts on climate. The curriculum emphasizes quantitative skills and hands-on experience in analyzing and interpreting climate data and models. Students learn about the fundamental physical and chemical processes that govern the atmosphere, oceans, and land surface, as well as the interactions among these components. The program prepares students for graduate studies in climate science or related fields, as well as for careers in government agencies, environmental consulting firms, and non-profit organizations focused on climate change research, mitigation, and adaptation.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Clinical Laboratory Sciences
EnglishScore: If your native language is not English, you must demonstrate English proficiency. Stony Brook accepts the TOEFL, IELTS, Duolingo, and PTE academic tests. Our minimum score requirements are: 80 on the TOEFL iBT, 6.5 on the IELTS, 105 on the Duolingo, and 53 on the PTE.
Requirements: Completed applications are reviewed by the CLS Admissions Committee. The following documents must be submitted to the Office of Student Services by the February 1st deadline: 1. A completed Stony Brook University Health Professions (SHP) application. This application is available on the School of Health Professions Office of Student Services website. 2. Application fee of $100.00. 3. Two letters of recommendation from college professors or other professionals who are familiar with the applicant’s academic ability and/or work performance. 4. Official transcripts from ALL colleges and universities attended. 5. A personal statement indicating why you are choosing the CLS profession. 6. International applicants who have completed their post-secondary education in a non-English speaking country must take the TOEFL or IELTS exam.
Description:
Clinical Laboratory Scientists (CLS), sometimes called medical technologists or medical laboratory scientists, are an integral part of the healthcare team. Working in hospital, public health, and private clinical laboratories, these professionals perform and analyze a wide variety of laboratory tests used in the detection, diagnosis, and treatment of disease and in the maintenance of health.
The Bachelor of Science in Clinical Laboratory Sciences program prepares students to become highly skilled Clinical Laboratory Scientists, who are proficient in all areas of the clinical laboratory, including clinical chemistry, hematology, immunology, immunohematology (blood bank), and microbiology. Graduates are eligible to take national certification examinations and New York State licensure examinations to qualify them for employment.
Accredidation: Accredited by the National Accrediting Agency for Clinical Laboratory Sciences (NAACLS), 5600 N. River Rd, Suite 720 Rosemont IL 60018-5119, (773) 714-8880.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Coastal Environmental Studies
EnglishScore: If your native language is not English, you will need to take a test to demonstrate your English proficiency. Stony Brook accepts the TOEFL, IELTS, Duolingo, and PTE tests. Minimum score requirements: TOEFL: 80 (iBT); IELTS: 6.5; Duolingo: 105; PTE: 53. Completion of the ELS Language Center's Level 112 will also be accepted.
Requirements: Prospective students must apply using either the Common Application or the Coalition Application. Required application materials include an official high school transcript, a letter of recommendation from a school counselor, a teacher evaluation/recommendation, and a personal essay. Stony Brook is test-optional, meaning SAT or ACT scores are not required for admission.
Department: School of Marine and Atmospheric Sciences
Description: The B.S. in Coastal Environmental Studies (CES) is a multi-disciplinary major intended for students interested in a scientific understanding of coastal environments and the impacts of human activities on them. Students must declare one of four specializations: Conservation and Restoration, Human Dimensions of Coastal Environments, Coastal Water and Ecosystem Health, or Coastal Geology and Geophysics. Located on the North Shore of Long Island, Stony Brook University offers an ideal location for the study of coastal environments. Access to Long Island Sound, the Atlantic Ocean, and many bays, estuaries, and wetlands, combined with dedicated research vessels and state-of-the-art facilities, provide many opportunities for students to participate in hands-on field and lab research. The CES major is a joint program between the School of Marine and Atmospheric Sciences (SoMAS) and the College of Arts and Sciences (CAS). Its multi-disciplinary nature makes it an excellent choice for students interested in graduate school or careers in environmental research, policy, and management.
ScholarshipAmount: Varies; up to full-tuition scholarships available (e.g., Presidential Scholarship)

EnglishScore: International applicants for whom English is not their native language must demonstrate proficiency by submitting one of the following: a minimum score of 80 on the TOEFL internet-based test (iBT), a minimum composite score of 6.5 on the IELTS, a minimum score of 105 on the Duolingo English Test (DET), or a minimum score of 53 on the PTE Academic. Exemptions may apply based on SAT/ACT scores or previous education in an English-speaking country.
Requirements: To be considered for admission, applicants must submit either the Common Application or SUNY Application, an application fee or fee waiver, official high school transcript(s), and one letter of recommendation from a teacher or counselor. Submission of SAT/ACT scores is optional.
Description: The Bachelor of Arts (B.A.) program in Communication provides students with a broad knowledge of human communication processes. Students develop an understanding of communication across a variety of contexts, including interpersonal, small group, organizational, rhetorical, and intercultural settings, and acquire skills that allow them to analyze, evaluate, and produce effective and ethical communication. The program provides the foundations for understanding the production, content, and effects of communication as well as communication in new media. It is designed to develop students’ abilities to critically assess different perspectives and theories, engage in ethical reasoning, conduct and interpret communication research, and apply acquired knowledge to solve problems in real-world settings. Communication majors are prepared for a range of professional careers in fields such as business, education, government, healthcare, law, non-profit management, and public service, or for advanced graduate study.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Engineering in Computer Engineering
EnglishScore: Applicants whose native language is not English must demonstrate English proficiency. Official test scores must be sent directly from the testing agency. Stony Brook's school code for the TOEFL is 2548. Minimum scores required for admission: TOEFL: 80, IELTS: 6.5, Duolingo English Test (DET): 105, PTE Academic: 53.
Requirements: All first-year students must submit the following: Common Application or Coalition Application, powered by Scoir; $50 non-refundable application fee; Official high school transcript; One letter of recommendation from a teacher or counselor; Essay; SAT or ACT Scores (Test-Optional).
Department: College of Engineering and Applied Sciences
Description: The Bachelor of Engineering (B.E.) in Computer Engineering program provides students with a strong foundation in digital hardware design, computer architecture, computer networks, and embedded systems, with an emphasis on both hardware and software aspects of computer systems. Graduates of the program are well-prepared for careers in various industries, including software development, hardware design, embedded systems, and cybersecurity, as well as for graduate studies in computer engineering or related fields.
Accredidation: Both the Electrical Engineering and Computer Engineering undergraduate programs at Stony Brook University are accredited by the Engineering Accreditation Commission of ABET, www.abet.org.
ScholarshipAmount: Varies by scholarship, e.g., $2,000 per year up to full tuition

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Computer Science
EnglishScore: If English is not your native language, you must demonstrate English proficiency. You may do so by providing the results of the Test of English as a Foreign Language (TOEFL), International English Language Testing System (IELTS), Duolingo English Test (DET), or the Pearson Test of English (PTE).
Requirements: First-year applicants must submit a Common Application or Coalition Application, a $50 non-refundable application fee, an official high school transcript, and one teacher/counselor recommendation (up to three will be reviewed). For applicants to majors in the College of Engineering and Applied Sciences, such as Computer Science, calculus is required. Stony Brook is test-optional for the Spring 2024 and Fall 2024 application cycles, meaning students can choose whether or to submit SAT or ACT scores as part of their application.
Department: College of Engineering and Applied Sciences
Description: The Bachelor of Science (BS) program in Computer Science is accredited by the Computing Accreditation Commission of ABET, http://www.abet.org. The BS program prepares students for careers in computer science or for graduate study. The program requires a total of 120 credits. Requirements for the BS in Computer Science include a set of core courses, a statistics requirement, upper-division computer science courses, technical electives, and a written communication course. In addition to the Computer Science major requirements, students must also satisfy the University’s general education requirements (SBC) and earn at least 120 credits total.
Accredidation: Accredited by the Computing Accreditation Commission of ABET, http://www.abet.org.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Fine Arts in Creative Writing
EnglishScore: Applicants whose native language is not English must demonstrate proficiency. Stony Brook accepts the TOEFL, IELTS, Duolingo, and PTE academic tests. The minimum required TOEFL iBT score is 80, the minimum IELTS score is 6.5, the minimum Duolingo score is 105, and the minimum PTE score is 53. The English proficiency test requirement may be waived under certain conditions, such as specific SAT/ACT scores or attendance at a school where English is the language of instruction.
Requirements: Admission to the Creative Writing and Literature major is competitive and is by application only. Application materials may be obtained in the Creative Writing Program Office, 2042 Humanities. To be considered for admission into the major, students must have: 1. A grade of B or higher in CWL 202 Introduction to Creative Writing. 2. A sample of the student's creative work (no more than ten pages of prose or poetry). 3. A short application form (available from the Creative Writing Program Office).
Description: The Bachelor of Fine Arts in Creative Writing provides students with an intensive undergraduate course of study in the writing of fiction, poetry, and screenwriting. It is designed to prepare students for careers in writing, publishing, journalism, teaching, and for graduate study in creative writing. The program offers workshops at the beginning and advanced level, as well as courses in literary theory, history, and practice. The curriculum requires students to take courses in a variety of literary forms and to complete a significant amount of coursework in literature. The BFA in Creative Writing requires 60 credits in creative writing and literature courses, with a minimum of 36 credits in creative writing workshops. Students must take courses in fiction, poetry, and screenwriting, and must complete an advanced workshop in at least two genres. The program culminates in a senior thesis, a substantial work of creative writing in the student’s chosen genre, completed under the guidance of a faculty mentor. Students are encouraged to participate in literary internships and to take advantage of the many literary events and readings offered through the English Department and the College of Arts and Sciences.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Data Science
EnglishScore: For international students where English is not their native language, one of the following exams is required: TOEFL (minimum score of 80), IELTS (minimum score of 6.5), Duolingo (minimum score of 105), or PTE (minimum score of 53).
