Description: The Minor in China Studies provides students with an opportunity to gain an interdisciplinary understanding of China and Chinese culture, society, history, language, and politics. Students completing the minor will have an understanding of the diversity and dynamism of Chinese civilization and its relationship to the modern world.

Requirements: Completion of the minor requires 18 credits. All courses offered for the minor must be passed with a letter grade of C or higher. At least nine credits applied to the minor must be in courses numbered 300 or higher.
Description: A minor in Classics provides students with the opportunity to achieve familiarity with the classical languages and civilization of ancient Greece and Rome. This minor provides a foundation in classical studies and an introduction to the methodologies employed in the study of classical civilization. The minor will be of value to students majoring in a wide variety of subjects, including humanities, social sciences, and the natural sciences. Students interested in the minor should consult the Undergraduate Director of the Department of Classics. All courses for the minor must be taken for a letter grade. Completion of the minor requires 21 credits. Students must complete a minimum of 9 credits in courses at or above the 300-level. No more than 6 transfer credits may be applied to the minor.

Requirements: Completion of the minor requires 21 credits. All courses taken for the minor must be passed with a letter grade of C or higher. At least 12 of the 21 credits must be from courses in the School of Marine and Atmospheric Sciences (ATM, MAR, CSO). Students should declare the minor in Climate Solutions no later than the first semester of their junior year. Before declaring the minor, students should meet with the undergraduate program director.
Department: School of Marine and Atmospheric Sciences
Description: The Minor in Climate Solutions is designed to provide students with foundational knowledge of Earth's climate system, the impacts of climate change, and various mitigation and adaptation strategies. It is an interdisciplinary minor drawing on courses from across the University and is suitable for any major. The minor will help students develop a comprehensive understanding of the scientific, social, economic, and policy dimensions of climate change. Students will gain analytical and critical thinking skills to evaluate climate-related challenges and propose solutions, preparing them for careers in sustainability, environmental policy, research, and other related fields, or for further graduate study.

Requirements: Students should declare the minor in Coastal Environmental Studies by the beginning of their junior year to ensure that they can complete all requirements. Declaration forms are available at the Undergraduate Program Director’s office, 105 Endeavour Hall (632-8674).
Department: School of Marine and Atmospheric Sciences
Description: Coastal environments are among the most dynamic and productive ecosystems on Earth, but they are also among the most threatened by human impacts. This interdepartmental Minor is designed to provide students with a broad understanding of the scientific, social, economic, and policy issues relevant to the sustainable management and conservation of coastal environments. It is a perfect complement to a wide range of majors including marine sciences, environmental studies, biology, geology, political science, economics, and business. The Minor is open to all students, and provides both a strong foundation for students interested in graduate studies or careers in coastal environmental management, and a valuable addition to the education of students interested in environmental issues.

Requirements: To declare the minor, students must have a cumulative grade point average of 2.5. The minor in Communication requires 18 credits. All courses taken for the minor must be passed with a letter grade of C or higher. Requirements are as follows: COM 100 Introduction to Communication, COM 205 Interpersonal Communication, COM 207 Communication Theory. Nine additional credits in COM at the 300 or 400 level.
Description: Communication is a broad field, encompassing a wide array of theoretical approaches and applied practices. The field is typically defined by its focus on the processes, messages, contexts, and effects of human communication. The Communication minor will give students an interdisciplinary perspective on the study of communication and allow them to gain a theoretical and analytical foundation, including an understanding of current topics and debates. Upon completion of the Communication minor, students will be able to: 1. Understand and apply fundamental theories, concepts, and approaches in the study of communication. 2. Identify and describe current topics and debates in the field of communication. 3. Apply communication theories and concepts to analyze and address specific communication issues, problems, and situations. 4. Demonstrate a fundamental understanding of relevant ethical issues in communication. 5. Critically evaluate and synthesize information from a variety of sources related to communication.

Requirements: Completion of the minor requires 18 credits. All courses must be passed with a letter grade of C or higher. Students must have a G.P.A. of 3.0 or better to be accepted into the minor.
Description: The Minor in Communication and Innovation (CMI) is an interdisciplinary program designed to equip students with critical skills and perspectives for understanding, engaging with, and shaping communication in a rapidly evolving technological landscape. This minor emphasizes the interplay between communication theory, digital technologies, and societal impact. Students will explore how new media and innovative tools transform human interaction, public discourse, and organizational practices. Through a blend of theoretical coursework and practical application, students will develop competencies in areas such as digital storytelling, media analytics, strategic communication, and ethical considerations in technological innovation. The CMI minor aims to prepare students for diverse career paths in fields like digital marketing, media production, public relations, technology policy, and user experience design, by fostering adaptability, critical thinking, and creativity essential for navigating the complexities of the 21st-century communication environment.

Requirements: Completion of the minor requires a minimum of 22 credits. All courses taken for the minor must be passed with a letter grade of C or higher. Students must have a g.p.a. of 3.2 in the courses CSE 114, 214, 215 to be admitted to the minor. For an automatic approval of the minor declaration, students must have a GPA of 3.2 or higher in CSE 114, CSE 214 and CSE 215, and have a C or higher in each of these courses. All other students are admitted on a space-available basis.
Department: College of Engineering and Applied Sciences
Description: The Computer Science Minor provides a basic understanding of computer science concepts, programming, and problem-solving techniques. It is designed for students in other disciplines who wish to acquire a foundation in computer science to complement their major fields of study. The minor requires a minimum of 20 credits, including specific courses in programming, data structures, and computer organization, along with elective credits in computer science. This minor enhances a student's analytical and technical skills, making them more competitive in a technology-driven world.

Requirements: Students wishing to declare a minor in Creative Writing must have a cumulative grade point average of at least 3.00 and have completed CWL 202 with a grade of B or higher. Students should fill out the Minor Declaration Form available in the Creative Writing and Literature office, Humanities 2089, by appointment. The form should be submitted to the undergraduate program director.
Description:
The Minor in Creative Writing consists of 21 credits beyond the introductory course. All courses for the minor must be taken for a letter grade and passed with a grade of C or higher. A maximum of 6 credits may be transferred from another institution. No more than 6 credits may be double counted with a student's major, and no more than 3 credits may be double counted with another minor.

Students wishing to pursue the Minor in Creative Writing should consult the undergraduate director of Creative Writing.

Completion of the minor requires a minimum cumulative GPA of 2.50 in the courses applied to the minor.

Requirements: Students should declare the minor in Digital Arts by the end of the first semester of their junior year. To declare the minor, students should fill out a Declaration of Major/Minor Form and submit to the Director of the Digital Arts Minor.
Description: The minor in Digital Arts provides students with an opportunity to gain an understanding of the concepts and techniques for creating art using digital media. Students who complete the minor will have fundamental skills in one or more digital arts areas (e.g., imaging, animation, web, games, interactive art, 3D modeling, digital fabrication).

ProgramName: Minor in Ecosystems and Human Impact
Requirements: Students should declare the minor in Ecosystems and Human Impact (EHI) no later than the first semester of the junior year. Declaration forms may be obtained from the SoMAS Undergraduate Director's Office. All courses must be passed with a grade of C or higher. No more than one course (or 4 credits) may be taken under the Pass/NC option. At least nine credits of the minor must be from courses offered by SoMAS (ATM, ENS, MAR, MTD, etc.).
Department: School of Marine and Atmospheric Sciences
Description: The minor in Ecosystems and Human Impact provides students with the fundamental understanding of how ecosystems function and how human activities affect the sustainability of ecosystems and the services they provide. The minor focuses on critical analysis of environmental issues and emphasizes the interdisciplinary and multidisciplinary nature of environmental problem solving. The courses in the minor cover topics related to population dynamics, ecological communities, energy flow, biogeochemical cycles, human demography, global climate change, conservation biology, ecosystem restoration, environmental policy, and environmental justice. This minor can complement a wide range of majors including those in the natural sciences, social sciences, engineering, and humanities. It is designed for students who are interested in pursuing careers related to environmental sustainability, conservation, policy, or education.

Requirements: All courses taken for the minor must be passed with a letter grade of C or higher. Completion of the minor requires a minimum of 22 credits. 1. Required Courses: ESE 124, ESE 211, ESE 224, ESE 271. 2. Electives: At least two courses from the following: ESE 272, ESE 273, ESE 280, ESE 300, ESE 301, ESE 304, ESE 305, ESE 306, ESE 311, ESE 314, ESE 315, ESE 323, ESE 324, ESE 330, ESE 337, ESE 340, ESE 341, ESE 343, ESE 344, ESE 345, ESE 347, ESE 350, ESE 352, ESE 355, ESE 356, ESE 358, ESE 360, ESE 363, ESE 366, ESE 372, ESE 380, ESE 381, ESE 382.
Department: College of Engineering and Applied Sciences
Description: The minor in Electrical Engineering is intended for students who wish to gain a basic understanding of electrical engineering principles. It requires 21 credits of coursework focusing on the fundamental concepts of electrical circuits, electronics, and digital systems. Students will learn how to analyze and design simple electrical and electronic circuits, understand the operation of basic digital systems, and gain hands-on experience through laboratory work. The minor provides a strong foundation for students interested in careers or graduate studies in fields that integrate electrical engineering concepts.
ScholarshipAmount: Varies; for example, the Presidential Scholarship is $10,000 per year.

Requirements: The minor in English consists of 21 credits (seven 3-credit courses). All courses must be passed with a letter grade of C or higher. A maximum of one course may be transferred. The requirements are as follows: 1. EGL 204. 2. One course in British literature before 1800. 3. One course in American literature before 1900. 4. Four additional EGL courses at the 200, 300, or 400 level.
Description: The minor in English allows students to focus on areas of interest to them within the discipline while providing them with the valuable analytical, critical reading, and communication skills for which the study of literature is especially renowned. Students choose from a range of courses in literary study, critical theory, and writing. Courses in the English major are open to English minors; many count toward the minor requirements.

ProgramName: Minor in Environmental Design, Policy, and Planning
Requirements: Completion of the minor requires 21 credits. A grade of C or higher is required in all courses applied to the minor. Students should declare the minor by the time they are in their junior year. For more information, students should contact the undergraduate program director or the faculty director.
Description: This minor introduces students to the challenges of achieving environmental sustainability within diverse geographic and cultural settings, and to the analytical and practical tools that can be used to meet these challenges. The minor is offered jointly by the Sustainability Studies Program, the Department of Urban and Community Studies, and the Department of Ecology and Evolution. The Environmental Design, Policy, and Planning minor is an interdisciplinary program designed to give students a comprehensive understanding of sustainable practices and environmental issues. Students will learn about environmental planning, policy-making, and design principles, providing them with a foundation to address complex environmental problems. This minor is suitable for students interested in careers in environmental management, urban planning, policy analysis, and related fields.
ScholarshipAmount: $1,000 - $2,500 per year; some awards cover full tuition

Requirements:
All courses taken for the minor must be passed with a letter grade of C or higher. Completion of the minor requires 21 credits.

Required Courses (9 credits):

ESG 100 Introduction to Engineering Science
ESG 201 Engineering and Technology in Society
CIV 210 Surveying
One of the following (3 credits):

GEO 102 The Earth
GEO 103 The Earth through Time
Three of the following (9 credits):

CIV 330 Water Supply and Wastewater Treatment Design
CIV 331 Hydrologic and Hydraulic Design
CIV 333 Coastal Engineering
ESG 302 Thermodynamics of Materials
MEC 260 Engineering Statics
Department: College of Engineering and Applied Sciences
Fees: NY State Resident: $7,070/year; Out-of-State: $28,340/year. Additional Engineering & Applied Science Fee of $845/year.
Description: The Minor in Environmental Engineering is designed to provide students with a fundamental background in environmental engineering principles related to water resources, air pollution, solid/hazardous waste, and environmental site assessment and remediation. The minor provides students with the fundamentals of environmental engineering analysis and design required to pursue a career or graduate studies in environmental engineering or environmental science. This minor is open to all students.
CollegeApplicationFee: NY State Resident: $7,070/year; Out-of-State: $28,340/year. Additional Engineering & Applied Science Fee of $845/year.

Description: Environmental Humanities is an interdisciplinary field that brings the insights of the humanities (philosophy, history, literature, cultural studies, ethics, media studies, religious studies, and the arts) to bear on the problems and questions posed by environmental change. It offers students the opportunity to explore the human dimensions of environmental issues such as climate change, biodiversity loss, pollution, and resource depletion, providing a crucial complement to scientific and technical approaches. The Minor will introduce students to the diverse methodologies and approaches of the Environmental Humanities and develop their capacities for critical inquiry, analytical thinking, and ethical engagement with the challenges of the Anthropocene. Students will learn to analyze environmental issues through various lenses, including historical context, cultural representation, ethical frameworks, and philosophical inquiry, thereby fostering a deeper understanding of the complex interplay between human societies and the natural world.

Requirements: To be eligible to declare the minor, students must have completed at least one course that can be used to fulfill the requirements for the minor with a grade of C or higher.
Department: School of Marine and Atmospheric Sciences
Description: The minor in Environmental Studies is an interdisciplinary minor designed to provide students with the opportunity to pursue an interest in environmental issues as a complement to their major program of study. The minor requires a minimum of 21 credits selected from an approved list of courses offered by departments across the University. Students must complete a minimum of three credits from at least three different departments. For more information regarding course selection for the Environmental Studies minor, students should contact the faculty director or the undergraduate program director in the School of Marine and Atmospheric Sciences.

Requirements: The minor in Ethnomusicology requires a minimum of 21 credits. All courses must be passed with a letter grade of C or higher. A minimum of 12 credits must be from upper-division courses (300-level or higher). A maximum of three credits of MUS 487 may be used to satisfy the requirements for the minor. Required Courses (9 credits): MUS 119 Introduction to World Music Cultures, MUS 250 Theory and Practice of Ethnomusicology, MUS 350 Ethnography of Music, MUS 450 Advanced Studies in Ethnomusicology. Electives (12 credits): Students must complete an additional four courses (12 credits) selected from the following list: MUS 318, MUS 325, MUS 326, MUS 327, MUS 328, MUS 329, MUS 487, AFS 375, AAS 380, LLL 320.
Description: The Minor in Ethnomusicology provides students with an introduction to the interdisciplinary study of world musics and associated cultures. It emphasizes the critical relationship between music, sound, and the human experience, examining diverse musical traditions within their cultural and social contexts. Students will explore theoretical frameworks and methodologies used in ethnomusicology, including fieldwork, ethnographic research, and sound studies. Through courses in various world musical traditions (e.g., African, Asian, Latin American, Middle Eastern), students will develop a broad understanding of global musical diversity and its significance. The minor encourages critical listening skills, cultural sensitivity, and an appreciation for the role of music in shaping identity, community, and social change. It complements studies in music, anthropology, sociology, cultural studies, and global affairs, providing valuable perspectives for students interested in careers in arts, education, international relations, and cultural heritage.
CostPerCredit: NYS Resident Part-time (per credit): $295; Non-Resident Part-time (per credit): $1,181
ScholarshipType: Merit-Based Scholarships, Departmental Scholarships, External Scholarships

ProgramName: Minor in Film and Screen Studies
Requirements: To declare the minor, students must meet with one of the Film and Screen Studies co-directors to discuss their interests and plan a program of study. The minor must be declared before the student has completed 12 credits of coursework applicable to the minor.
Description: The Minor in Film and Screen Studies is an interdepartmental minor with offerings in the departments of Cultural Analysis and Theory (College of Arts and Sciences) and English (College of Arts and Sciences). It introduces students to film and television as artistic, cultural, and industrial forms, as well as to their historical development and theoretical approaches. Courses in the minor focus on the aesthetic, social, and cultural analysis of film and screen media, and they are typically drawn from the fields of Film Studies, Media Studies, Literary and Cultural Studies, and Art History. The minor is suitable for students pursuing a wide range of majors in the humanities, social sciences, and arts, and it can enrich students’ understanding of the pervasive influence of screen media on contemporary culture.

Requirements: The Minor in Filmmaking is open to all undergraduate students. Students must declare the Minor in Filmmaking no later than the first semester of their junior year. Interested students should meet with the Minor Director to plan a course of study. Completion of the minor requires 21 credits.
Description: The Minor in Filmmaking is designed for students who want to develop their knowledge and skills in film and media production. Students will learn the fundamentals of screenwriting, directing, producing, cinematography, editing, and sound design across a variety of genres and formats, including narrative, documentary, and experimental film. The program emphasizes hands-on experience and critical thinking about film as an art form and a medium of communication.

Requirements: Completion of ECO 108 with a grade of C or higher. Completion of AMS 102 or AMS 110 or MAT 125 or MAT 131 or MAT 141 with a grade of C or higher. A minimum g.p.a. of 3.2 is required to declare the minor.
Description: The minor in Finance allows students who are not majoring in Business Management to gain an understanding of the concepts, theories, institutions, and analytical tools associated with financial markets, instruments, and decisions. The minor is appropriate for students interested in careers in finance, and for those who wish to enhance their business knowledge to complement other career interests. Students completing the minor will have a solid foundation in the principles of financial management, investments, and financial markets.
CollegeApplicationFee: $1,591.50 per semester (Broad-Based Fees for full-time undergraduates, 2023-2024 rates)

Requirements: Completion of the minor requires 18 credits in French beyond FRN 212. All courses must be passed with a letter grade of C or higher. Up to six credits from a Study Abroad program may be applied to the minor with approval of the undergraduate program director.
Description: The minor in French will afford students the opportunity to complement their major studies with a deeper insight into French and Francophone language, literature and cultures, providing them with a strong basis in French that can be applied to a variety of areas of study including careers in education, communication, business, law and global studies.
ScholarshipAmount: Varies (e.g., Presidential Scholarship covers full NYS resident tuition; Provost's Scholarship is $2,500/year)
ScholarshipPercentage: 70% of first-year students received grants and/or scholarships

Requirements: The minor in Geology is open to all students. Completion of the minor requires 21 credits. 1. Two of the following courses with labs: * GEO 102/112 The Earth * GEO 103 The Earth through Time * GEO 122 Physical Geology. 2. Four upper-division GEO courses, at least three of which must be at the 300 level or higher. GEO 310, Introduction to Geophysics, is recommended. The department chairperson may substitute courses from other departments where appropriate. At least 12 credits of the minor must be taken at Stony Brook.
Description: A minor in Geology provides students with an understanding of Earth processes including volcanism, earthquakes, mountain building, the rock cycle, evolution of life, global change, and natural resources. These studies are critical for careers in environmental studies, natural resources, engineering, earth science teaching, and basic research. It is possible to earn a minor in Geology by completing 20 credits in Geosciences as outlined below. Students must fulfill University General Education requirements within their major.

Requirements: The minor in Geospatial Science is open to all undergraduate students at Stony Brook. Students who are interested in the minor should contact Professor E. Troy Rasbury.
Description: The Geospatial Science minor is an interdepartmental minor in the College of Arts and Sciences designed to provide students with foundational knowledge of spatial information science and spatial data analysis. This minor provides students with skills in Geographic Information Systems (GIS), remote sensing, cartography, and spatial statistics which are in high demand in a wide range of fields including environmental science, urban planning, public health, business, and social sciences. The minor also prepares students for further graduate study in geospatial science.

ProgramName: Minor in Globalization Studies and International Relations
Requirements: Students should declare the minor as early as possible and no later than the first semester of their senior year. Declaration forms may be obtained from the Globalization Studies and International Relations office, and are also available at http://www.stonybrook.edu/global.
Fees: New York State residents: $7,070/Year; Out-of-state residents: $26,910/Year
Description: The Minor in Globalization Studies and International Relations, administered by the Department of Political Science, is an interdisciplinary program designed for students seeking to understand the nature and scope of globalization in its political, economic, historical, and cultural dimensions. Students explore the connections between globalization and international relations and analyze the challenges and opportunities posed by an increasingly interconnected world. The program also examines the impact of globalization on various regions of the world, including the United States. Students gain an understanding of global challenges, such as sustainable development, human rights, global health, and international conflict, and develop critical thinking skills necessary to engage with complex global issues. The minor complements a wide range of majors in the social sciences, humanities, and fine arts.
CostPerCredit: New York State residents: $295/Credit; Out-of-state residents: $1,121/Credit
CollegeApplicationFee: New York State residents: $7,070/Year; Out-of-state residents: $26,910/Year
ScholarshipAmount: Varies; for example, the Presidential Scholarship is $10,000 per year.

ProgramName: Minor in Health, Medicine, and Society
Requirements: To declare the minor, students must complete the Undergraduate Minor Declaration Form, which is available on the Registrar's website.
Description: The Minor in Health, Medicine, and Society (HMS) offers students the opportunity to examine the social dimensions of health, illness, and healthcare systems. Using sociological perspectives, students learn to critically analyze health and healthcare issues that are increasingly relevant to our society and daily lives. This minor is designed for students interested in careers in healthcare, public health, medicine, social work, public policy, or research, as well as students seeking to broaden their understanding of health, illness, and society.

Requirements: Declaration of the minor is open to all students in good academic standing. The minor requires the completion of 24 credits, including the four-course language sequence in Modern Greek (HLL 101, HLL 102, HLL 201, and HLL 202) and two courses (six credits) from the list of electives below. All courses taken for the minor must be passed with a letter grade of C or higher.
Description: The Minor in Hellenic Studies provides students with the opportunity to explore the rich culture of Greece, ancient, Byzantine, and modern. It offers a structured introduction to the fields of Greek history, art, language, literature, philosophy, and religion through a variety of courses offered by several departments. The minor is suitable for students who wish to pursue their interest in Greek culture and complement their major field of study. It is also designed for students who want to prepare for graduate study in Hellenic Studies.
ScholarshipAmount: Varies; e.g., Presidential Scholarships provide $10,000 per year, others range from $1,000 to full-tuition.

Requirements: Students should declare the minor in History as early as possible and no later than the first semester of their junior year. Forms for this purpose are available from the Director of Undergraduate Studies in the Department of History.

ProgramName: Minor in History of Health, Science, and the Environment
Requirements: Completion of the minor requires 18 credits. All courses must be passed with a grade of C or higher. At least 12 of the 18 credits must be in courses at the 300 level or higher. Required Course: HIS 290: Topics in the History of Health, Science, and the Environment. Electives: 15 credits selected from the following list, at least 9 of which must be at the 300-level or higher. No more than one course from outside the History Department will be counted toward the minor. Other courses may be accepted by petition to the undergraduate director. List of courses: AFS 368/WST 368, AMS 318, BCP 405, BIO 358, ENV 301, HIS 214, HIS 244, HIS 317, HIS 343, HIS 368, HIS 379/SOC 379, HIS 392, HIS 398, PHI 383, POL 310, SOC 340, SOC 344, WST 392.
Description: The History of Health, Science, and the Environment minor explores how different societies have understood and interacted with disease, bodies, nature, and the cosmos from ancient times to the present. The program is explicitly interdisciplinary, drawing on a range of fields including history, philosophy, sociology, anthropology, and journalism. Students will learn how to analyze the historical development of science, technology, and medicine; trace the shifting conceptions of health, illness, and the body; examine the evolving relationship between humans and the natural world; and consider the ethical, social, and political implications of scientific and technological change.

Requirements: Declaration of the minor requires a cumulative grade point average of 3.00.
Department: College of Engineering and Applied Sciences
Description: Industrial engineering is concerned with the design, improvement, and installation of integrated systems of people, materials, information, equipment, and energy. Industrial engineers apply specialized knowledge and skills in the mathematical, physical, and social sciences, together with the principles and methods of engineering analysis and design, to specify, predict, and evaluate the results to be obtained from such systems.

Requirements:
All courses required for the minor must be taken for a letter grade and passed with a grade of C or higher. Completion of the minor requires 21 credits.

Required Courses:
ISE 108 Fundamentals of IT or CSE 101 Computer Science Principles
ISE 208 Object Oriented Programming in Java
ISE 218 Fundamentals of Network & Data Communications
ISE 305 Database Design and Practice
ISE 316 Software Engineering
ISE 321 Introduction to Information Systems Security
One upper-division elective course from the following list: ISE 300, ISE 304, ISE 306, ISE 311, ISE 312, ISE 320, ISE 323, ISE 325, ISE 331, ISE 332, ISE 364.
Description: The Minor in Information Systems provides students with an understanding of how information systems are developed, deployed, and managed. Information systems are the backbone of modern organizations, and professionals with expertise in information systems are in high demand across all industries. This minor is open to all undergraduate students. The minor requires a total of 21 credits. Students must complete five required courses (15 credits) and two elective courses (6 credits). A minimum grade of C must be achieved in all courses used to fulfill the minor requirements. Completion of the minor will be noted on the student’s official transcript.
ScholarshipAmount: Varies (e.g., $1,000, $2,500, up to full tuition per year)
ScholarshipType: Merit-based, need-based, or other specific criteria

Requirements: The minor in Italian American Studies requires 18 credits, of which at least nine must be in upper-division courses. All courses offered for the minor must be passed with a letter grade of C or higher. Completion of the minor requires a g.p.a. of 2.00 in all courses applied to the minor.
Description: The minor in Italian American Studies provides an interdisciplinary approach to the study of the Italian American experience. It gives students the opportunity to examine the history, sociology, literature, and culture of Italian Americans. The minor provides a strong foundation for students interested in a variety of fields, including teaching, law, social work, journalism, and public service. It also prepares students for further academic work in Italian American Studies or related disciplines.

The Minor in Italian Studies, offered by the Department of Linguistics, consists of courses in Italian language, literature, and culture. The minor requires a minimum of 18 credits, of which at least 12 credits must be taken at Stony Brook University. Only courses in which the student has earned a grade of C or higher may be counted toward the minor. For more information, please contact the Department of Linguistics.

Requirements:
The minor in Japanese Studies requires 18 credits. A maximum of six credits may be transferred from another institution. All courses offered for the minor must be passed with a letter grade of C or higher. At least 12 of the 18 credits must be in courses numbered 300 or higher.

A. Language Requirement (6 credits)
Choose one of the following sequences:
* JPN 201 Intermediate Japanese I and JPN 202 Intermediate Japanese II
* JPN 311 Advanced Japanese I and JPN 312 Advanced Japanese II

B. Culture and Literature Requirement (9 credits)
Choose three courses from the following list. At least two of the three must be taken at Stony Brook.
* AAS 370/JPN 370 Is Japan a Post-colonial Empire?
* EGL 336/JPN 336 Asian American Film and Video
* JPN 112 Modern Japan
* JPN 215 Introduction to Japanese Culture and People
* JPN 305 Japanese Popular Culture
* JPN 330 Topics in Japanese Studies
* JPN 334 Survey of Japanese Literature
* JPN 335 Japanese Film
* JPN 410 Readings in Japanese Studies
* Relevant topics courses in AAS, ARH, CCS, EGL, HIS, PHI, SOC, THR may be accepted with the approval of the undergraduate director.

C. Upper-Division Writing Requirement
Students should consult with the department advisor to ensure that their plan for completing the Upper Division Writing Requirement is consistent with university graduation requirements for the minor. Students who are preparing to write a senior thesis or research paper are encouraged to take the JPN 410 or another 400-level course that requires a substantial research paper.

D. Grade Requirement
All courses taken for the minor must be passed with a letter grade of C or higher.
Fees: $26,890 per year for out-of-state students; $7,070 per year for NY residents.
Description: The Minor in Japanese Studies is intended to provide students with knowledge of Japanese language and culture, through a combination of language and culture/civilization courses. Students take five courses for a minimum of 18 credits. All students pursuing the minor must meet with the undergraduate advisor for Japanese to declare their interest in the minor. The minor must be completed with a minimum GPA of 2.0 in courses for the minor. Students should consult the Department of Asian and Asian American Studies website for additional information. Transfer students who wish to apply courses from other institutions toward the minor must consult with the undergraduate advisor. For information on a minor in Asian American Studies, see Asian and Asian American Studies. For information on the Major in Asian and Asian American Studies with a concentration in Japanese Studies, see Asian and Asian American Studies.

EnglishScore: As this is an undergraduate program, the English proficiency requirements are set by the university's general undergraduate admissions for international applicants. Non-native English speakers are required to provide proof of English proficiency by submitting official scores from one of several exams, including TOEFL iBT, IELTS, Duolingo English Test (DET), or PTE Academic.
Requirements: The Minor in Jazz Music provides a course of study for students who wish to pursue jazz studies to supplement their major. Declaration of the minor is available to students who have completed one semester of MUS 201 (Jazz Improvisation I) with a grade of C or better. All students wishing to enroll in Jazz Combos and/or Jazz Big Band must first perform a successful audition for the Director of Jazz Studies. Completion of the minor requires 19-20 credits.
Description: The Minor in Jazz Music provides students with an in-depth understanding of the foundations of jazz performance, history, and theory. Designed to complement majors in other disciplines, the minor enhances musical skills, cultural appreciation, and creative expression through a rigorous curriculum covering improvisation, ensemble playing, jazz history from its origins to contemporary forms, and theoretical frameworks unique to jazz. Students will develop proficiency in jazz performance and gain a comprehensive knowledge of the genre's rich cultural heritage.
ScholarshipAmount: Up to full cost of tuition

Requirements: The minor in journalism is open to all students in good standing at Stony Brook. Declaration of the minor is made through the student's major department.
Description:
The Minor in Journalism is a 21-credit program that gives students interested in journalism and related professions grounding in the practical and ethical principles of journalism. It offers training in basic news writing and reporting skills, as well as an understanding of the impact of journalism on society.
The minor is administered by the School of Communication and Journalism.
See "Courses" for a complete list of classes and descriptions.
The Minor in Journalism can be combined with any major except Journalism, and is open to any student with a cumulative grade point average of 2.50 or higher, including transfer students.
For more information, visit stonybrook.edu/journalism.
Declaration of the Minor: Students seeking to declare the minor should complete the online declaration form available on the School of Communication and Journalism website, along with any other requirements specific to the minor. Students interested in the minor should consult with the Undergraduate Program Director for advising.
ScholarshipAmount: $500 to $2,000 per year; some scholarships cover full tuition

Requirements: Students should declare the minor in Judaic Studies by the beginning of the junior year. To plan a course of study, students should consult the undergraduate program director.
Description: The Minor in Judaic Studies is an interdisciplinary program designed to give students a comprehensive background in the study of Jewish civilization and culture. The program aims to promote knowledge of Jewish history, religion, languages, literature, politics, and the arts, from antiquity to the present. The minor is suitable for students who wish to supplement their major with a substantial body of knowledge in Judaic studies. Students in the minor are encouraged to develop their interests in consultation with the department.
ScholarshipAmount: Amounts vary, e.g., Provost's Scholarship is $2,000/year, some are full-tuition.

Requirements: The minor in Korean Studies is open to all undergraduate students. Completion of the minor requires 21 credits, of which at least 12 credits must be in courses at the 300 level or higher. No more than three credits of KOR 447 may be used to satisfy the requirements of the minor. All courses must be passed with a letter grade of C or higher.
Description:
The minor in Korean Studies allows students to develop an understanding of Korean language, history, and culture and engage in a comparative study of East Asia. The minor is offered by the Department of Asian and Asian American Studies.
Students who complete the minor will be able to:
1. Demonstrate an intermediate proficiency in Korean language.
2. Demonstrate an understanding of Korean history and cultural traditions.
3. Compare and contrast Korean society and culture with other East Asian countries.
4. Interpret Korean cultural products within their historical and social contexts.

ProgramName: Minor in Latin American and Caribbean Studies
Description: The Minor in Latin American and Caribbean Studies provides an interdisciplinary and transnational approach to the study of Latin America and the Caribbean. Drawing on courses from across the social sciences and humanities, students in the Minor will gain a broad understanding of the region’s histories, cultures, politics, and economies. Students will develop an understanding of the region as a complex and diverse area connected to global processes, including migration and globalization, while also exploring specific topics such as indigenous cultures, social movements, and environmental issues. The Minor will equip students with analytical and critical thinking skills to analyze the complexities of the region and its connections to the wider world. It is open to all students and complements a variety of majors.

Requirements: Students should declare the minor in Linguistics no later than the middle of their junior year by completing the minor declaration form and submitting it to the Linguistics Undergraduate Director.

To be admitted to the minor, students must have a GPA of 3.00. The minor requires completion of a minimum of 18 credits. All courses for the minor must be passed with a letter grade of C or higher. Required courses include MEC 310, MEC 410, MEC 411, and three electives (9 credits) chosen from an approved list.
Department: College of Engineering and Applied Sciences
Description: The minor in Manufacturing Engineering provides students with an overview of the tools, techniques and strategies of modern manufacturing. The curriculum covers the materials, processes and systems of manufacturing. Topics such as conventional and advanced manufacturing processes, process planning and control, automation, and computer-integrated manufacturing are covered. Students completing the minor will have a strong foundation for careers in manufacturing and related areas such as product design, process engineering, and quality control.

Requirements: To declare a minor in Marine Sciences, students should go to the SoMAS undergraduate office in 145 Endeavour Hall. All courses taken for the minor must be passed with a letter grade of C or higher. Completion of the minor requires 18 credits. 1. MAR 101 or MAR 104; 2. 15 additional credits in MAR and ATM courses, including at least two courses at the 300 level or higher. No more than three credits of MAR 487 may be used to satisfy the requirements for the minor. The one-credit MAR 250 does not count toward the 18 total credits for the MAR minor. For Marine Science majors, only six credits of coursework may be double counted toward the MAR major and minor.
Department: School of Marine and Atmospheric Sciences
Description: The Marine Sciences minor provides an excellent opportunity for students to acquire a broad understanding of the scientific study of the oceans through courses in marine biology, chemistry, geology and physics. The minor can complement a wide variety of majors, especially those in the natural sciences, by providing students with an opportunity to integrate their primary field of study with the interdisciplinary field of marine sciences. The minor also provides students with a general introduction to the marine sciences, serving as a basis for further study in this field.
ScholarshipAmount: Scholarships range from $1,000-$2,000 per year, up to full NYS resident tuition.
ScholarshipType: Merit-based, and a combination of merit and financial need

Requirements: The minor in mass communication, offered by the School of Journalism, consists of 18 credits. A grade of C or higher in each course is required. Students must apply to the minor. Acceptance is competitive and is based on a student’s overall academic record. All students must complete an online application.
Description: The Minor in Mass Communication allows students from any major to gain a basic understanding of the role of mass media in contemporary society and to acquire practical skills in the areas of writing, researching, and producing mass communication messages. The minor is suitable for students interested in careers in advertising, public relations, journalism, corporate and non-profit communications, and media production.

Requirements: Declaration of the minor is open to all students at Stony Brook. Declaration of the minor is made in the Materials Science and Engineering office after successful completion of the prerequisite courses with grades of C or higher.
Department: College of Engineering and Applied Sciences
Description: Materials Science is an interdisciplinary field that investigates the relationships between the structure, processing, properties, and performance of materials. This minor provides an introduction to the fundamental concepts of materials science and engineering. Students will gain an understanding of different classes of materials (metals, ceramics, polymers, composites), their atomic and microscopic structures, and how these structures influence properties such as mechanical strength, electrical conductivity, and optical behavior. The minor also covers basic material processing techniques and characterization methods. It is suitable for students in various engineering and science disciplines who wish to broaden their knowledge in this essential field. The minor prepares students for entry-level positions in materials-related industries or for further study in materials science and engineering.

Requirements: Students should declare the minor in Mathematics before the start of their final semester. Application forms for the minor are available at the Mathematics Undergraduate Office.
Description: The Minor in Mathematics is for students from other disciplines who desire a stronger background in mathematics than can be obtained from the introductory calculus sequence. The minor provides a background suitable for students whose major requires substantial mathematical skills or who wish to pursue graduate work in a mathematically oriented field. Courses taken for the minor may not be taken under the Pass/No Credit option.

Requirements: The minor in Mechanical Engineering is open to all University students in good standing. Students should declare their intention to complete the minor as early as possible. To be granted the minor, students must complete the following requirements with a grade of C or higher in each course.
Department: College of Engineering and Applied Sciences
Description: The Minor in Mechanical Engineering is intended for non-ME majors who wish to demonstrate to prospective employers or graduate schools a proficiency in the fundamental principles of mechanical engineering. It provides an exposure to the various sub-disciplines within mechanical engineering, including mechanics, thermal fluids sciences, and design and manufacturing, and provides students with a solid foundation to pursue careers or further studies in these areas. Students completing the minor will have a better understanding of how devices and systems work.

Requirements: To declare a minor in Middle Eastern Studies, a student must have a G.P.A. of 2.0 or better and submit a Minor Declaration Form to the MES Undergraduate Director and the Registrar's Office.
Description: This minor is designed for students who are interested in the languages, cultures, religions, politics, and history of the Middle East, broadly defined to include North Africa, Central Asia, and the Caucasus. Students who complete the minor will gain a basic understanding of the history and development of the region, its varied cultures and societies, and its growing importance in contemporary global affairs. A wide range of courses, drawn from several departments, will enable students to choose a course of study appropriate to their individual interests. Students may choose to focus on a particular subregion, such as North Africa, or a particular topic, such as the history of a specific religion. The minor can complement a wide variety of majors, including Anthropology, Art History, Asian and Asian American Studies, Comparative Literature, History, Linguistics, Political Science, Religious Studies, Sociology, and Women's, Gender, and Sexuality Studies.

Requirements: Admission to the minor in Music is by audition with the Department of Music. Interested students should see the Undergraduate Director in the Music Department for further information and to declare the minor. Completion of the minor requires 22-25 credits. All courses offered for the minor must be passed with a letter grade of C or higher. No more than one course may be taken under the Pass/NC option. Transfer credits are not accepted toward the Music minor.
Description: The minor in music is designed to introduce students to the diverse field of music, including its history, theory, and cultural contexts. The minor complements a wide range of majors by fostering critical listening skills, creative expression, and an understanding of music's role in human experience. Students will engage with various musical traditions and develop foundational knowledge in music theory, analysis, and performance.

Requirements: To declare the Music and Technology Minor, a student must have completed MUS 119 with a B or better. Students should fill out the Minor Declaration form available at the Music Department office. Declaration must be completed before the beginning of the student's final semester. The minor requires a total of 23-24 credits. At least 12 credits must be in upper-division MUS courses. All courses taken for the minor must be passed with a letter grade of C or higher.
ScholarshipAmount: Amounts vary, some merit scholarships range from $2,000 per year to full tuition.

Requirements: To be admitted to the music minor programs, students must consult with the undergraduate director and receive his/her approval. The minor in music theory is awarded for successful completion of 18 credits distributed as follows: Required courses (12 credits): MUS 131 Harmony and Counterpoint I, MUS 132 Harmony and Counterpoint II, MUS 231 Harmony and Counterpoint III, MUS 232 Harmony and Counterpoint IV. Two upper-division courses in music theory (6 credits).
ScholarshipAmount: Varies; for example, Presidential Scholarship covers full tuition, Provost's Scholarship is $2,000.

Requirements: Application for admission to the minor can be made once a student has achieved U3 status at Stony Brook and has a minimum GPA of 3.0. Application must be made before completion of the first semester of the senior year.
Department: College of Engineering and Applied Sciences
Description: The Nanotechnology Studies (NTS) minor is an interdisciplinary program designed for students wishing to pursue careers or graduate studies in fields that integrate knowledge of science, engineering, and technology with an understanding of the societal impact and entrepreneurial aspects of nanotechnology. It is a STEM-designated minor open to all majors. The minor will provide students with a solid foundation in the fundamental science and engineering principles of nanotechnology and an appreciation for its broader implications.
ScholarshipAmount: Varies, amounts range from $2,000 to full New York State tuition

ProgramName: Minor in Native American and Indigenous Studies
Requirements: To declare the minor, students should contact the undergraduate program director listed on the Program Faculty tab.
Description: The Minor in Native American and Indigenous Studies is an interdisciplinary program designed to give students a comprehensive understanding of the histories, cultures, and contemporary experiences of Native American and Indigenous peoples. The minor draws on courses from various departments including Africana Studies, Anthropology, English, History, Political Science, and Sociology. Students will explore a range of topics, including Indigenous sovereignty, land rights, environmental justice, cultural preservation, and decolonization movements. The program encourages critical thinking about Indigenous issues from both historical and contemporary perspectives, fostering a nuanced understanding of Native American and Indigenous contributions to global societies.

Requirements: All courses offered for the minor must be passed with a letter grade of C or higher. The minor in Optics is administered by the Department of Physics and Astronomy. Completion of the minor requires 21 to 24 credits.
Description: The Minor in Optics provides students with a fundamental education in optics and photonics. This program is suitable for students from a range of science and engineering majors who wish to demonstrate to future employers or graduate schools a proficiency in the field of optics. The minor requires completion of a total of 18 credits from the approved list of courses. The selection of courses is approved by the Program Director. Successful completion of the minor is recorded on the student's official transcript.

Requirements: Completion of the minor requires 18 credits in philosophy. No more than six credits of transfer work may be used for the minor. All courses must be passed with a grade of C or higher. At least 12 credits must be in courses numbered 300 or higher. PHI 108 is a required course for the minor and may be used to satisfy three of the 18 credits.
Description: The minor in philosophy provides students with an opportunity to explore philosophical problems and ways of thinking. The minor is a useful complement to a wide variety of majors, helping students to develop analytical and interpretive skills that are valuable in any field. The requirements for the minor are structured to provide students with a solid foundation in the history of philosophy, while also allowing them to pursue their own interests in specific areas of philosophy.

Requirements: Students should declare the minor as early as possible but no later than the last semester of their senior year by visiting the undergraduate program director in Physics and Astronomy. Completion of the minor in Physics requires a minimum of 20 credits. All courses for the minor must be passed with a letter grade of C or higher. At least 12 credits of courses at the 300-level or higher must be taken at Stony Brook.
Description: The minor in Physics gives students an opportunity to obtain a broader science background and an introduction to Physics as a basic science. It provides the necessary foundation for students interested in graduate studies in areas such as Biophysics, Medical Physics, and Astronomy.

Requirements: Declaration of the minor requires a minimum g.p.a. of 2.0. Completion of the minor requires a g.p.a. of 2.0 in all courses taken for the minor. All courses taken for the minor must be passed with a letter grade of C or higher.
Description: The Department of Political Science offers a minor in Political Science. The minor offers students the opportunity to learn about the nature of political power, the institutions through which it is exercised, the policies it yields, the processes through which it is formed, and the ideas and values that shape and challenge it, both in the United States and across the globe. By exposing students to the various aspects of political analysis, the minor is designed to help students acquire a richer understanding of current events, hone their analytical and critical thinking skills, and enhance their ability to express themselves clearly and effectively both orally and in writing. The minor may be combined with any major. Students interested in the minor should consult with the undergraduate director of the Department of Political Science for help in planning their course of study.

The Minor in Professional Writing provides instruction in how to communicate clearly and effectively in a variety of professional and public contexts. It is a valuable credential for students considering careers that require strong writing skills, such as business, law, medicine, journalism, public relations, technical writing, scientific writing, and publishing. The Minor develops critical thinking and research skills, as well as the ability to adapt writing to different purposes and audiences. Students will gain experience writing a variety of professional documents, including proposals, reports, letters, memos, web content, and other forms of professional discourse. It is an excellent complement to any major.

ProgramName: Minor in Real Estate and Insurance
Description: This minor is designed for students in any major who are interested in understanding the fundamental principles of real estate and insurance. This minor will provide students with the foundational knowledge and skills to pursue careers in real estate, insurance, or related fields. The minor combines courses from Business, Economics, and Sustainability Studies, offering a multidisciplinary perspective on the complex issues and challenges in these industries. Students will learn about property valuation, real estate development, risk management, types of insurance, and the economic and legal aspects of real estate and insurance markets. Upon completion of this minor, students will have a strong understanding of the real estate and insurance industries, enhancing their career prospects in various sectors.

Requirements:
The minor in religious studies requires 18 credits. No more than one course may be taken under the Pass/NC option.

1. RLS 101, What is Religion?
2. Five additional courses chosen from the list of approved courses below, including:
a. At least two RLS courses at the 300 level
b. No more than two courses from any one department other than Religious Studies.
Description: The minor in Religious Studies offers students an opportunity to explore the historical and cultural significance of religion as a human phenomenon. Religious beliefs, practices, and institutions have shaped civilizations and continue to play a crucial role in contemporary society. The minor takes an interdisciplinary approach to the study of religion, drawing upon methods and insights from history, philosophy, anthropology, sociology, literature, and art history. Students are introduced to a broad range of religious traditions from around the world and across different historical periods, including Judaism, Christianity, Islam, Buddhism, Hinduism, and indigenous religions. The program emphasizes critical thinking, analytical skills, and cultural understanding, preparing students to engage with diverse perspectives and complex global issues. The minor is suitable for students pursuing a wide variety of majors, as it complements studies in the humanities, social sciences, and even some natural sciences, providing a valuable foundation for careers in education, journalism, public service, law, and international relations.

Requirements: Students interested in the minor should consult with the undergraduate director of the Department of Germanic and Slavic Languages and Literatures.
Description: The Russian Studies minor is an interdisciplinary program designed to give students a comprehensive understanding of Russia’s history, culture, politics, and language. Students can choose to concentrate on a variety of fields and periods through courses in history, political science, sociology, anthropology, and literature. The minor requires a minimum of 21 credits.

Requirements: Completion of the minor requires 18 credits in courses approved for the minor. No more than nine credits may be from any one department. No more than six credits may be from courses taken at another institution. All courses for the minor must be passed with a letter grade of C or higher.
Description: The South Asian Studies Minor is an interdisciplinary program designed to give students a critical perspective on the societies and cultures of South Asia and its diaspora. Students will have the opportunity to study South Asia from various disciplinary perspectives, including anthropology, art history, history, political science, religious studies, and sociology. South Asia, an area encompassing India, Pakistan, Bangladesh, Sri Lanka, Nepal, Bhutan, and the Maldives, is home to a quarter of the world's population and is a growing force in the global economy and polity. Through a range of courses, students will explore topics such as colonialism, postcolonialism, nationalism, gender, religion, migration, and development within the region. The minor will enhance students' understanding of a region of increasing global importance and prepare them for careers in government, non-governmental organizations, journalism, business, and academia related to South Asia.

ProgramName: Minor in Spanish Language and Literature
Requirements: Students must declare the minor in Spanish no later than the first semester of their senior year. All courses offered for the minor must be passed with a letter grade of C or higher. Completion of the minor requires 18 credits in Spanish beyond SPN 112.
Description: The minor in Spanish Language and Literature provides students with knowledge of the literature, culture, and civilization of the Spanish-speaking world while developing and refining their linguistic abilities. The minor is a valuable complement to a wide range of majors, including those in the humanities, social sciences, natural sciences, and business. It prepares students for a variety of professions in a globalized society.

Requirements: Students wishing to minor in Sustainability Studies should meet with a SoMAS Undergraduate Adviser to declare the minor and plan a course of study. Students must have a g.p.a. of 2.0 or higher.
Department: School of Marine and Atmospheric Sciences
Description: The Minor in Sustainability Studies focuses on the interdisciplinary character of sustainability studies and the interaction between human and natural systems. Through an interdisciplinary curriculum, students in the Minor in Sustainability Studies learn to combine perspectives from different disciplines to address the complex issues of sustainability. Students learn to recognize the inherent linkages between ecology, economics, ethics, equity, technology, policy, and other dimensions of sustainability. Students learn to consider a range of solutions to sustainability problems, and how to develop and implement these solutions.

EnglishScore: If your native language is not English, you will be required to provide proof of your English proficiency. Stony Brook University accepts TOEFL, IELTS, Duolingo, and PTE Academic scores. The requirement may be waived for students who have studied for two or more years in a high school, college or university in the United States, United Kingdom, Ireland, Australia, New Zealand, or Anglophone areas of Africa, Canada or the Caribbean, and have earned a passing grade in at least one college-level English composition course.
Requirements: Interested students should email the undergraduate director, Julie Sheehan. The minor is open to all students, no matter what their major. Students must complete the minor with a GPA of 3.0 or higher in all courses taken for the minor. Prerequisites: Wrt 102 and CWL 202.
Description: The Minor in Television Writing at Stony Brook University prepares students to enter the rapidly growing field of television scriptwriting. The program is designed to give students a comprehensive understanding of the craft of writing for television, from sitcoms to hour-long dramas, with an emphasis on creating compelling characters, developing engaging storylines, and mastering the formatting and structural conventions of the industry. Through a combination of workshops, lectures, and hands-on writing assignments, students will develop a portfolio of work that demonstrates their ability to craft high-quality television scripts. The program also offers opportunities for students to connect with industry professionals, gain practical experience, and explore potential career paths in television writing.

Requirements: The minor in Theatre Arts provides students with a general introduction to the theory and practice of theatre. Students must take at least 21 credits for the Theatre Arts minor. All courses offered for the minor must be passed with a letter grade of C or higher. Completion of the minor requires 21 credits.
Description: The Minor in Theatre Arts is designed to give students an opportunity to experience various aspects of the art and discipline of theatre while complementing their major course of study. The minor requires a total of 21 credits. Students must complete one course from each of the following four areas: Theatre History and Literature, Performance, Design and Technology, and Dramatic Theory. In addition, students must complete three credits of a capstone experience and three credits of theatre electives. The remaining six credits may be taken in any theatre area. A minimum grade of C must be achieved in all courses for the minor. Students interested in auditioning or interviewing for departmental productions are encouraged to contact the Theatre Arts Program for information regarding opportunities. It is also recommended that students meet with the undergraduate director to discuss specific courses appropriate for their goals. For more information regarding the program, please contact the Theatre Arts Program at (631) 632-7330.
ScholarshipAmount: Varies; Departmental scholarships range from $500 to $1,000.

ProgramName: Minor in Women's and Gender Studies
Requirements: Students should declare the minor in Women's and Gender Studies by the beginning of their junior year at the latest. To plan a course of study, they must meet with the Undergraduate Program Director.
Description: The minor in Women's, Gender, and Sexuality Studies (WGS) provides students with an interdisciplinary understanding of the social and cultural construction of gender, the historical and contemporary status of women, and the importance of sexuality in human experience. The minor is a useful complement to a wide array of majors across the humanities, social sciences, sciences, and professional schools. The minor encourages students to analyze the social world, understand power relations, and engage in social change. It provides students with critical thinking, writing, and communication skills applicable to any career, as well as an understanding of diversity and intersectionality essential for global citizenship.

Requirements: To declare the minor, students must complete the Undergraduate Major/Minor Declaration form and submit it to the Program in Writing and Rhetoric office. All courses must be passed with a letter grade of C or higher. A minimum g.p.a. of 2.0 is required for the 18 credits.
Description: A minor in Writing and Rhetoric provides students with the opportunity to refine their analytical and rhetorical skills as readers and writers. Through the study of a range of texts, contexts, and genres, students cultivate an understanding of writing as a social and intellectual activity in academic, professional, and civic life. The minor offers students the opportunity to choose from courses focusing on topics such as rhetoric and composition theory, digital rhetoric, professional writing, writing for social change, and the teaching of writing.
